business.start.para: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT(Senator West) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate—
(a) notes the overwhelming choice for independence exercised by the East Timorese people on 30 August 1999;

(b) welcomes United Nations Security Council Resolution 1264 authorising a multinational force to restore peace and security in East Timor, protect the United Nations' mission in East Timor and facilitate humanitarian assistance;
(c) endorses Australia's agreement to the United Nations Secretary General's request that Australia contribute to and lead the multinational force;
(d) expresses its full support for the Australians serving with the multinational force and its full confidence in them; and
(e) looks forward to their safe return.

There is no more serious a decision for a government than to send its nation's armed forces abroad. There is no greater obligation on an Australian parliament than to consider carefully the reasons for that decision. Yesterday, the first contingent of Australian troops arrived in East Timor as part of an Australian led and United Nations mandated multinational peacekeeping force. As of this morning, there were about 1,500 troops from Australia and other countries in East Timor. By tomorrow morning, there will be about 2,500. In these circumstances, it is important that the government should report to the parliament on the reasons for the deployment of troops, what their task is and what the decision means for Australia's foreign and defence policy. It is an opportunity for the parliament to express its united support for the task ahead and for the special burden which Australia will inevitably bear as the leader of the multinational force in East Timor. Our armed forces are entitled to know they have the unqualified support of the Australian parliament and the Australian community.

On 15 September 1999, the United Nations Security Council unanimously authorised the establishment of a multinational force in East Timor. The resolution gives the force three tasks in its mandate: first, to restore peace and security to East Timor; second, to protect and support the United Nations mission in East Timor; and, third, to facilitate, within force capabilities, humanitarian assistance operations in East Timor. The multinational force has been authorised by the United Nations Security Council under chapter VII of the UN Charter to use all necessary measures to achieve its mandate. The multinational force will prepare the ground for the United Nations to complete its task of managing East Timor's transition to independence. This will involve the arrival as soon as possible of a fully-fledged Blue Helmet UN peacekeeping operation and the establishment of a UN transitional administration. The Australian government will be doing everything it can to ensure that the UN transitional administration is ready to take over when the Indonesian parliament ratifies East Timor's independence.

The government's expectation is that the multinational force will be about 7,500 strong. Australia is initially deploying 2,000 troops, increasing to 4,500 if necessary. Australia will provide the force commander, Major General Cosgrove, and Thailand the deputy force commander, Major General Songkitti. We estimate the cost of Australia's contribution to be in the order of $500 million in the financial year 1999-2000. Under the terms of the Security Council resolution, costs will be borne by participating states or met from voluntary contributions to a special trust fund that has been established by the United Nations.

We have firm commitments to participate from more than 12 countries. These include Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand from ASEAN. New Zealand, Britain and Canada are making valuable contributions. The United States will provide significant support, including airlift capability, communications, intelligence, engineering support and helicopters. There are many other contributions, including contributions from Korea and China. The Minister for Defence will provide fuller details separately. Some countries that are not contributing troops will contribute financially to the UN trust fund, and we welcome Japan's offer of a substantial contribution. The government particularly appreciates the support of all the countries that are contributing troops or financial assistance, especially Thailand which so promptly responded to the Prime Minister's request for assistance in providing a substantial military contingent as well as the deputy commander of the force. I draw the attention of the Senate to the very strong support offered by President Kim Dae-jung of Korea during his recent visit. Likewise, President Estrada of the Philippines and other leaders have given strong support to the UN multinational force.

Australia is not alone in this venture. The region has responded readily and promptly in creating this force with us under the umbrella of the United Nations. The government has every confidence in the professionalism of the Australian Defence Force and its preparedness for this operation. The units have inspired confidence by the speed with which they have got themselves ready and the proficiency with which they are deploying. We congratulate the Defence Force on this. The task facing our men and women is not easy. We hope it will be accomplished soon, but we have to be prepared for the possibility that it will be protracted. The risk of casualties is a serious one: this is a dangerous operation. The rules of engagement for Australia's forces will allow them to use lethal force to achieve their mandate to restore peace and security. Our troops will not be sent into danger with one hand tied behind their backs.

Indonesia has undertaken to cooperate with the multinational force. We welcome the fact that the force commander has been able to report that he has enjoyed good cooperation on the ground from the Indonesian commander in East Timor. It is the case, however, that the multinational force could be a target of attack from the pro-integration militias. It would be foolhardy to plan on any other basis. In the past, the militias have been supported by some in the Indonesian armed forces. We sincerely hope that all parts of the Indonesian armed forces understand that it would not be in the interests of their country to continue such support.

The formation of the multinational force is a result of strenuous efforts on the part of many, including the United Nations Secretary-General, Mr Kofi Annan. Through the recent negotiations establishing the peacekeeping force, he has displayed great diplomatic skill, patience, determination and a clear understanding of the issues at stake. The speed of the international community's response is due in good measure to his commitment.

Australia's leadership of the multinational force is the most recent step in a sustained effort by the government to help resolve the East Timor issue. Apart from the human toll from the conflict in East Timor during nearly 25 years, the issue has held Indonesia back internationally and has been a cause of tension in Australia's relationship with Indonesia. The resignation of President Suharto and the moves towards democracy last year in Indonesia opened the door to a possible resolution in East Timor. Moreover, the conflict in East Timor was worsening. The Prime Minister, Mr Howard, therefore wrote in December last year to President Habibie encouraging him to take a different approach to East Timor. The Prime Minister suggested to him that he negotiate directly with the East Timorese and consider the option of autonomy for East Timor with an act of self-determination after a substantial period of autonomy.

For a quarter of a century, governments of both persuasions in Australia had reluctantly acquiesced in Indonesia's policy towards East Timor. Although the issue was raised from time to time, Australian governments were not prepared to see the relationship with Indonesia damaged over East Timor. The Prime Minister's letter, therefore, represented a significant change in Australia's approach.

Subsequently, in January this year, President Habibie took the bold and principled step of agreeing to a UN supervised ballot on independence for East Timor. We indicated at the time that Australia would have preferred a longer period of substantial autonomy for East Timor before a ballot was held. We recognised, however, that once the decision had been taken to hold a ballot, the dynamics in East Timor and internationally had changed forever. The best and only realistic course of action was to help the United Nations ensure as safe a ballot as possible. If we had argued for a delay, the opportunity could well have been lost entirely.

Australia was not a party to the agreement among Indonesia, Portugal and the United Nations on the holding of the ballot and subsequent transition arrangements. This agreement was based on a promise by the Indonesian government that it would ensure security in East Timor throughout the process. The Australian government, well aware of the links between the armed forces and the East Timorese militias, mounted a sustained international campaign to press Indonesia to adhere to the commitment to provide security it had made to the United Nations.

In order to ensure an environment as free as possible of violence and intimidation, the Australian government insisted on an increase in civilian police advisers to some 300 before the ballot. We insisted that these numbers be again increased for the period immediately after the ballot which, we were aware, was potentially dangerous. Australia can be proud of the performance of our Federal Police, ably led by the UN civilian police commander, Alan Mills. Australian military liaison officers, the staff of the Australian consulate and many Australians, including from the Australian Electoral Commission, helped ensure a fair ballot. The government acknowledge their dedication and bravery in such difficult circumstances.

In the end, on a day that passed without major disruption, the outcome was decisive. East Timorese voted by a margin of four to one for independence. The turnout—with 98.6 per cent of those registered casting a vote—and the integrity of the process vindicated the United Nations' judgment to proceed with the ballot despite threats from the pro-integration militias. The conduct of the ballot was a tribute to the work of UNAMET and the leadership of its head, Ian Martin.

After the ballot, however, Indonesia's armed forces proved unwilling or unable to maintain security. We have all been horrified by the violence against the people of East Timor, by the mass flight of people within the territory and from it and by the scale of the destruction of property and infrastructure. This was the background to Australia's efforts to establish a multinational peacekeeping force under the United Nations and to convince Indonesia to invite one in.

In numerous telephone conversations with the United Nations Secretary-General, President Clinton, President Habibie and other regional leaders before, during and after the APEC meeting in Auckland, the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, emphasised the need for decisive international action to restore peace to East Timor, deal with the looming humanitarian disaster and create the conditions for the transition to independence for East Timor. It is to the great credit of President Habibie that he agreed to invite in international peacekeepers. This was a difficult decision for him personally and politically.

Ours has been the correct and only responsible course of action. Some have argued that Australia should have insisted on a UN peacekeeping force before the ballot or argued for a delay in the ballot. It cannot be emphasised too strongly, however, that there was never any prospect that Indonesia would have accepted a peacekeeping force before the ballot. It was raised directly by the Prime Minister with President Habibie in Bali in May. He made it clear that any such proposal was totally unacceptable to Indonesia. Insisting on a peacekeeping force would have meant no ballot. Insisting on a delay in the ballot could well have meant no ballot. Many in President Habibie's government and much of the Indonesian leadership opposed the ballot. Indonesia had resisted any change for East Timor over nearly 25 years.

Nor would the international community have been ready to form a peacekeeping force. An international peacekeeping force has only now become possible because the world has seen 78.5 per cent of East Timorese vote for independence and is not prepared to see them denied the independence they voted for. The United Nations made the decision that the ballot should go ahead on schedule. As the UN Secretary-General has said, if the United Nations had not accepted a ballot in the circumstances available, the ballot probably would not have happened. We did not have the right to take that away from the East Timorese.

In the face of the violence after the ballot, a few called for Australia to send troops to East Timor without the consent of Indonesia. That would have been tantamount to declaring war. It was an option no responsible government could have contemplated despite the distress we, along with all Australians, felt about the terrible events in East Timor. That has been recognised by the Australian people. Nevertheless, the international community has moved faster than in any other case of which we are aware to form a peacekeeping force. That has happened because of the leadership that Australia has shown in forming a coalition of countries under the UN umbrella. It has also happened only because the government, aware of the potential risks, took the precaution early this year of bringing an extra brigade of the Australian Army to a higher level of readiness in order to respond to any peacekeeping needs.

Developments in East Timor reaffirm some of the home truths about Australia's place in the region, to which we pointed when we came to office. The first truth is that foreign policy needs to be based on a clear sense of the national interest and on our values. As Lord Palmerston once pithily observed, `nations do not have permanent friends, only permanent interests'.

This government has from the beginning put a clear sense of the national interest at the core of the government's approach to foreign and trade policy. We should not delude ourselves that relations between counties turn on the personal rapport of leaders, the sentiment of governments or so-called special relationships. Our relationships are most productive when they are realistic, concentrating on mutual interest, building on those areas where cooperation is possible and openly recognising—where they exist—differences in values and political systems.

The second truth is that in occupying what the Prime Minister has called a unique intersection—a Western nation next to Asia with strong links to the United States and Europe—Australia deploys unique assets in its relationship with Asia. These links and our history are not an embarrassment to be lived down. We have stopped worrying about whether we are Asian, in Asia, enmeshed in Asia or part of a mythical East Asian hemisphere; we have got on with the job of being ourselves. In turn the region has recognised that we are an asset to our region and have a constructive role to play in it. Australia's global links have enabled us to work with the United Nations, the United States and others to persuade Indonesia that their best interests would be met by inviting in a multinational force. Moreover, our defence links with all these countries, through ANZUS, the five-power defence arrangements and our bilateral defence cooperation programs, provide us with a capacity to cooperate effectively with them and lead a multinational force.

Third, Australia's alliance with the United States does work. The results reflect the effort the government have put into strengthening the alliance since we came to office. Neither Australia nor the region looks to the United States to solve the East Timor problem, but the alliance relationship has underpinned a visible and operationally significant US contribution to the peacekeeping force. We are completely satisfied with the scale of the US contribution.

Fourth, the government has been right to exempt defence spending from the necessary budget cuts of our first term. The defence reforms we have pursued have put more resources into the combat capability of the Defence Force. The need to examine an increase in defence spending has already been foreshadowed. Australia faces an uncertain regional security situation. The resource and force structure implications of this will be significant. The government's next white paper on defence will examine the likely demands on the ADF for regional peacekeeping, the evacuation of Australian nationals under difficult conditions and the capacity to participate in coalition operations. While the Defence Force must be equipped to defend Australia from direct attack, it must also be able to respond to other more likely contingencies.

Finally, national interest cannot be pursued without regard to the values of the Australian community. Australia has no quarrel with the Indonesian nation. Both countries have an interest in getting on with the other. We share important common interests. We are neighbours. Indonesia is the largest country in South-East Asia. How it develops and behaves will influence the strategic balance in our region. It is a significant economic partner for Australia. Australian policy approaches need to take account of the changes that are taking place in Indonesia. We welcome the transition towards democracy that is occurring. In time this will strengthen Indonesia and our capacity to work with it.

We recognise the enormous difficulties that Indonesia faces as it responds to the most serious economic crisis in decades and traverses this political transition. Indeed, the government have been in the forefront in helping Indonesia manage those difficulties and in garnering greater international support and understanding for its problems. We also recognise the complexities of governing a nation of over 200 million people spread over thousands of islands. Successful economic and political management by Indonesia of a united but diverse nation is important for Indonesia's own future stability and prosperity.

But none of this means that Australia's objective can be to maintain a good relationship at all costs or at the expense of doing the right thing according to our own values. We seek a relationship of mutual respect and mutual benefit with Indonesia. On that basis, we look forward to working closely with the new democratically elected government of Indonesia to be formed in the near future. Events in East Timor have put our relationship with Indonesia under great strain. Some resent Australia's efforts to help in East Timor or seek to use us as a scapegoat, but we should keep this in perspective. The criticisms of Australian policy that we have seen and heard in Indonesia are not the only Indonesian voices. There are many people who identify with democracy and support the steps Indonesia is taking in this direction, who are appalled at the total breakdown of security in East Timor and who will understand and sympathise with the response from Australia and the rest of the international community.

We ask those in Australia who exercise their legitimate right of protest to refrain from violence against people and property and not to impede people going about their normal business. Such behaviour is unlawful and will be treated as such. It damages the interests of our own citizens and has a counterproductive effect on Indonesian attitudes. The government is encouraged by the commitment of so many of Indonesia's political leaders to respect the vote cast by the East Timorese. We look forward to the new Indonesian parliament formally deciding to allow East Timor to separate from Indonesia.

When this government came to office some commentators said Asia would not accept us. The comment was revealing in its assumption that Australia had to be invited into a regional framework. It was a view of Australia that underestimated the strengths of Australia's institutions, our economy and our capacity and will to achieve national goals. Our safe passage through the Asian economic storm makes that view even more dated. The truth is that our economic, military and other credentials are respected and give us a capacity to help in the region. Just as we were in a position to assist our neighbours during the Asian economic crisis, so also on East Timor we have shown that we have the capacity under the United Nations to work with our regional partners in putting together a multinational peacekeeping force. It is an example of both our commitment to the region and our capacity to make a constructive and practical contribution to its affairs.

The deployment of Australian troops in East Timor meets the test of national interest in two respects. First, our troops are going in the spirit of Australia's military tradition to defend what our society believes is right. They are not going to occupy territory, impose our will or act against the legitimate interests of another country. They are going at the request of the United Nations with the agreement of East Timor. They are going to defend the choice the East Timorese have exercised for independence in a free vote granted to them by their government with the blessing of the whole international community. They are going in to facilitate the humanitarian relief that is so desperately needed for the hundreds of thousands of displaced people in East Timor.

Our troops are going to East Timor to put an end to the sort of violence we have seen in recent days. Apart from the human cost, this scale of violence undermines Australia's own interests in a stable region. Our troops will prepare the way for the United Nations to undertake the vital task of developing a transitional political and administrative framework for East Timor. For the East Timorese, this offers the hope of reconciliation among groups that have fought each other for decades and the opportunity to create their own future. They have a responsibility to come to grips with these issues. For Indonesia, this means it will more readily be able to concentrate on its nation building task with the full support of the international community.

Madam Deputy President, Australia's contribution to the peacekeeping force in East Timor is the biggest commitment of Australian forces in 30 years. Our men and women go well trained, well led and in a just cause. At this time, our thoughts and prayers are with those in the field as they go to help restore peace and security to a people who themselves once helped Australian soldiers at a time of need and who have suffered much. At home, we undertake to give them our support and to watch over their families while they are away. I commend the motion to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —The opposition supports the motion that is before the Senate. Yesterday and today Australian forces landed in East Timor, taking part in the most dangerous military operation Australia has undertaken since the Vietnam War. These brave men and women now step into harm's way, bringing all their years of dedication and training and all their reserves of skill and courage to the protection of innocent people. As we speak here today, they and their colleagues from other nations are making their contribution to the creation of an independent state of East Timor. Our Australian forces march at the head of a long column which stretches back through time to the young men of a young nation who landed on the beaches of Gallipoli. We honour them all, and all of them are there in spirit as their descendants land on foreign soil.

speech.para: It is vitally important to these soldiers to know that the nation is behind them. I know a number of our troops have expressed their concern that the same fate would befall them as befell Australian soldiers returning from Vietnam—that because many Australians were opposed to the conflict in which they fought, the community would not give them the welcome home they deserved. Let me assure those soldiers that that will not happen. Let me assure them: your country is behind you, your government is behind you, the opposition is behind you and the Australian people are behind you. We wish you well. We are proud of you. We want to see you home soon and home safe. Our thoughts are with your families and your loved ones at this time.

Our thoughts must also be with the kind of backing our troops deserve: they deserve the very best. This is a peace enforcement mission—it will need substantial supplies of war stocks. We need to make sure they have first-rate medical facilities and that they are properly resourced down to the ground, with boots, packs, water supplies, ammunition and the like. This is something the government is going to have to think its way through and stay on top of right through this particular situation. We are turning a new page in our military history. This is doing something different: this is taking the weight ourselves, this is taking our responsibility. Let me also say I very much hope that the Minister for Defence and his office take a personal and detailed interest in looking after our troops on the ground. There is no substitute for care and attention from the very top, and no-one could deny our troops deserve it.

It is right that the Australian people should feel some relief that peacekeepers are now on the ground in East Timor. It is right that we feel some relief, some licence to hope that the killing, the destruction, the starvation and the deportation will soon cease. The opposition welcome the arrival of a multinational peacekeeping force in East Timor. We particularly welcome the participation of our allies in this. They have stood shoulder to shoulder with us at this most difficult of times, and that contribution will not be forgotten. We hope that this force will put a stop to the terrible violence and destruction we have all witnessed these last three weeks. We welcome the fact that the landing appears to have gone without incident. We hope that it will pave the way for a free, independent and secure East Timorese state. We register today our concern at INTERFET's mandate—in particular, the omission of a requirement for the militia who caused this violence to disarm and for the withdrawal of the Indonesian Army, the TNI, from the territory—and the unresolved danger of partition of East Timor. These are concerns not only for the safety of the peacekeepers but also for the East Timorese and the future of their independent homeland.

I wish I could leave it there. I wish we were able to welcome the arrival of peacekeepers for the positive development that it is and go no further into this terrible chain of events. But we must go further, and this has to be understood. We did not need to come to this point. We did not need to have Dili in ruins. We did not need to have hundreds of thousands of Timorese displaced. We did not need to have possibly thousands of them dead, amongst them many of the leaders who would have made the future of an independent Timor brighter. We did not need to have a breach between Australia and our nearest neighbour of 210 million people so profound that it may take a generation to repair it. These events were not preordained; there were alternative outcomes. What got us here were policy errors, and those policy errors are mostly the responsibility of Indonesia, which for 25 years failed to reconcile the people of East Timor to Indonesian rule and whose leaders believed that there was a military solution to their problem.

Our abhorrence of the recent violence in East Timor is not directed at the Indonesian people. We have nothing but affection and respect for the people of Indonesia. But we have nothing but contempt for the people who have perpetrated the crimes of these last three weeks—contempt and determination that they be brought to justice for their crimes against humanity. But these terrible events demand that we in Australia also examine our role in this crisis. We, after all, claimed with pride that we were the catalyst for these events. Had they worked out more positively, we would have justly taken some of the credit. It is not good enough to solve a problem you yourself have created. We should not be in the business, particularly when thousands of human lives have been lost, of congratulating ourselves on second-best solutions, of creating a problem and then asking congratulations for having solved it. The question Australians rightly ask of their government is whether, with all its resources and all its expertise and all its power, it did everything it could to prevent the events of the last few weeks in the first place as opposed to how quickly or otherwise it managed to respond when things had already taken their tragic course.

There is now a dawning understanding that our diplomacy has failed in crucial elements of this most critical of times. There is a dawning understanding that we have arrived at this point basically because our diplomacy has not been up to the standards of our armed forces. There has been powerful evidence warning of precisely what has now happened in East Timor for months now. We started with a situation where we were getting the intelligence reports that we needed to indicate to us that something was seriously wrong on the ground. Our diplomacy failed at the highest levels to respond. The Prime Minister was not engaged, as is evident by his performance in the United States. The Minister for Foreign Affairs was in a state of denial, and we had the Minister for Defence spending the year—in which, for the first time in three decades, Australian troops had the potential to be committed in a very difficult and damaging situation—botching the job of sacking his secretary.

What all this means, of course, is that our troops go into a ruined nation. Four weeks ago there existed a potentially viable nation. Now what they are going into is a deeply wounded society, with the task of reconciliation enormously more difficult. We say these things today not because we want an occasion to establish some point of differentiation between ourselves and the government but because the government's performance has not been up to the mark. It must change and, unless it is exposed, it will not change. So we are obliged to do these things in the interest of decent national security policy in this country. We will continue to keep them up to the mark on this.

There will be much claim and counterclaim in the months and years to come about this period of our diplomatic history. I want to focus on two issues today: firstly, that the horrific events of the last three weeks in East Timor were both foreseeable, and indeed foreseen, by the Australian government and, secondly, that the Australian government did not take all reasonable steps to get peacekeepers on the ground for the ballot and avoid the resultant carnage.

I now turn to these two crucial points in detail. The first of these is that the Australian government had warning and an expectation that the ballot would provoke violence. We are told now that the extent of the violence was unforeseen. That is implausible for three reasons. Firstly, the Australian government has, by its own admission, the best intelligence of any country in the world on East Timor, the Indonesian military and the events of the last three weeks. This has been confirmed by one of Australia's foremost intelligence experts, Professor Desmond Ball. When asked by Paul Lyneham if Australian intelligence would have picked up the militia and the army's preparations for the slaughter in East Timor, he said:

Yes. Yes, I am sure. Already by last May, in private discussions . . . which I had with members of our intelligence agencies, it was apparent that planning and preparations were already under way then.
Reports from the DIO from 4 March this year state:
ABRI could apprehend or easily control pro-Indonesian militias, but has chosen not to do so . . . unless Jakarta takes firm action, ABRI elements will continue to support intimidation and violence.

The clear conclusion is that the government's own agencies were foretelling precisely what happened over the last three weeks, and doing so more than six months ago. Secondly, there is the one tragic area of agreement between the aggressors and the victims in East Timor: both sides predicted bloodshed after the ballot. Xanana Gusmao wrote a letter in March this year arguing for the deployment of an international security presence for the ballot. During the same period the militia carried out an infamous massacre in April, killing 45 civilians. The military commander of Dili, Colonel Tono Suratman, publicly threatened that if the East Timorese voted for independence:
. . . all will be destroyed and East Timor won't be as we see it now.

When opposition foreign affairs spokesman Laurie Brereton consistently pointed out the need for peacekeepers before the ballot, from as early as April this year, the Minister for Foreign Affairs sneered in response:
. . . we still hear the call from the bunyip Napoleons for Australia to send heavily armed peacekeeping forces immediately to East Timor.

Finally, there is recognition from the government that at the highest levels they did recognise the danger that sources on the ground were warning them of. John Howard, in his address at Georgetown University in July, said:
Whatever the outcome of the UN ballot, some groups will contest it.
And Alexander Downer on Meet the Press on 5 September said:
. . . we always expected that this would be an extremely tense period, that the losers, being the militias, would be pretty violent in their response to the ballot.
And on 7 September Fran Kelly asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs on Radio National:
Did you ever think things would break down so quickly?
He responded:
Yes, I did think there was a very real risk of that. I obviously have thought that.

This establishes beyond doubt that the government had ample warning from multiple sources of the violence we have seen in East Timor. That placed a heavy responsibility upon them to do what they could to prevent it. It is the opposition's contention that, far from engaging to prevent the violence, there is evidence the government actively argued against peacekeepers going in before the ballot.

The government's argument is that there is little they could have done. On the contrary, we argue there are three key things they should have done: press the case for peacekeepers with the Indonesian government and military, assemble an international coalition to help pressure Indonesia to accept, and assemble a coalition of willing participants in a peacekeeping force.

I now look at these in turn. The government offers only one defence on the issue of pressing peacekeepers with Indonesia. It recounts John Howard's meeting with President Habibie at which the Prime Minister raised the issue of a UN peacekeeping force to enter East Timor before the ballot. Yet after the meeting the Prime Minister declared himself content with an unarmed AFP contingent. We ask: is that all there was? Did the Prime Minister make no other effort? Was that the extent of his determination on this most important of issues?

Let me make this clear: we understand why the Prime Minister put his original plan to Dr Habibie for greater autonomy for East Timor. As far as plans go, it bore a fair resemblance to those advanced by Bishop Belo, Xanana Gusmao and Jose Ramos Horta. What we are deeply concerned about is why, once President Habibie advanced his much more radical plan, the Australian government—knowing the weakness of his domestic position and knowing the challenge this represented to powerful military interests—was not absolutely frantic from day one about improving the security provisions of this plan. The Minister for Foreign Affairs himself said in parliament yesterday:
It was also our view—
in the lead-up to the ballot—

—and, I suspect, for longer than that—that the most dangerous period in this process would be the period immediately after the announcement of the result of the ballot. Of course, that turned out to be true.

But Australia was anything but frantic about security for the ballot. In fact, the record of Australia working other diplomatic channels is in turn inadequate and deeply troubling. The one country that we know had the power to deal with this situation, the one country whose intervention in the end was decisive, was the United States. But our diplomacy was woefully inadequate. When you are lobbying the United States on a crucial issue that is far from their shores, nothing less than a comprehensive and integrated campaign will do. You need to lobby the National Security Council, the Pentagon, the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the Congress, the Senate and, of course, the President.

But is there any evidence that we did these things? No, the great weight of evidence is to the contrary. We have already heard the reports of the Joint Chief of Staff of the US military, General Shelton, that he had not, until things blew up in East Timor, had any approach from the Australians regarding the need for security before or after the ballot. We have had strong complaints from the United States, reported in last week's Australian, that they had not been sufficiently informed about developments in East Timor and the likelihood of the need for a peacekeeping deployment. These complaints come against the background of information that US officials were beginning to register their concern at the inadequacy of security for the East Timor ballot with their own government and directly with Australia. The Australian government could not engage US interest, but their people on the ground were arriving at their own conclusions.

There are two key pieces of evidence supporting this. We asked questions on both of these in early August. The first is the documented concerns of US Assistant Secretary of State, Stanley Roth, who expressed the view that a full-scale peacekeeping operation for East Timor would be necessary, only to be told by the Minister for Foreign Affairs's secretary, Dr Ashton Calvert, that the Australian government opposed this view. The second is the cable from US military command in the Pacific to the Commander Australian Theatre, Air Vice Marshal Treloar, investigating the attachment of Australian military officers to a potential peace enforcement operation in East Timor.

Let us never forget that when we asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs a question about this cable, he said he had not read it. It was implausible then; it is a tragedy now. It has become only too clear, ever since violence erupted in East Timor, that the government, in addition to having failed to establish a peacekeeping presence before the ballot, also failed to do the proper groundwork of preparing a contingency plan to get peacekeepers in quickly if, as they clearly had every reason to expect, violence erupted.

This is what has led to the chorus of outrage from the most respected journalists and commentators in this country. It is not just the Labor Party saying this. It is Greg Sheridan, Laurie Oakes, Tony Wright, Paul Kelly, Peter Hartcher, Karen Middleton and Paul Lyneham. And it is even the foreign minister's own former adviser, Greg Hunt.

Australians may ask a further question, of course, and that is where this will all end. I think it is fair to say that none of us here knows the answer to that question. It will need to be answered—across all the dimensions—in the weeks and months to come. War crimes investigations, the cost of reconstruction, the likely duration of Australia's military commitment, Australia's future security posture and our relations with Indonesia and so forth: these are properly questions for another day, and I indicate now the opposition's intention to pursue them at the appropriate time.

But several areas deserve some scrutiny. The first of these is the question of the end game. We can now hope that everything goes well. We would then see a situation where the Indonesian parliament passes in a month or so a resolution to give Timor independence, a transitional administration is put in place for a period of time, a proper reconciliation process takes place and, some time early in the new year, the government emerges in Timor with only a limited requirement of assistance from us. But what if that doesn't happen? What if there is no clear-cut decision from the Indonesian administration? What is our position then to the United Nations? What is our position to our allies, the people that we have mobilised? We are grateful to our allies, as I said earlier, but we will need them right through to the conclusion of this particular process. We also need UN cover—proper UN cover—for this mission, as soon as we can possibly get it. These are things we must be engaging on right now, if we are not to make the same mistakes again—only this time with thousands of our own troops on the ground.

This leads on to the question of our relationship with Indonesia. This is the most complicated task we have at hand. For whatever good reasons, it has to be said that a good relationship, which governments have sought on a bipartisan basis for 50 years with Indonesia, has disintegrated on the watch of this government. That is clearly not all the government's fault. The Indonesians have snatched defeat from the jaws of victory. Picture the situation which would have occurred either if President Habibie's response had been along the lines of what he was actually asked for by the Timorese and delivered or if he had had the support of the military to carry it through.

There are a lot of people in Indonesia at the moment blaming Australia for their circumstances, but the truth of the matter is that Australia has only responded to a situation which they have initiated. It is they who put this issue on the table; it is they who said that they would be responsible for upholding law and order; and it is they who have not been able to deliver on that.

Nevertheless, having said all that, at some point of time serious efforts have to be made to restore the relationship. But with all of the errors of the government we have found one thing as Australians in this crisis. That has been the Australian people standing up and accepting responsibility, the Australian people looking at what it means to stand alone or to have to stand alone. The lesson that we have been taught here is that there is public investment and public goods, and defence just happens to be one of them. We have had an accountant's view of the world, and an accountant's view of the Australian nation, for three years now. The next phase of national development, of nation building, is going to revolve around the skills of our people—as surely as now the future of an important part of our foreign policy revolves around the skills of our armed services.

In conclusion, it is too easy for us to accept second-best in this. The horror has been so great that the natural human reaction is to not want to explore the question of whether we did all we could to avert it. The natural human reaction is to want to believe we did everything we could. The temptation is to gloss over the hard analysis in favour of an answer that is easier to bear. It is a temptation we must resist. We owe it to the East Timorese dead and displaced and we also owe it to the future of East Timor and what will be a troubled and dangerous relationship with its much larger neighbour.

We should not be in the business here of comforting ourselves with a soothing fiction that we did all we could. Our sense of honour as a nation demands in this case that we choose the truth over our own comfort. It might not be easy to confront these realities, but we must do so. Australia encouraged this ballot. We could have justifiably taken credit, had events followed a happier course. That they did not demands that we attend to this issue, painful as it is, with honesty and candour and that we do so now.

In sum, the opposition argues as follows: we welcome and support the presence of a peacekeeping force in East Timor; we will never waver in our dedication to the brave Australian men and women who now serve their country. But we believe the tragedy of recent weeks was foreseeable—and, indeed, foreseen—by the Australian government and that it manifestly failed in its duty to do all it could to prevent the horrors that have since unfolded.

talk.start.para: —I must say that I am disappointed in the response of Senator Faulkner. I would have hoped that, for the people we sent away yesterday and their families, we could have had this motion debated in a non-partisan way. I am disappointed, Senator Faulkner, that you have chosen to turn this into a political debate when this motion should be supporting both our men and women who are going overseas and their families.

speech.para: Yesterday Australia heard the roar of our Hercules landing at Dili. The world watched our soldiers in full combat gear walk onto the tarmac to restore security to East Timor in Operation Stabilise. Those strong steps were taken out of friendship and not out of hostility, out of necessity and not out of whim. They are the paces of peace, not of war. They are the echoes of the world's first peacekeepers, who were also Australians. Fifty-two years ago, on 14 September 1947, four Australian military officers stepped off a RAAF plane in the capital of the breakaway republic of Indonesia. Those four were Australia's first, and probably the world's first, United Nations peacekeepers. They too left from Darwin, a Darwin still rebuilding from bomb damage during the war.

Australians were there to keep the peace at the birth of Indonesia's independence. They were military observers attached to the United Nations Good Offices Commission, later the United Nations Commission for Indonesia. Their role was to monitor the cease-fire between the Dutch and the republican Indonesians and ultimately to oversee Indonesia's independence. The political climate was sensitive then, as it is now, and conditions on the ground were not easy. The Australian War Memorial magazine of November 1997 reports that the `Australian aim in getting observers into the field quickly was to present a true picture of that situation to the world. That has been one of the fundamental aims of United Nations peacekeeping ever since.'

The first four Australian peacekeeping observers were followed by a further 60 in Indonesia. The War Memorial magazine states that `Australia had played its part as a staunch defender of the republican position'. We acted to defend the ideal that colonial powers like the Dutch should not be able to ignore the voice of the United Nations. This was a most significant first step in peacekeeping for the world.

This decade opened with the Gulf War. Parliament witnessed some 80 speeches in that debate. Since then we have participated in United Nations operations in Somalia, Rwanda and Cambodia. Operation Stabilise continues our long and proud tradition of contributing to peace as part of some 37 multinational operations. Operation Stabilise was described by the Chief of the Defence Force, Admiral Chris Barrie, as `the most significant military undertaking we have had since World War II. It is also the most significant military undertaking to occur in our part of the world since the war'. Australia expects to make the most substantial contribution, gradually increasing to 4,500 military personnel. This will place a heavy demand on our defence forces in the long term. The aims of the United Nations INTERFET effort are to restore peace and security, protect and support UNAMET and facilitate humanitarian efforts.

I am proud to associate the National Party with this motion. There would be very few country towns around Australia without some link to the forces going to East Timor. Rural Australia has always been so very generous in sending its sons and now daughters to the world's hot spots. These small communities feel ownership and responsibility for their young who are away keeping the peace for people they will only ever see on TV screens. Our troops are part of a multinational force with contributions from Thailand, Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, New Zealand, Brazil, Ireland, Canada, the UK, Italy, France and the US—with financial support from Japan.

Its success will ultimately depend, as noted by Admiral Barrie, on all parties, both in East Timor and Indonesia, joining with the international community to seek a long-term and peaceful solution for the people of East Timor. He also noted that `for the sake of long-term regional stability we must always work hard to deal with Indonesia in a constructive way'.

There are several distinct groups of stakeholders with sometimes competing interests as we make this commitment to restoring peace and security in East Timor. It is no easy matter for governments to strike the right balance, particularly when the timing and outcomes are not predictable. The overarching principle is that we must always act in the national interest.

First and foremost, there is the responsibility of Australia as a UN member to participate in a regional deployment to stabilise and keep the peace. It is important to Australians that we play our part in a carefully considered and measured way. The need for a UN force came about as a result of the escalation of violence and an absence of protection for hundreds of thousands of East Timorese in the wake of their 30 August referendum vote. We heard of horrific and senseless crimes against unarmed civilians and clergy. Dili was burned and hundreds of thousands made homeless, fleeing to the hills for safety or taken to West Timor.

The threat to human life and peaceful existence was such that the international community acted in concert with the Indonesian government to authorise and provide for the INTERFET forces. Australia's involvement in INTERFET comes at a high cost. When a nation makes such an important decision to send so many of our fine service men and women to keep the peace beyond our borders, we do so with both eyes open and with a third eye to the future.

We must not get carried away by the romance of saving a small, vulnerable people. There is no romance in peacekeeping, only challenges at every turn. The first outburst of enthusiasm by the Australian people must be followed through to the end. We must be realistic from the beginning. That is the only way that we will manage as a nation to see this through in a cohesive, consistent and comprehensive way.

We send our sons and daughters away at perhaps their own personal cost—certainly that of their families back home. We must be mindful of their need for support. Important family occasions and anniversaries will pass without key members present. Thousands of Australians may see in the new millennium from barracks in a poor island country in the thick of monsoons, far away from the fireworks and lavish partying of their fellow Australians back home. Auld Lang Syne will carry a poignancy not seen for a generation. I hope that on 31 December this year all Australians will call to mind their brothers and sisters far from home heralding a new peace for a new millennium.

While conditions improve with every deployment, there will still be difficulties. The destruction and absence of infrastructure and facilities will act as constraints on living and working conditions such as water, power, transport, communications and the need to bring in food supplies. The wet season will bring its own difficulties—the steamy conditions and the rains making transportation and work difficult on an already tough terrain.

There will be uncertainty from difficulties identifying troublemakers or rogue militia elements from the rest of the civilian population. If they can be rescued with refugees and flown to Australia, they can certainly blend into local life in East Timor. This adds to on the ground tension. It is the first conflict where some locals are actively against an Australian presence. We have to be careful that our words and actions back home do not inflame an already antagonistic situation faced on the ground in East Timor by our young men and women. There will be reliance on the integrity and honesty of media reporting, coupled with an obligation on government to be open with the Australian people. With thousands of troops away from home, rumours can spread like wildfire and be sensationalised, causing harm and exacerbating fears.

Our troops may face long periods of boredom and uncertainty tempting morale and enthusiasm for the task. We know they are professional and highly trained. In the coming months, they may need to call on all their resources to get the job done. Excitement and adrenaline will fade. That is when they are going to really need our support, and we must be ready and able to give it. We must stand by our men and women keeping the peace in another land.

All those who so loudly called for Australian involvement must answer their own call by committing themselves to the fortune of Australians in East Timor, whether that fortune is for good or bad. We must see this through together. We must steel our resolve to continue what we have begun and prepare for any sorrow and pain which may follow. This will be a shock to Australia—the lucky, carefree, `she'll be right' country. East Timor will not be right for some time yet. We do not even know when.

There is another cost which some have put to one side in the fervour of righteousness, but it cannot be ignored. Australia's relationship with Indonesia is bleeding. This is a relationship that has taken years to develop and has been based on trust. For many years Indonesia has looked to Australia for friendship and assistance, and we have responded generously. Trade between our two countries has grown apace, reaching a high of nearly $3.4 billion in exports in 1997, and imports from Indonesia totalled some $3.5 billion in 1998. Millions of Australian dollars have been invested in a range of enterprises.

Right now, many Indonesians believe Australia is to blame for the East Timor crisis, that we are subsequently acting as invaders who believe ourselves superior to Indonesians. None of these things is true, but there is a tragic gap between our two cultures. This will cost both countries dearly and could take years to rebuild, depending on our actions and words over the next crucial 12 months. Effort must go into rebuilding it for the long-term sake of both our countries. Trade between our countries has built bridges of understanding between our cultures. The business sector will play a key role in restoring this crucial strategic relationship.

There have been student riots, fires and economic and political upheaval but, until now, Australians have not felt personally threatened. There have been bomb threats and warnings to stay away. Australians in Indonesia also need our moral support. We hold their fate in our hands as well. Much will depend on the peacekeeping effort. We must keep in our minds the lack of access by many Indonesians to open media reporting of what has happened in East Timor. Anti-Australian feeling is present in every sector of Indonesian society. We will have to straighten it out, and it will not be easy.

I talked before of using a third eye in preparing ourselves for this momentous undertaking. That third eye is to our future and our region's future. That means keeping a long-term lookout, it means answering questions like: after two months, then what? After six months, then what? After two, three, five or even 10 years, then what? These are the times when we seal the fate of many Australians, East Timorese and Indonesians for future generations in years to come.

There is probably no Australian family who does not know someone going to East Timor or someone connected with the effort in some way. It means looking after our troops in every possible way, ensuring little things like mail and telephone calls home are regular and that pay and conditions do not become the subject of long-term disputes. It means careful strategy over the forthcoming months, preparing for the Indonesian parliament's consideration of the independence vote in East Timor and for the aftermath of that debate.

It means assisting in the repair of the ravages of the past few weeks in terms of economic and social infrastructure. It means healing the trauma of so many East Timorese driven away from their homes in fear and suffering. It means preparing for a long stay away from home on a tiny island the world would rather forget. But we cannot forget. Our bonds with the East Timorese were forged when our country fought for its very survival. Lest we forget. We cannot forget.

The whole world will witness what friendship with Australia means. It means we will make sacrifices of our own family life and our resources to help a friend in trouble. That is what we did in 1947, almost 52 years ago exactly, at the birth of Indonesia's independence. Yesterday, today and tomorrow, we are proud to continue in the footsteps of those first peacekeepers.

talk.start.para: —I am not going to go through the long history that we have with East Timor and, indeed, with Indonesia itself today. I will be leaving that to my colleagues—in particular, to Senator Bourne, when she speaks in a moment. I want to focus on some of the more immediate issues that we are dealing with as we look at what is happening today and what will be happening in the next few months in East Timor.

speech.para: Military intervention is not something that we can take lightly. We would obviously prefer not to have to send young men and women—and some not so young—over to East Timor to face who knows what. Obviously, they will be directly in the line of sight of many of those people who have caused such tremendous trauma over the past weeks, months and years. It is indeed a highly dangerous situation, a situation where destruction and random shooting has been going on and where innumerable atrocities have occurred. But it is precisely because of what is happening that we have to move.

We have all seen on TV programs night after night, particularly on the news, evidence of what is happening: families being forced from their homes, people being shot at random, children being terrorised, houses and buildings being burnt. Dili seems to be but a shell, as we can see now that our troops are there and moving through it. I would say now that Australians are actually relieved; if my mail and my email are anything to go by, Australians are enormously relieved that something is at last being done and that we are on the ground in East Timor ensuring that, at least for the moment, things are peaceful.

Our troops are in East Timor because we are upholding our values—our values of decency, of a free society, of a commitment to peace and security and freedom and, in particular, of at least protecting children. I think for many of us, some of the real horrors have been watching what has been happening to the children. This is a very important moment in Australia's history. Looking around Australia, there is without a doubt absolutely overwhelming support for what our troops are doing. I was privileged to be able to join the Prime Minister and Mr Beazley over the last couple of days to meet with many of those troops. My main reason for going was to reinforce the fact that there was widespread—I would say very close to unanimous—support across this country.

This is an issue with which the Democrats have had significant difficulty in the past. We have opposed the sending in of troops in previous times because we have felt that there were other measures that could have been taken, that there were things that had not been explored, that there were things that had not been done. But in this particular instance we and, as I said, all Australians are supporting those troops in what they are doing.

We know—and certainly I know from speaking with the troops—how well trained they are, how focused they are on what they have to do, how well briefed and prepared they are. Added to that is the fact that at the moment there is virtually no resistance; there have been virtually no incidents since our troops moved in at dawn yesterday. But this does not offer much comfort for their families. It may help a little bit but those partners and particularly the children left behind are having a lot of difficulty with what is happening to their loved ones right now. They obviously are not going to have ready access to them; they are not going to be able to communicate with them readily. So as we remember the troops that are on the ground over there, I ask that we also all remember the families that they have left behind, their friends and, in particular, their children as they come to terms with perhaps not seeing mum or dad again for many, many months. We do not know how long we are going to have to be there.

The troops that I spoke to on Sunday night were well aware of this. They had not been able to tell their families very much, but they certainly were able to communicate to them that this could be a month after month commitment. Of all the people I met with in Townsville—we were able not just to speak with them in a formal sense but to then have dinner with them in the mess—there was only one young man who was very distressed. The reason he was distressed was that he had come in with his intake, he had done his three months basic training, but he was only 17. So while all the rest were about to embark, he had been put on guard duty in Townsville. He had just been through a long process of hunting out any senior officer he could find, telling them what his birth date was and basically indicating that he wanted to be in Darwin the day before that his birthday so that he was ready to embark the minute he turned 18.

We spoke with those troops who—even though I do not think some of them knew it at the time—were ready to go at 4.15 that morning. I still see in the press some indication of the perception that the initial wave went from Darwin; it actually went from Townsville. I do not think any of those troops would have slept that night; they knew it was fairly close and they were very, very well prepared and committed and ready to do what they had to do.

In Darwin, unfortunately, I was not able to spend so much time talking with the troops, but the feeling that one got was the same. There were a few problems yet again; concerns were expressed about the quality of the packs that they were carrying. That is something that I have undertaken to talk to the Minister for Defence about. As someone who does a lot of bushwalking, I cannot imagine how they get 60 kilograms in a pack without a proper frame on their backs as well as everything else that they have to carry. For us that is a minor consideration but for them, particularly those early troops, it is a major issue, as they were planning not to be reinforced at all, even with food, for three or four days. But for all of them embarkation could not come soon enough.

Also in Darwin I was fortunate to be able to look over the Incat catamaran built in Tasmania, which has already taken well over 400 troops in just a few hours, believe it or not. I think it alone can do in 10 hours from Darwin to Dili what many, many Hercules would take to get troops down on the ground. The catamaran allows for all to be seated comfortably, I guess in seats you would describe as being of airline quality. I believe that for one Australian industry this may be the thing that helps them in the years to come with further orders in these types of roles.

As I said before, it could be some time until all of our troops are back home, having established peace. We must remember at the beginning that this is not a peacekeeping mission. They are actually going there to enforce the peace; they are going there to restore law and order. They have been given very different instructions from the instructions that have been given to previous peacekeeping operations, and so far we are very pleased to see that all is going well. They have been given instructions to stop the intimidation, to stop the killings, to disarm the militia, to do what we had hoped the Indonesian government would have ensured or insisted that the military do but which, unfortunately, it seemed to have either no interest in doing or actually was refusing actively to participate in doing.

Hopefully by the time we are debating this matter into this evening we will see the United Nations back in East Timor. I have not heard as yet whether they are there, but they were planning to go back virtually immediately, and the humanitarian organisations will be right behind them. It is absolutely urgent that we get food to those people in the hills outside Dili and to those people who have been displaced further afield in East Timor. In particular, it is urgent that we immediately get support, and particularly supervision initially, into West Timor to see what is happening to those people who have been forced, against their will, across the border. The TV reports have been showing us the horrors and at last there will be an opportunity within the next couple of days to start getting more food to those people than the drops are able to deliver.

Yesterday I met with some of the East Timor refugees. The children seemed to have bounced back reasonably quickly, although obviously many of them are suffering from long-term health problems. For the adults the traumas are overwhelming, particularly for some of the older women. They will need enormous support. I understand that some of them will be moving out of Darwin, possibly to Perth, within the next few days. Some have already gone to Melbourne. So as we look at what we as individuals can do, I think on our list has to be supporting those East Timorese who have been temporarily relocated to Australia. But it is going to be a long time before they can be completely resettled and supported back into any sort of life that we would consider to be comfortable, relaxed and normal.

The question that so many Australians are asking is: how on earth could this have happened? How could there have been no plan B? How could we have seen the United Nations and Australia and other countries so supportive of the ballot process yet this absolute disaster occur so quickly after the announcement was made? There were other plans for other people. There were plans to get our colleagues out—those Australians who were there monitoring what was going on during the ballot—should something have gone wrong at the time of the ballot. So violence was not something that should have been a surprise; violence, unfortunately, should have been something that was expected.

So what went wrong? I am not going to try to answer that completely. Again, some of my colleagues will be looking at this. But I do want to comment that in a very dramatic way what has happened in East Timor has brought the role of the United Nations to the forefront. It has brought to the forefront the actual structure and organisation of the United Nations. The images of the last few weeks have been horrific. As we sat back and watched helplessly many of us were wondering, `Why can't the United Nations step in? Why can't they be involved in doing something?'

We then obviously have to go to the structure of the United Nations and its role. Over the years commentators have pointed to the make-up of the Security Council as being one of the major hurdles. The group was decided upon after the Second World War. Then it was obviously the correct structure comprising the United States, France, the UK, China and Russia—it was the USSR then. When any one of those countries can veto any decision, can basically decide that, no, it is not in their interest or it is not something they believe is in the interests of a country that they work with closely, then it is very difficult for the United Nations to act. But I think we need to start saying that things have changed since World War II.

As we move into the new century, surely it is time for us to look again at how the United Nations is structured and exactly how it operates. I was listening this morning to some comments from Kofi Annan. He was talking about whether or not we can take any notice of borders when genocide and ethnic cleansing is occurring—in other words, whether or not we can look at what is happening in, say, Kosovo, Rwanda or East Timor and say that the perpetrators are actually the people who have to give us permission. That situation is untenable. It simply does not work.

As we look now to the future—and I will spend a couple of minutes doing that—I think one of the keys to a more peaceful future is looking at the structure of the United Nations: who has the power, how it functions and at what stage it can step in when ethnic cleansing is obviously occurring and when the body that needs to give the United Nations permission is actually suspected or known to be the body that is involved in, or at least turning a blind eye to and responsible largely for, what is happening.

Another issue obviously is the financing of the United Nations. It is well known that the United States is years and hundreds of millions if not billions of dollars behind in its financing of the United Nations. So what is the long-term future of this organisation if Australia is one of about seven or eight countries that is up to date with its funding of an organisation so important in keeping world peace? That will be more and more a focus of its operations, but it is not being funded to the point where it can actually do it.

Looking at our role as individuals, the role of ordinary Australians, we cannot just leave it up to bodies like the United Nations or, indeed, government. We cannot leave it up to our troops who are on the ground. All of us need to think about what our personal commitment is and to encourage Australians to put their hands in their own pockets now, whether it is to support Amnesty or Oxfam or the Red Cross or church organisations who are going to be spending millions upon millions of dollars for year after year, not just to get people fed and housed but to get the infrastructure in East Timor back up to scratch. Obviously, as it moves towards independence, the possibility of Indonesia doing much of this is very limited. So I hope anyone who can possibly be encouraged to spare those few dollars over the coming months and years will do so.

I want to close by stressing again our complete commitment to and support for those men and women who are now in East Timor and the many who will no doubt be needed over there in the coming months. But we must learn the lessons from East Timor as well as from Kosovo and all of those other places. We must put in place better procedures for the future. For our ongoing relations with Indonesia, as Senator Boswell highlighted, this is again an issue that is going to come up time and time again in the months and years ahead. How do we re-establish a relationship with Indonesia? I think the basic answer is to concentrate on those people in Indonesia who have, like the people of East Timor, also voted for a government that they see as being democratic and concerned about people, and to give every encouragement possible so that the result of the Indonesian election is upheld in that country, as well as the result of the East Timorese election being upheld in East Timor.

We have to do everything possible as a nation to isolate the militia and the military from the political decision making processes in Indonesia by working through every source that we can, whether it is through business and industry groups who want to invest there or whether it is through bodies who are funding Indonesia and helping it through its time of crisis economically. We must do everything we can to see that democracy actually does get a foothold in that country. Perhaps one of the best ways to communicate all of this to the average person in Indonesia is to get the transmitter on the Cox Peninsula open again so that we can transmit straight into Indonesia so that the ordinary people in Indonesia know that our beef is not with them, our problem is not them; our problem is the militia and the military and what they have done to East Timor since they took over.

talk.start.para: —This morning as I was driving my wife to the airport I took a wrong turn and ended up in the sports fields of the RMC at Duntroon. We had a little bit of time, so we went through Duntroon and past the chapel. We thought we would go in and say a prayer for the troops. Little did Marian know, when she launched 045, the catamaran which is now the Jervis Bay , only a short time ago, that it would be taking Australian troops overseas into a very difficult situation.

speech.para: In the silence of the Military College chapel, we remembered the men and women of the armed forces. We prayed that God would protect each one of them, that they would perform their tasks in a professional manner without bitterness or hatred, that they would complete their mission as peacemakers and peace restorers and that they would be able to secure the whole of the area of East Timor without suffering casualties. We prayed that the families would feel support and have support while their loved ones are away on this very important peace mission task, that they would not succumb to apprehension and that they would be able to trust and be supported by neighbours and the whole of Australia.

We remembered the other members of the United Nations force, because these countries, our neighbours, realise the importance of peace and prosperity in this whole area. We prayed that the TNI would hand over control in an orderly and prompt fashion. Our hopes went out to the East Timorese who themselves have suffered enormously—untold dead, hundreds of thousands displaced, churches, houses, homes and buildings destroyed and burnt. We prayed that the nation would be rebuilt again.

As I stand here I welcome the statements I have heard from Indonesian members of parliament and others supporting the decision—or at least acknowledging the decision—which was made in the referendum and indicating support when parliament resumes for the proposition that separation take place. Now is the time for reconciliation, and I speak directly to the key policy makers of Indonesia. I feel that now is the time, even in the midst of this disturbance, to start to reconcile and assist and, as an indication of goodwill, to open up the passages for humanitarian assistance for those persons who have left East Timor and are in West Timor.

I make the point that, yes, it is a difficult decision to make that part of what you have believed to be your own country is to now be independent. However, I am sure that many Indonesian people and many of the Indonesian leaders now realise that this is inevitable. I was concerned, as others were concerned, about the unthinking burning of Indonesian flags in Australia and the burning of Australian flags in Indonesia. I think those people should realise that we were the first country in the world to recognise Indonesia's independence from Dutch colonialism.

There is a very strong relationship between the peoples of Indonesia and Australia. I speak personally. I am honoured to be the father-in-law of a young Javanese lady and the grandfather of four Indonesian-Australian children. There has been a great deal of effort put in by many in Indonesia and many in Australia to cement those ties and relationships. That is important. Many of my friends in Indonesia were appalled by the actions of the militia in East Timor, were appalled by the actions of elements of the Indonesian armed forces in East Timor and were concerned that this might affect the development of democracy in Indonesia itself. They know as well as I do that a mature democracy is one in which the armed forces of that country are under the control of the elected civil power and the security forces, the police, go about their business—which is to bring criminals to justice and to ensure that persons are able to go about their undertakings, their lives and their businesses lawfully.

Through you, Madam Acting Deputy President, I say to the Indonesian leaders in various areas that I have strongly supported the study of bahasa Indonesia in Australia and efforts by Australians to understand the cultures of the Indonesian people. I was terribly disappointed when I heard some commentator in Indonesia saying that Austral ians thought of the Indonesians only as small, chocolate-coloured people, inhabitants of a country near our shores. None of that is going to do any good.

I admire the work that is done by a number of groups within Australia to advance understanding between Indonesia and Australia, including: the Australia-Indonesia Youth Exchange Program; the regular senior editors meetings between Australian and Indonesian editors; support for the Australian Studies Centre at the University of Indonesia; the Australia-Indonesia Institute's fellowship for eminent Indonesians to visit Australia; the Australian lecture series in Indonesia; scholarships for teachers, students and journalists to study the Indonesian language and culture in country; and a broad range of performing and visual arts. The Australia-Indonesia Institute list goes on.

I know that at this point in time in three states and in the Northern Territory the most significant language other than the English language taught in government schools is Indonesian. More people are studying bahasa Indonesia in government schools in those three states—Victoria, Tasmania and Western Australia—and in the Northern Territory than are studying other languages other than English.

I hope that what has happened can be put behind us. Indonesia-Australia relations should be protected and enhanced. We can do this by cooperatively looking at how best we can now restore peace, build prosperity in East Timor and continue the efforts we have made over the last 50 years to improve that relationship in the interest of both our nations—we are nearest neighbours—and in the interest of the peace and prosperity of the whole area.

A number of other things can be said, but I do not believe that this is the occasion to say them. I have concerns about a number of matters. No doubt on the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade and other such forums there will be opportunities to have these matters considered. For example, why wasn't the information that was provided by DIO in March acted upon? There are questions relating to the timing of the referendum and the security arrangements therefor.

Indeed, I think this whole issue has called into question our relationship with the United States.
