I am not reflecting on the United States of America, but it has its own interests, and they may not, and very often do not, coincide with ours. We have to consider all those matters. However, I do not think this debate is the occasion for internal recriminations. I put myself in the boots of the troops. How would they feel if this particular debate degenerated into mere bickering?

Other matters have been raised quite legitimately. For example, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, raised a very important question just recently which needs to be looked at if we are going to sustain this country and develop it into a viable country in this region. But I appeal to the Senate to put those matters aside for another date; to note the overwhelming choice for independence exercised by the East Timorese; to welcome the UN Security Council resolution and the multinational peacekeeping, peacemaking and security force in East Timor; and to express our full support for—and I support this wholeheartedly—and our confidence in the Australians serving with the multinational force.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Australian Greens I also support the motion on East Timor put forward by the Prime Minister. I particularly want to reiterate the unanimous feeling of the Australian Greens in the national meeting on the weekend which, amongst other things, wished our Australian Defence Force personnel and all members of the international peacekeeping force safety and success in the challenging and dangerous times ahead and a speedy return home. The thoughts of the Australian people will be with the thousands of Australians in the defence forces as well as in the humanitarian and assistance groups going to East Timor—and, hopefully, to West Timor as well—in the months ahead as we do what we can to bring a salve to the horrific wound that the people of that island have suffered in recent times and are continuing to suffer as we speak here today.

speech.para: There will be a need for this parliament to continue to press the government in ensuring that the defence forces in East Timor are given every assistance necessary for them to carry out their job as part of the international force. I want to reiterate what Senator Lees had to say in calling for the re-establishment of broadcasts of Radio Australia through the Cox Peninsula transmitter. This transmitter should never have been closed, but never has there been a more prudent time for the government to reverse that wrong decision and to ensure that the Radio Australia broadcasts are going not only to Australians in East Timor but also to the East Timorese people—and to the Indonesian people—wherever they might be and whatever their view might be on these events.

It is also essential that our nation give support to all the leaders of the East Timorese people in these times, not least to Xanana Gusmao, who has shown extraordinary statespersonship in his time in detention in Indonesia and in recent days where, in the face of the cruelty that has been dealt to his people, he still had the humanity to be calling for talks with the militia—the very perpetrators of the bloodshed in East Timor. There will be millions of people around the world wishing Xanana Gusmao and the other leaders of the East Timorese people all strength and assistance as they move towards the establishment of a democratic set-up in East Timor and as that country itself regains its freedom and independence.

It is also essential that we extend rapid humanitarian aid to the whole of the island of Timor, East and West. This is a role in which every Australian can take a place. It is important for us to dig deep into our pockets and to give the maximum in aid to help the humanitarian groups as they go for the first time to Timor to help the hundreds of thousands of people in extraordinarily distressing situations there and then in the long years ahead as the country, which is now burning, is rebuilt. It is also extremely important—and no Australian should overlook this—that we strengthen our bonds with Indonesia's democrats, those people in Indonesia who are hurting because of the events which have occurred at the hands of brigands and also with the assistance of at least sections of the Indonesian armed forces, not just in recent times but going right back to the invasion of East Timor in 1975. At the moment, these people are themselves inevitably showing courage and speaking out in Indonesia for the international peacekeeping force going to East Timor. They include trade unionists, journalists, students, lawyers, MPs and mosque and church leaders in Indonesia. We should salute their courage and ensure that their voice not only is heard in Indonesia but also is well known to the Australian people. It is through their courage that we will see the rapid evolution of not just a democratic East Timor but also a democratic Indonesia as our neighbours to the near north.

I also want to reiterate the call of those who have already mentioned the need for a war crimes tribunal. This is not simply—or even principally—a matter of vengeance. Where people create murder and mayhem against innocent people because they have a different point of view, it is extraordinarily important that it be known to them that retribution is coming down the line. To not do so is to encourage this to happen somewhere else—some place, some time in the future. I wrote to the President of the Security Council back on 10 September to call for a war crimes tribunal. I am extraordinarily supportive of those, including Mary Robinson, who are now moving to establish such a war crimes tribunal.
In the letter which I wrote to Mr Jaap Ramaker, the President of the United Nations Security Council, on 10 September, I said:
The Tribunal should investigate the following acts:
. Genocide;
. Crimes against humanity;
. Grave breaches of the 1949 Geneva Conventions;
. Violations of the laws or customs of war.
These are the basic terms of the tribunals established to investigate war crimes in Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia. I went on to say:

It would appear from literally thousands of news reports from East Timor that, at the very least, the following people should be investigated: Indonesian Defence Minister General Wiranto; Eurico Guterras of the Aitarak militia; and Manuel Sousa of the Besi Merah Putih militia.

There will be many other names on that list, but let us not in the future fall back to an acquiescence—to use a word used earlier in this debate—which removes the names of those people who were involved in the process of deciding and deliberating on and carrying out murder, rape and destruction in Timor from the list of people who should be brought before a war crimes tribunal, however long it takes, however harrowing the process is and however testing of diplomacy it is.

As an immediate measure, we should be using international pressure—as the United States used—to help establish the peacekeeping force to secure the lives and the livelihoods of people trapped on the western side of East Timor's border. There are thousands of people there in extraordinarily distressing circumstances, as you know, Madam Acting Deputy President. It is distressing beyond words to hear evidence that even now the militia, apparently in cahoots with the military, is removing people from those camps, including supposed leaders of the East Timorese independence movement. This is leading to the situation where there is almost an absence of men, particularly young men, in those refugee camps containing tens of thousands of people.

It is also very important that we insist that the Indonesian forces secure the border so that the militia, with whom they intermesh, are not able to cross freely from West Timor into East Timor in the coming months. In particular, it is important we recognise that from now on it is going to be Australian and international personnel who are at risk, as well as the East Timorese civilians, as a result of that free movement, if it is permitted, of people who have murder and destruction as their aim.

I would also reiterate the issue I brought up in question time yesterday with the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. It is important for the government to be scrupulous in establishing that absolutely no aid which in any way can be of assistance to the military or the militia in Indonesia now or in the future is going from this country to that country. I condemn here and now the Blair government's decision to allow three more war planes to be sold to Indonesia because of contractual obligations. What about the contractual obligations of the Indonesian militia to ensure peace in East Timor? The Blair government is to be condemned for allowing this continuing trade in weapons at a time when international forces are being put at risk in East Timor and at a time when hundreds if not thousands or tens of thousands of East Timorese still have their lives in the hands of the people with whom Britain is trading in these weapons.

We must also insist that, in diplomacy, we do not allow ourselves to mix up the issues of economic advantage and democratic and civil rights. This is a big test for our country and for all Western democracies. But let us hope that, if nothing else comes from these awful times in East Timor, there is a keen, renewed and forever strengthened recognition that democracies must not trade human rights with dictatorships and that trading in arms—let alone trading for economic advantage in all goods—can never be an excuse for acquiescing to the removal of rights of other world citizens.

I have seen some newspapers say that we must contain the resolution of the East Timor troubles, that this must not be allowed to flow on to incite freedom-loving people in West Papua, Aceh or Kalimantan in Indonesia—let alone Tibet or East Turkestan in China and dominated by China—or to places like West Sahara, where there is to be a United Nations referendum on self-determination for those people who were invaded by Morocco a decade or two ago. This is absolutely wrong-headed thinking. This is not what a fair go is about. This is not what democracy and freedom that we value in this country is about, and it cannot be traded.

The experience of the last 25 years should bring home to future Australian leaders that, if you do trade these values for better relations with dictatorships, history will come to judge you for it. The acquiescence to the military occupation of East Timor, which the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate mentioned earlier as being a necessary part of our relationship with Indonesia, was neither needed nor ethical. It cannot be excused in retrospect, and it will not be excused into the future.

I put it to those who say that we must acquiesce to the military domination of countries like West Papua, Tibet or even Burma—where internally military authorities have taken away the democratic aspirations of the people and overrun the democratic vote of their own people—that we cannot and must not acquiesce to that. Acquiescence in these matters is a policy which has failed and which has inevitably led in part, or in the main, to the disaster for the East Timorese people which has troubled our country so greatly.

I salute the strength of the Australian people in driving the political move and strengthening the political spine of this nation, which is leading at last to peacekeeping forces going into East Timor to secure—despite the awful bloodshed—the inevitable outcome of independence and freedom for the East Timorese people who are near neighbours of ours. I have been at the rallies in recent weeks in Melbourne, Sydney and Hobart where not thousands but tens of thousands of people have turned out and expressed their heartfelt grievance against the events to our north and their support, caring and love for the East Timorese people. I do not need to reiterate the details of the awful calamity for individuals in East Timor which have been voiced and remembered at these enormous gatherings.

I also want to salute the union movement in this country, which acted so rapidly to invoke sanctions on Indonesia and then lifted them when the time was right. It used that as leverage for a humanitarian and democratic purpose beyond its own immediate bailiwick. This was an act of high ethical courage and determination by people who did not need to get involved in that way, but it did establish also a strengthening bond with people in Indonesia who have stood up for the rights of democracy in that country.

It is going to be very important that in the years ahead—as I said at the beginning of this speech—we remember the need to strengthen the power of those in Indonesia itself who believe in democracy, a free press, freedom of worship and the freedom of self-determination and have had the courage to voice those beliefs on behalf of the people of East Timor through these very difficult times when it is so easy for such voices to go quiet. I salute those people in Indonesia. They are the true democrats; they are true world citizens.

At the end of this century of horrific events and bloodshed, and dictatorships believing that the lives of people they disagree with are expendable in terms of their own accretion of power or experimentation, the events in East Timor will be part of a watershed leading towards a safer, more secure, democratic and free world as we move into the next century. We are going to face harrowing events in the months and years ahead. These are going to be all the more personal for us because so many thousands of Australians are now directly involved. I join those in the parliament who wish them a safe return to our shores after the establishment of the belated rights of the East Timorese people to their own freedom, independence and peace.
Debate (on motion by Senator Ian Campbell) adjourned.

subdebateinfo.title: Days and Hours of Meeting and Routine of Business

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: That on Tuesday, 21 September 1999, the routine of business be varied to provide that the question for the adjournment of the Senate shall not be proposed till after the conclusion of consideration of the motion on East Timor, or a motion for the adjournment is moved by a minister.

I might just state that it is clear from the speakers list that the current debate before the chamber on Australia's involvement in East Timor would not be concluded by 10 or 11 o'clock tonight if senators take up an average amount of time. The Senate is due to adjourn somewhere after 6.50 this evening. We have had discussions with senators around the chamber to ensure that the debate can continue into this evening. I have sent a letter around. Senator Brown would not have re ceived his as yet, but there have been discussions with Senator Brown.

The Senate will sit tonight but it will be on the basis that there be no divisions and no quorums. It would mean that senators who have other engagements—bearing in mind the Senate would not normally sit tonight, that is understandable—will not need to be in the chamber. I understand that the motion will be put and concluded tonight. It will be able to be voted on and there should not need to be a division. It should be carried on the voices. I believe that is everyone's understanding. That is the government's intention: no divisions and no quorums after 6.50 this evening, to allow any senator who wishes to speak on this debate to do so, and for the debate to be concluded tonight.

talk.start.para: —The opposition supports the motion as moved by the Manager of Government Business on the basis he has outlined—that is, no quorums and no divisions after 6.50 tonight. The calculation of time that he has made for the consideration of what is obviously an extremely important matter for the entire Australian community is that at about 2.30 tomorrow morning we may conclude this matter, if everyone takes their 20 minutes and if there are no further senators who wish to add their names to the speakers list.

speech.para: It is obviously a matter that will take considerable time and it is our view that, on a no quorums, no divisions basis, this matter should be put tonight. It is our understanding that that is the government's intention and there will not be a division on the matter itself at the conclusion of this debate. On that basis, we are happy to support the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the government's motion welcoming United Nations Security Resolution 1264 and the peacekeeping party into East Timor. I sincerely hope that the peacekeeping force will be that, and that it will be a temporary situation leading to the just return of control of their land to the sovereign people of East Timor. I also wish to endorse the sentiments passed today in support of our Australian troops, and very clearly remind this nation of their families, their children, their mothers and their fathers whom they have left behind. I believe it is very important that we support Senator Harradine's sentiments in that we, as a nation, pray not only for that force and their families but also for the East Timorese people. We also pray that righteous people will be uplifted in Indonesia so that the real intention of the Indonesian people is heard around the world.

speech.para: Senator Faulkner called on the Indonesian parliament to pass legislation to allow recognition of the right of the East Timorese people to freedom and self-government. I believe, in actuality, that Senator Lees was far closer to the mark when she made the comment, `Why are we asking the perpetrators of this violence to give their permission so that the people on whom they are perpetrating that violence can have their freedom?' I believe that Senator Lees is correct in that it is an anathema that we are doing that. Senator Alston commended not only the countries of the world which have contributed to the peace force by way of members but the other countries which have pledged funds to support the East Timorese people. I would like to call upon the Australian government to reconsider the aid of approximately $120 million that it has appropriated for the Indonesian government—$8 million of which I believe was expressly for military purposes. I call upon the government to reconsider that allocation and to seriously consider transferring those funds ultimately to the people of East Timor. Senator Brown also went on to say that we should not mix up our responsibilities between economic and civil rights. I believe he has explicitly hit the nail in relation to the East Timor issue.

I would like to take a little time to relate to the senators in the chamber and those people around Australia who are listening to this what I believe equates to a similarity with the emperor who paraded with no clothes. The advisers to the emperor were sufficiently articulate with words to convince the emperor he had the finest set of clothes when, in reality, the people could clearly see that he had none. You might ask: what does that mean in relation to this motion? I believe it largely depicts sentiments being expressed not only in Indonesia but also in Australia. I will share with the chamber some words, and I would like you to focus on them. The words are:

Something happened here that moved me very deeply. It was so far outside our experience as Australians that we'll find it very difficult to convey to you, but we'll try. Sitting on woven mats, under a thatched roof, in a hut with no walls, we were the target of a barrage of questioning from men who knew that they may die tomorrow and cannot understand why the rest of the world does not care.

Does that sound like a report from last Saturday night's news? It does. It has a familiar ring. But it is actually part of the last on-camera report by Greg Shackleton. It was filed on 15 October 1975. The questions being relayed to the government in that statement are no different from those questions we ask today. East Timor asks why the rest of the world does not care. Finally, 24 years later, we are committing Australian sons and daughters to a peacekeeping mission. All that foreign aid has done is reinforce behaviours that in many instances are repugnant to the world.

When five journalists were murdered in Balibo in 1975 the Australian government barely flinched. Then, at a funeral of a young boy, Sebastiano Gomes, the Indonesian armed forces went on a killing spree, murdering between 100 and 500 innocent people. The honourable member for Holt declared:
The massacre is not a matter of deliberate or calculated Indonesian government policy.
The United Nations begged to differ, describing the incident as:
A well planned military operation designed to deal with public expressions of political dissent.

Throughout all of this, Australian governments kept the money flowing into Indonesia. Two years ago Pauline Hanson knew that this money would buy neither favours nor better behaviour from a basically corrupt government. She raised these issues during her time in the House of Representatives. I wonder whether regional neighbourliness and friendship is the real issue behind the funding that we pay to Indonesia. In November 1997 Pauline asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs:

Why is it in the national interest for Australia to provide foreign aid to countries which have promoted military officers responsible for the murder of Australian citizens? It is suspected that Indonesian military—
personnel—
killed Australian journalists in East Timor . . .

Australians feel morally obliged to assist people in the world as best we can. Unfortunately, the minister forgets we should also be morally bound to look after our own. We have now sent our defence force into East Timor, a force which has had its funds and, subsequently, training opportunities limited by a government determined to give Australian taxpayers' money to overseas countries to buy regional mateship. Yes, I suggest all we have tried to do is buy regional mateship.

Let us not overlook the opposition's track record in their support of our Timorese friends. In 1991 an Australian government representative told the United Nations that Australia defends self-determination as a fundamental right of people everywhere. Yet, subsequently, the Hon. Gareth Evans, as Minister for Foreign Affairs, said:

We cannot lend ourselves to an exercise which is premised on non-acceptance of the sovereign incorporation of East Timor into the Republic of Indonesia. East Timor is just a country, an area that was never a sovereign state . . . It was an abandoned colony.

A colony that on 7 December 1975 was invaded not just by the sea but also by air. The East Timorese people were slaughtered, as we know they are being slaughtered today. The Australian public condemned these atrocities, but the government never committed itself to any action that could jeopardise the `special relationship' with Indonesia. For the last 25 years each party in this chamber has talked about moral and humanitarian obligations. They have given away billions of dollars of hard-earned Australian taxpayers' dollars in an attempt to buy the favour of our regional mates. I suggest that the special relationship with the Indonesian government was more important to our leaders than the rights of the Indonesian people.

By the time one-third of the East Timorese had died as a direct result of the invasion, Australian politicians had signed a treaty with Indonesia on the Timor Gap, which had oil and gas deposits worth billions of dollars. Unfortunately, the only obligation our government upheld was the economic rights of the invaders. Short of a jab in the nose, I often wonder how much has to be done to alert the major political parties as to what is happening within their electorates, let alone in another country.

Pauline Hanson's One Nation has certainly turned some—yes, I admit only some—of the thinking of the major parties around, to consider the will of the people. The government had been given advice about the possibility of violence following the Timor independence vote. Yet with great skill, finely honed through previous years in power, that advice was ignored. Really, the Prime Minister and the honourable Minister for Foreign Affairs know best what should happen in Timor. Never mind that respected East Timorese leaders asked that a cooling-off period of five years be adopted prior to the referendum, due to the military strength that was deployed in East Timor. Father Hilario, senior religious East Timor leader, said last October:
I think my days are numbered.
A senior Indonesian army official told the Sunday program:
If the pro-independents do win . . . all will be destroyed.

To allow a government with a brutal track record of violence to be in charge of security after the Timor referendum was negligent and a denial of reality. These very same people who told us back in 1998 that they were confident that they could manage any situation that arose now have blood on their hands. The great tragedy is that this blood could include that of some of our peacekeeping force members, who will have to try to broker a peace between hostile groups who are threatening to kill an Australian a day.

We have always argued that we need to build up our defence forces spending, personnel and equipment. This must be coupled with a government that can spend these funds wisely with a minimum of waste. The tragedy of East Timor is a stern warning to the other rebellious provinces of Indonesia, namely Aceh and Irian Jaya. The Ambonese are mainly Melanesian, of both Islamic and Christian faith. The province of Aceh is also populated by people of Melanesian origin and contains valuable natural resources, as does Irian Jaya. While losing East Timor will not hurt the Indonesian economy greatly, the loss of those other areas would have a definite economic consequence, and I cannot see the Indonesian government allowing this to happen under any circumstances.

I believe that the violence, the killing, and the burning of East Timor is a specific process set about by the Indonesian people to send a very clear warning to the other provinces, such that if they in any way move towards voting for independence they know exactly what is going to happen to them. I believe that the Australian government should repeal the Timor Gap treaty with Indonesia and renegotiate the agreement with the new East Timorese people.

The East Timorese crisis has made us realise that we do not have a special relationship with the Indonesian government and never did have. Let us have an end to these special relationships with other countries. No one likes a groveller, not the Indonesians and certainly not the Australian people. In conclusion, Pauline Hanson's One Nation wants to thank from our heart the wonderful members of our Army, Air Force and Navy for defending the rights of the East Timorese people.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I stand to support the motion on East Timor moved by Senator Alston. Can I first say, however, that I am so disappointed by the speech of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate. At a time when unequivocal support from the whole nation is needed, to have what was, in my eyes, political opportunism in that speech was a terrible shame. I think that a political speech does Labor no credit at all, especially when many of us remember the 13 years when the Hawke and Keating governments made no effort at all to achieve a ballot in East Timor.

speech.para: I also note that the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, is rewriting history as fast as he can. He claims that Labor said at an early stage that there needed to be peacekeepers in place in order to have a vote. Yet in fact, on many occasions from February to April, he spoke against the deployment of Australian troops and for the control of the situation by the Indonesian military. Does he think that the record is not available to others?

He has claimed that the Prime Minister did not raise the question of East Timor on his visit to the United States in July, and yet that is quite untrue. On 12 July the Prime Minister spoke to our media in the United States about discussions with President Clinton which went on at great length over lunch. So much for Mr Beazley rewriting history.

I have also been appalled this afternoon to hear the frantic contribution by Mr Beazley in the House of Representatives. Does he think we forget that he was defence minister at a time when more and more help was being given to the Indonesian military and yet no attempt was being made by him as defence minister or by his government to draw on that close relationship to ensure a plebiscite in East Timor?

It was his government that was so close to the Suharto government that senior military officers were invited to a guided tour of some of our defence establishments. Surely Mr Beazley might have had the ticker to convince the Indonesian military of the need to support an East Timorese plebiscite. So political opportunism and frantic shouting in the chamber today seem to me to be no solution to hiding Labor's record while in government.

I now turn to some of the key issues, as I see them, in relation to East Timor. Our country has a compelling strategic interest in promoting peace and security in East Timor as it moves to independence. We also respect Indonesia's territorial integrity. We do not want to see a destabilising break-up of the archipelago. I recognise full well the focus in that nation, since the time of its independence, in trying to keep together a very diverse nation of many islands in the archipelago. I can understand that they have concerns about the future of their nation and that they want to avoid a destabilising break-up. We respect their territorial integrity. We cannot be secure ourselves in a region in turmoil.

Our leadership of INTERFET is not only about being a good international citizen; it is just as importantly about our very strong interest in maintaining an effective relationship with Indonesia. Indonesia is a close and important regional neighbour. We have many shared security interests. The security of Australia can best be assured by having a close working relationship with our nearest neighbour. So the Australian government's intention is for the multifunctional force to carry out the mandate and hand over transitional authority to the United Nations as soon as is practicable.

We must never forget—and there are no two ways about this; it is just like you cannot choose your family and usually you cannot choose your neighbours—that in this case Indonesia is our neighbour. That is a fact of life. They will be our neighbour forever. Their size and their population mean they will have a shared role in the Asia-Pacific region in future and it is best if we can restore friendly relationships between our two countries. It is best for all of us.

In that context we must acknowledge and recognise that the Indonesian government and, in particular, President Habibie have done the right thing by allowing the referendum in East Timor and by agreeing to the peacekeeping force. We were especially encouraged by the reporting by the commander of INTERFET, Major-General Cosgrove, of the first-class cooperation he received from Indonesian military authorities during his initial visit to Dili on 19 September.

I am particularly pleased to have seen the number of countries from Asia that have been prepared to contribute forces. The history of ASEAN has been that most nations have been very unwilling to ever publicly criticise another member of ASEAN, let alone take part in a peacekeeping force in one of the nations of the region. So it is very significant that it is not only Australia as a neighbour of Indonesia that is taking part in this force but also Thailand, the Philippines, Singapore and Malaysia. I am also very pleased to see the Gurkhas there—they are doughty military men. I think they will prove very effective in the peace enforcement role.

The value of our military alliance with the United States has been reconfirmed. That was a key ingredient in helping us to bring INTERFET together so quickly. It is an issue that the opposition has used as a political hammer perhaps, but in ignorance or wilful disregard of the facts. Portugal also has played an essential diplomatic role in the process. Its contribution to the UN Trust Fund, together with that of Japan's financial support, is critical to ensuring the participation of a number of states who are unable to manage the cost of deploying their forces. The range of countries that have been prepared to contribute is wonderful, I think.

Progress towards reconciliation will depend on the efforts of the UN but, of course, ultimately on the people of East Timor themselves. The process is going to be slow and painful and it may well take many years. So we urge the UN to start that work of reconciliation in the province immediately. INTERFET's role in that process will be to prevent the recurrence of the violence on the scale we saw over the last two weeks, to protect and support UNAMET and any other UN entities in their work of building political reconciliation and to facilitate the delivery of the humanitarian aid by protecting the agencies involved.

While I pay tribute to the scale and the capabilities of the forces that have contributed to INTERFET from all over the world, we must recognise the fact that they are not sufficient to control security throughout the territory. That would hardly be possible with a force many times the size of INTERFET. We will do all we can in the time ahead of us to provide the most secure environment we can for the process of political reconciliation and humanitarian relief to go forward.

I would like to speak briefly about Australia's defence preparation. Although no country anticipated the extent of the destruction after the referendum, Australia did make preparations. We decided in June to increase the training and operational readiness of a brigade size force in Darwin. We were enabled to do that because of the fact that we had protected the defence budget since we came into government. We had had a review of the expenditure within the department and reallocated moneys which were not going to the sharp end but now can. So the ability for us to have increased training and operational readiness for another brigade size force in Darwin has meant that these people were ready to go.

We put the catamaran HMAS Jervis Bay into service. As a proud Tasmanian I am delighted that it is a Tasmanian vessel that is carrying our troops. I think it was Senator Lees who mentioned that maybe this will be an even greater support for an emerging industry in our state, because it is a sad fact that other countries are not very interested in buying military hardware from a nation unless they can point to the fact that it is already in use in the nation producing the item. This opportunity for the Incat vessel which is on lease for two years will, I am sure, make a significant impact in the region.

I would think it is true to say that the Australian Defence Force has not been at such a high point of military readiness since the end of the Vietnam War. It is a tribute to the professionalism of our forces that they have made themselves ready for this task so quickly. The sorts of problems they will be facing in East Timor are the sorts of problems for which the Australian Defence Force—certainly the Army—has trained for many decades. They are leaders in the field around the world. I would say that the Australians, the New Zealanders and the Brits as well have some great skills which are going to be called upon—we hope not too much—in this expedition.

Australia's commitment includes an initial deployment of land forces—a brigade group with two infantry battalions with associated support elements including engineers and reconnaissance vehicles, logistic support elements, and rotary wing support including Black Hawks and Kiowas. Air elements include C-130s, Caribous and B707s to provide transport of personnel and cargo and to maintain supplies for the mission. Naval components include HMAS Anzac, HMAS Adelaide, HMAS Darwin, HMAS Tobruk, HMAS Jervis Bay, HMAS Success and two heavy landing craft.

I now turn finally to the support of families of ADF personnel deployed to East Timor. The measures that have been announced are quite significant, important and practical. A National Welfare Coordination Centre has been established to provide a 24-hour point of contact for families and the next of kin of personnel deployed. The role of the centre is to provide a central coordination point for all welfare and family support assets and to provide information on this to members of the deployed forces and their families.

The tasks of the centre will be to provide the Defence Community Organisation with details of the families of deployed soldiers so they can establish contact and assess the family's needs and to develop family support plans in conjunction with regional Defence Community Organisation offices. This may include assistance in areas such as home maintenance. The centres will supplement the usual support provided to families by the Defence Community Organisation service delivery offices and FIND, the Family Information Network for Defence.

The Defence Community Organisation has been participating in unit organised predeployment briefings for members and their families. Families will be given contact details for all regional Defence Community Organisation service delivery teams for support in such matters as how to contact the member, information on accessing local support groups, family crisis support, counselling, crisis intervention counselling support, suitable local referrals for specific problems and access to emergency financial assistance in periods of financial crisis or illness.

The Defence Community Organisation will also sponsor social gatherings that promote networking and reinforce the valuable role that spouses play. The Family Information Network for Defence is continuing to provide a central information resource. The Defence Community Organisation web site will contain an East Timor information page. The Defence Community Organisation site also offers email links. I understand that already there have been 270 calls to the National Welfare Coordination Centre and 140 were made to the FIND line on the first day, yesterday. That certainly means that some people know where to find help.

Although those things are very important, the announcement of those items themselves will not be enough to guarantee the support that is needed, the support that is so vital to the morale of the troops. I do not know whether the Australian people understand or not, but the support that is given to the families back home has a critical impact on how troops serving overseas can stick at the job, which is often so difficult. I would urge the Australian people to understand how vital their continuing support will be to our men and women. That is the prime need: to know that your country honours your service or the service of your loved one.

It is not good enough in a debate in the parliament today for the Labor Party to endorse the motion before the parliament and to turn the occasion into an opportunity for political attack. It is not good enough for Labor to say that they support the troops and that the troops need the nation's support and then talk about how the men who came back from Vietnam needed that support. Do they think that the Army has forgotten who rejected our men coming back from Vietnam? Labor led a concerted attack on our soldiers and their role as well as delivering great hurt and resentment to their families who were left here to worry and to put up with the cruel abuse. I was one of those wives who was left behind who had to put up with the cruelty and the unfair treatment that was stirred up by the ALP against the men and their families, not against the government. Whatever it is they are trying to do, Labor cannot rewrite history now. Any Vietnam veteran in Australia will tell you the blame is firmly on Labor's doorstep. So the contribution of Labor today fills me with fear that their political opportunism will be the determinant of how long they `support' our troops.

The Department of Defence and the ADF also need to ensure that the support mechanisms actually work, work well and continue to work. Some families, for example, are not near defence bases, and they will tend to feel isolated. They need special care and attention. Some will proudly refuse help but still need it. Many will be living thousands of miles from their extended families and need that bit of extra support. The Australian today reported on Mr and Mrs Geall of Biloela in Queensland, whose lovely daughter Jaclyn has left for East Timor. Her family are proud but naturally worried. They live a long way away from the usual Defence networks. My experience as the wife of an infantryman serving in Vietnam in 1967-68 was that the announcement of family support from Defence at the beginning of the tour of 2RAR sounded fine. The only trouble was that the actual effectiveness was pretty short lived. Our men and women may be away for some time—we do not yet know for how long—and I know that Ministers Moore and Scott will be paying particular attention to this support for the families. I urge all parliamentarians to keep an eye out for the support that they need.

As the Minister for Family and Community Services, I too will take a close interest in the needs of those families who are supporting our peacekeepers. Let us start with something very basic and practical but terribly important: let us ensure that their mail is received regularly, something that has not always been the case in previous peacekeeping efforts. I am proud of our well-trained and professional troops and their leaders. I know they will do well, and I am glad that they are taking on this task with the total support of their fellow countrymen. Long may that support continue, and may they do their jobs and return home safely.

talk.start.para: —On 30 August, East Timor had a population of 825,000 people: 437,000 had enrolled to vote in the ballot being held that day under the watchful eyes of United Nations supervisors and international observers. Overwhelmingly, those eligible to vote did so. It was a fair ballot. Most attended early in the day. Correspondents reported long queues at polling stations all over the country.

speech.para: Initially sombre and determined, the mood gave way to expressions of joy and pleasure. People who had never known democracy were happy and proud at the sense of freedom and dignity the right of a proper election brings. Critically, those people had voted under UN banners proclaiming that the United Nations protected their right to vote, assuring them that they would not be persecuted if they marked the ballot paper according to their wishes to express their beliefs. Observers reported that this guarantee of protection by the UN gave the people of East Timor the confidence to freely exercise their opinion, and it was the reason for the large enrolment and the monster turnout.

Since the Indonesian takeover of East Timor in 1975, 200,000 people have lost their lives. This was reason for the East Timorese to be cautious. But the UN had been from village to village, from door to door, to assure them. And they believed, and they came and they voted. In the event, in the nationwide poll, and despite acts of intimidation and threat, there was a 98.6 per cent turnout and a 78.5 per cent vote for independence.

When an Australian led UN peacekeeping force landed in Dili yesterday, they encountered a vastly different East Timor from the one that existed on 30 August—just three weeks before. An estimated 20,000 to 30,000 people are now dead. The Red Cross say that 600,000 people have been driven from their homes and are at risk from hunger, disease or violence in the countryside. They also say that 200,000 people have been driven out of the country altogether and are refugees now in West Timor or elsewhere. Dili itself has been torched and levelled, its infrastructure and services destroyed. From the countryside, there are continued reports of massacre, fear and starvation. No-one can authoritatively say what is the condition of many towns and villages in the hinterland, but we fear the worst.

The UN compound, which became a safe haven for 2,000 refugees, was besieged and all but closed, with a few UN staff courageously hanging on, the rest in Darwin, and the refugees hiding in the hills or repatriated on Australian Air Force Hercules to Darwin. The Red Cross office also sheltered around 2,000 refugees. They were not so lucky. They were removed at gunpoint by armed militia. Their fate is not known. Bishop Carlos Belo, the Nobel Laureate, was driven out, his home trashed, priests and nuns murdered.

From 30 August until yesterday, when the peacekeeping force landed, East Timor had been abandoned to the gunmen. The United Nations promise of protection of a free vote had not held. A nation of people had the most vicious and catastrophic reprisal and revenge visited upon them. Mostly the world watched: action came too late to prevent a holocaust. Our civilisation cannot allow this to occur. Blame must go to those who perpetrated these terrible deeds—deeds which appear to be premeditated and according to an organised, systematic plan. Because it has happened, Australian lives have now been put on the line to stop it continuing and to bring order and, one hopes, peace and eventual reconstruction.

Our thoughts go out to those Australian soldiers and their families today and in the future. In the service of their country and for the principles which we as a nation hold dear, they are at risk. They come from a long tradition of honour among Australians under arms—a tradition stretching back to Gallipoli. But this tradition should not blind us to the dangers. They are in harm's way. It is a huge sacrifice that we are asking of them. I am sure they will acquit themselves well. I hope and trust that they all return unharmed.

Just as Sir Robert Menzies saw it as his role during World War II to point out what he perceived as weaknesses in the Curtin government's handling of the war, so Labor sees it as being only proper and also right for us to raise honestly and candidly the faults, the errors and the dereliction of our government's responsibility now. We are led to believe that these terrible events could not have been predicted. But we knew of the massacre on 6 April at the coastal town of Liquica where at least 58 people were murdered under the watchful eyes of the Indonesian military and the police mobile brigade. We know because our embassy in Jakarta sent two officers to investigate and report. Labor has asked for that report to be released. Our Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer, has declined the request.

So could we have predicted this? In truth, there was an avalanche of warnings. Every East Timorese leader—Bishop Belo, Xanana Gusmao, Ramos Horta—pleaded for Australia and the international community to put security first. They implored us to insist on a transition process underpinned by reconciliation, disarmament and a United Nations peacekeeping presence. Fourteen days after the Liquica massacre, Father Francisco Barreto met Laurie Brereton in Sydney. He came in his capacity as Director of Caritas in East Timor. He also called on Foreign Minister Downer in his plea for Australia to do what was required to guarantee security. He spoke of his dreadful foreboding of what was likely to happen to his people if they were left at the mercy of the militia and their military controllers. His foreboding proved all too correct: Father Barreto was one of the first of the Catholic priests to be assassinated by the militia following the announcement of the ballot result. But even before Liquica, Australia knew what was likely to happen.

On 4 March Australia's Defence Intelligence Organisation gave the government an assessment that pulled no punches. At the time when Foreign Minister Downer was still talking about possible `rogue elements' which might or might not be helping the militias, the Australian Defence Intelligence Organisation said:

The military in East Timor are clearly protecting, and in some instances operating with militias . . . No vigorous action to rein in the military have been noted, implying that General Wiranto is at least turning a blind eye . . . Unless Jakarta takes firm action, the military will continue to support intimidation and violence or at least won't prevent it.
They concluded:
Further violence is certain and Dili will be a focus.

But this was something the Australian government did not want to hear. After all, Australia was already campaigning to help Jakarta resist any move by the international community for peacekeepers. The first of Labor's many calls for peacekeepers came in February this year. We now know that the Clinton administration's pointsman in East Timor, Assistant Secretary of State Stanley Roth, also advocated peacekeepers. That same month, the month of February, he told the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade Secretary, Mr Ashton Calvert, that it was essential to build a coalition to push for peacekeepers for, without peacekeepers, East Timor, he said, would collapse into violence.
At every opportunity, Foreign Minister Downer rubbished the idea of pressing Jakarta to accept peacekeepers, though at times his argument got tortured indeed. He said:

. . . we hope that there won't be a need for a peacekeeping force because if you need a peacekeeping force, you need a peace to keep and peace first has to be negotiated and we hope that when the peace is negotiated it will be a peaceful peace that won't require a peacekeeping force.

Instead of pressing Jakarta to accept peacekeepers, pressing them to accept an international security presence, the Australian government put all its faith in President Habibie and the fact that General Wiranto stood alongside him at the Bali summit. This is very clear from John Howard's own words. On his return from Bali, the Prime Minister declared at a press conference outside his office:

I have no reason to doubt the sincerity of the commitments that were made yesterday by both the President and also the other ministers who were present . . . There is no doubt that there has been a quantum shift so far as the assertion of control both in relation to the military by the Government and also the central control of the military in relation to its activities in East Timor . . . I am certainly satisfied from what's happened publicly from the presence yesterday of General Wiranto, his participation in the discussions and the general attitude taken by Dr Habibie . . . there is a realisation that things had to change, that things have begun to change.
A journalist then inquired:

Prime Minister, how can you maintain the confidence given that even with General Wiranto's presence at a peace ceremony in the territory itself still the atrocities continue and there hasn't been a disarming of the militia?
The Prime Minister replied:
. . . the confidence . . . I expressed as a confidence that things were infinitely better than they were a week or two weeks ago.
That very day the foreign minister sang from the same hymn sheet when he said:

. . . there isn't any doubt that the Indonesians through this process are committed to the laying down of arms endeavouring to achieve disarmament, using the Peace and Stability Commission which they established on 21 April to assist with that process but also to do so in consultation with the United Nations. I can say that much, and obviously we're delighted to get that commitment from the Indonesians . . . I think people will feel more confident with the police playing a much more substantial role on the ground rather than the armed forces.

These were the very same police who helped oversee the massacre at Liquica. I think it is fair to say that these declarations, declarations just three weeks after the horror of Liquica, show that the die was cast. The Australian government embraced the plan to see the ballot through, to see it through come what may and without any real protection for the East Timorese people. Behind the scenes, Australia's intelligence assessments were quietly revised to remove any conflict with the government's acceptance of Jakarta's assurances. Against that background we were part of the United Nations encouragement to vote. It is not as if there is much doubt that there has been a major failure here.
Respected media commentators have this to say. Brian Toohey, in the Australian Financial Review on 18 December, said:

What was needed was unswerving pressure on [General] Wiranto. But Downer blew the chance of this happening when he rejected a plea back in February from a senior State Department official, Stanley Roth, for Australia to stop being "defeatist" and take the lead in building support for peacekeepers. Downer even boasted in Parliament that Roth was "grateful" for being lectured about the importance of the Indonesian military.
Laurie Oakes, in the Bulletin on 21 September, said:

The government argues it was necessary to solve the Timor issue to remove a constant irritant in Australia-Indonesian relations. There was, senior ministers say, no other way than to grab Habibie's referendum and run with it despite the awful cost. `Lives were often going to be lost' is an oft-repeated refrain. What has happened since the ballot, in the government's view, is the massacre we had to have.
Robert Garran, in the Australian on 16 September, said:
Australia has stumbled into East Timor by accident, over an issue that defence planners did not consider a top priority.
Greg Sheridan, in the Australian on the same day, said:
The deepening tragedy of East Timor represents the greatest catastrophe in the history of Australian foreign policy.
This has been a bloody and appalling failure of Australian strategy and policy.
Louise Dodson, in the Australian Financial Review on 17 September, said:

Mr Howard argues that he had no choice: it was either that [the current situation] or no ballot. But if Australia had better marshalled support from the UN, the United States and other countries at the time of the August 30 ballot, faster international diplomatic reaction and maximum international pressure could have prevented two weeks of bloodshed.
Peter Hartcher, in the Australian Financial Review on 18 September, said:

Howard and Co need to understand that this is not just a joust with Labor in the Parliament. This is serious. Carelessness in a crisis is not helping the East Timorese, and it is not helping Australia.
Other commentators have also spoken in similar terms on that same subject.

We as a nation now have a responsibility to give East Timor our most generous support. Sending our troops to lead the peacekeeping mission is a vital first step. We must also be prepared to provide them with humanitarian support on a massive scale and to commence the enormous task of reconstruction. We must play a key role in institution building for a free East Timor, a new independent nation on Australia's very doorstep.

Now, at its very beginning, we must end our de jure recognition of Indonesian sovereignty. This may seem a formality, but it is not. We should not wait for the Indonesian MPR to implement the ballot result. Indonesia's claim of sovereignty has no legitimacy whatsoever. We should do the right thing and end de jure recognition now. We must also be prepared to recognise a provisional East Timorese government—headed, one anticipates, by Xanana Gusmao—as soon as it is formed.

At the same time, it is tremendously important that Australia make a clear distinction between the Indonesian people and the Indonesian military and their militias who have been responsible for all of this horrific violence. The criminals who have directed the appalling events in East Timor must be held fully to account for their actions, but all Australians have a responsibility to ensure this condemnation does not extend to the Indonesian people whose own democratic aspirations are now in jeopardy. The tragedy in East Timor will indeed be even greater if the present crisis wrecks Indonesia's emergent democracy.

Australia must do the right thing by East Timor, but we must also support Indonesia's democracy. There is a responsibility for everyone in public office to ensure anti-Indonesian outbursts have no place in our nation's response to the East Timor crisis. We must make every effort to avoid a dangerous spiral of nationalistic rhetoric that will only damage democratic hopes and produce an enduring estrangement between our two countries.

As Australian troops are now on the ground led by Australian officers in an international peacekeeping force in East Timor, it is also important to remember that under their rules of engagement they are working alongside Indonesian military, some of whom have been associated with the atrocities that have occurred up until now. They are working in a situation in which they are not able, under their rules of engagement, to forcibly disarm militia of their weapons. They are working in a situation in which they do not have the right of hot pursuit of guerilla activity in East Timor across the border into West Timor. They are working in a situation in which it is estimated that some 175,000 refugees are still being held in Kupang in West Timor, the furthest point on the western shores of that country.

They are working in a situation of great military difficulty. They are working in classic guerilla mountain country in which it is possible to sustain guerilla warfare over a long time with an ever increasing scale of casualties being inflicted. This is indeed a very difficult operation for the United Nations peacekeeping force. What is a priority is to ensure that those East Timorese forcibly held in West Timor do not become hostages in this conflict. I applaud the efforts of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in trying to get them to have free passage back home to East Timor. That becomes an important priority. If there is a military engagement on the ground in East Timor, I fear that the militia, given the humanity they have expressed thus far, will start venting their spleen even further on those refugees they hold in custody against their will in West Timor. It is very important that steps to protect their rights proceed urgently.

It is also very important that the rules of engagement, subject to the circumstances on the ground in East Timor, be able to be revised if Australian troops are put in a situation in which they are further endangered. This is a situation, as I have said, in which a guerilla war can be waged over a long time which will inevitably sustain rising casualties. I do not think a peacekeeping force with the requirements on them that this peacekeeping force has is entirely in a position of being able to fight without one of their arms tied behind their backs. Those things which restrain them should be now removed.

There is a major question as well about the rehabilitation of East Timor. As a country, its subsistence is as a farming and agrarian economy. It is not a strong economic superpower, and now they have the daunting task of rehabilitating a nation that has been devastated by hoodlums and by thugs and at the point of a gun. Any of those of us who have seen film of the devastation of Dili can anticipate what the scenes look like in remote country townships around the country. One expects a nation with no infrastructure.

There is a huge cost here to be paid in rehabilitating this economy for those people who honestly voted under United Nations protection on 30 August for independence. The 78.5 per cent of those in a 98.6 per cent turnout who voted for independence should be given a chance to start their life in a new country in the circumstances of that country at the time in which they voted. The cost of rehabilitation becomes an international question now. Certainly, it is a cost that goes to the custodians of that country at the time. It is a cost Indonesia must bear. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The story of East Timor is one of almost unbelievable courage and also one of almost unbelievable barbarity. In fact, I cannot think of a word bad enough to use for what has happened in East Timor, particularly since the vote. We should also pay particular attention to the acts of courage of every single East Timorese who went to vote on election day, 30 August. These were people who knew what would happen. They knew that the place was going to erupt once the vote came in. I suspect that the Indonesian government did not realise how strong the vote would be for independence, but I must say that pretty well everybody there did realise how strong it would be.

speech.para: There had been intimidation, there had been harassment, there had been murders, there had been massacres, there had been torture; there had been everything you can possibly think of to try to stop people from voting for independence. But, even so, and we just heard the statistics from Senator Cook, so many people turned out. Some 98 per cent of registered voters actually turned out to vote, and most of those turned out to vote in the morning. By the time we on the official observer delegation from Australia got to one of the polling booths at 1 o'clock, there must have been about 12 people standing in line. We went and asked if there was intimidation or what was going on. We were told, `No, most people have already voted.' That was 1 o'clock in the afternoon and the polling booths were staying open until 4 o'clock. I think we in Australia do not realise how lucky we are. We complain about having to vote. These people were begging to vote. They all turned up. There were thousands of them there before the polling booths opened.

So we saw the courage of these people. They had fled to makeshift camps in the mountains and then came down the night before the vote. When we were coming back into Dili the day before the vote after visiting a few polling booths, we drove past dozens and dozens of people walking along the roads—getting off the road so we could drive past—coming down with just a bag, with the children and with a sleeping roll. They were going to sleep at the polling booth and vote in the morning and then flee back to the mountains because they knew for an absolute fact that the world would turn to dust after the vote because the vote would be so strongly for independence. And, of course, it was. So there was spectacular courage shown by the people of East Timor.

It is interesting, too, that I have heard of a lot of other individual acts of courage—and not just from the people who are the good guys. There were spectacular acts of courage from CIVPOL—the civil police attached to UNAMET. We, on the observer delegation, put one instance in the report we gave to Mr Downer. I hope that that report will be tabled because I think it is particularly interesting for people to read. It was certainly particularly interesting for us to hear. There was a report by CIVPOL, which we had met, about a particularly dangerous area at Gleno in Ermera. There were reports in other areas, too. We heard about particular acts of bravery from CIVPOL throughout the three months—and after the vote as well. We also heard about particular acts of bravery from POLRI, the police.

We have heard a lot about the Indonesian police and their role in this ballot. As a whole, I think they have very little to be proud of and a lot to be ashamed of. Equally, I can think of two instances of important acts of heroism which I heard of. One was where an Indonesian policeman probably saved the life of a Western journalist, an Englishman. I spoke to the journalist later and he was very impressed. He was sure that it was all very genuine and that this man had risked his own life in doing that—and he was an Indonesian. There was another where a policeman attached to our own delegation was probably instrumental in saving a journalist from a lot of trouble, if not saving his life. There were a lot of acts of heroism and not all were on the side of those who we see as the good guys. There were acts of heroism all over the place. There were also almost unbelievable acts of barbarity. I cannot even tell you some of the worst stories that I have heard because they are so bad and so appalling—such as the things that happened to babies—that it is impossible to talk about them.

However, both incredible courage and incredible barbarism have been evident for decades in East Timor. I was horrified and shocked, but I was not really surprised at the barbarity after the vote. Evidence of barbarity has been available to this parliament and to the Australian public. Not everybody can be interested in everything, and I certainly take that into account. There are a lot of subjects of deep importance to a lot of Australians that I have absolutely no interest in whatsoever, so I do not expect everybody to know everything about East Timor or even to know what there is to be known about East Timor. But evidence has been available in the Australian parliament for many years about the barbarity—the appalling acts of violence, torture, terrorism and intimidation—almost exclusively on the part of ABRI, which is the former name of the previously constituted army of Indonesia in East Timor.

We had an exhibition of photographs of tortured East Timorese a couple of years ago. I cannot blame senators and members for not wanting to come to that. I did not particularly want to look at it myself. It was absolutely unbelievably awful. They were genuine photographs of what ABRI had been doing in East Timor to the East Timorese who they thought were in favour of independence, not just a couple of years ago but for more than two decades. It is pretty shocking that I have seen photographs over probably 10 years of what a severed head looks like. I should not know what a severed head looks like. Children should not know what a severed head looks like. But these things—and they are not things; they were people—were actually put on poles outside schools. We have known that this has been happening for decades. But it is not just that; other dreadful forms of torture have been happening for decades, and we have known about them for decades.

Over the last few months, I have been told by various people from both the government and the Labor Party that it is fairly useless to go back over history and that we should all now be looking to the future. I think it is actually quite useful to have a look at history and to see that people from all the parties and the Independents that have made up the Australian parliament over the last 24 years have been very firmly of the opinion that the East Timorese should have a say in their own future and should be able to determine what they want to be—whether they want to be independent or part of Indonesia.

Even though these people have been there all along and have not been able to be shut up—and I give credit to a lot of people who are in the parliament at the moment—those at the top of the different parties—not the Democrats, but the Labor Party, the Liberal Party and probably the National Party—were very firmly of the view that East Timor was a part of Indonesia and would remain a part of Indonesia and there was nothing that any of us could do about it. I am sure that, on occasion, when ministers went overseas they did mention that there was supposed to be barbarity and torture going on in East Timor. I am sure they asked whether they could please be assured that it was not, and I am sure that they were assured that it was not. I know when I went to Indonesia I was assured that it was not by General Try Sutrisno at the time. But it was, and we knew it was. I do not think that we did enough.

Two election campaigns ago, I remember I was at a policy debate in Brisbane—I think at the University of Queensland—with Mr Downer and the then Senator Evans. As part of the policy which the Democrats have had for the last 2½ decades, I said that I believed we should be removing our de jure recognition of Indonesia's sovereignty over East Timor and encouraging a vote of self-determination for those people. This is something that, starting with Colin Mason in 1978, the Democrats have been saying in this place.

Both former Senator Evans and Mr Downer demonstrated to me how naive I was, how this was just silly, how this would never happen and how it was not in the best interests of the East Timorese nor those of Australia nor those of Indonesia. We have heard that all before. I remember there was one man up the back of the audience who got up and demonstrated to me in this chain reaction of dominoes falling how, if Australia removed its de jure recognition of Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor, it would inevitably lead to World War III, and then we would all be in terrible trouble. He was serious; he actually thought this would be the case. It was probably just a couple of months later that New Zealand removed its de jure recognition of Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor. And guess what? World War III did not break out. In fact, nothing really happened, except that the Indonesians had a bit more pressure put on them to do something about East Timor. If Australia had done that a bit sooner, it would have put a lot more pressure on the Indonesians to do something about East Timor and to do something about that torture.

I could table photographs of and reports about what has been going on and what we all hope to heaven will now stop in East Timor, but I will not, because they are so awful. I have tabled those over the years. As I said before, I went to East Timor as an official observer. I would like to thank the Minister for Foreign Affairs for asking me to do that. I would also like to thank the leader of my own party, Senator Lees, for putting up my name as the official Democrat on that observer mission. I did not think I would ever get into East Timor; I have tried in the past and have not been able to. But the Indonesian government were very good. They gave me a visa. I went over there, and it was one of the most moving experiences of my life. I am sure Senator Payne will agree with me when she speaks on this a bit later. She was on that observer mission as well, as were a number of other Australians. Tim Fischer led the delegation. We also had Laurie Brereton, Pat Walsh, Anne Wigglesworth, Rae Perry from local government and a lot of people—I think it was four people—from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Everybody worked really hard on that delegation.

It sounds odd to say it, but we all enjoyed our time there immensely. It was difficult, but it was incredibly inspiring to see these people carrying out huge acts of bravery by voting when they had been well and truly warned about what would happen if they voted for their own independence. And it did happen; in fact, it happened on an even worse scale. It is almost impossible to believe there could be a worse scale, but this probably was. They had been warned. There were statements about rivers of blood flowing if they voted for independence, and they did flow. Rivers of blood flowed because they voted for independence.

One young man came up to speak to me. He was so happy. He had voted for independence, and he wanted to thank the international community for giving him the opportunity to do that. I asked him why he was not going to vote for autonomy if the threats were so bad—and they were; we heard about them from Bishop Belo, Father Barretto and a number of people before the vote. We knew this would happen. He said, `You would not believe how bad it is here. It's got to get better. If we vote for independence, it's got to get better.' I hope to goodness that, from now on, it will.

There is no civil war in East Timor. I do not think anybody in this parliament is still using that term, but commentators are. It is not a civil war, because it is just one side attacking the other. It is the side that wants East Timor to still be part of Indonesia attacking the side that does not. The side that does not is at least 80 per cent of the population and probably more. The side that does can never get rid of them. They cannot get rid of them all. They might have taken 300,000—which is the latest estimate I have seen—out of East Timor and either killed them or put them in West Timor, Flores, South Sulawesi or goodness knows where, but they cannot get rid of all of them. We know there are far too many. We have to worry about those refugees, those displaced people who are now not in East Timor anymore. We have to worry about the ones who are in East Timor now, but we have to worry probably even more about the ones who are not. They have to be able to get back there if they want to, and 300,000 is an awful lot of people.

We also have to worry about whether there will be destabilisation in the future. We have to worry about whether, when East Timor becomes independent, as I believe it will, anyone will run a deliberate campaign of destabilisation of East Timor because other parts of Indonesia have to be shown what happens to you if you try to get out of Indonesia. We have to worry about that too. We should also be thinking about the presidential election that will happen in November, because that will give us a pointer to exactly why many of the things that have happened have happened.

It is also really important that we tell the ordinary Indonesian people that, if more noise about this crisis seems to be coming from Australia at the moment, that is because we are the closest nation to them amongst a huge community of nations around the world that feel exactly the same way as we do. It is not just Australia saying this; it is the entire world saying this. Even the Security Council gave unanimous support to the motion that set up INTERFET, an international—it is called international for a good reason; it is not just an Australian organisation—body of peace enforcers to go in and enforce a peace that the TNI either could not or would not enforce. I am pretty certain it is `would not', because some amongst them seem to be able to snap their fingers and turn the violence on and off. The Security Council gave unanimous support to the setting up of that peace enforcement body. The Security Council, as we all remember, includes two nations that traditionally do not like to see peace enforcement in somebody's country. I suspect that is because they think it may happen to them. But every single nation in the Security Council voted for this one.

I hope the Indonesian people themselves will reflect on that, because it is going to be a difficult time and it may last for years. It will certainly last for months, but I suspect it may last for years. I want to say to the many Indonesians who want to bring about democratic reform—and there are hundreds of thousands of them, probably millions—that their endeavours and their successes are of immense importance to us in Australia. What has happened in East Timor demonstrates just how important democratic change is to Indonesia. They do not want this to happen elsewhere and there is one way to stop that—that is, make sure the torture, the intimidation and those things that happened in East Timor do not happen elsewhere.

If Indonesia were at the stage now of upholding universal human rights within this region, then they would be more inclined to cooperation rather than confrontation. We have to think in that context about those human rights organisations and supporters who have supported human rights there for many years, usually at considerable cost to themselves. Also, what about the 300 Indonesian students who actually came to Timor for the plebiscite to give support to the Timorese? There was a lot of that as well. Reports in the Jakarta Post demonstrate that an increasing number of intellectuals and academics in Indonesia are questioning what is going on in Indonesia and supporting democracy there. So there should be scope for us, as a real democratic society, to help further the formation of a truly democratic society in Indonesia.

So where to from here? Let me just finish on this. Of course we should be encouraging the democracy movement in Indonesia. Of course we should be reopening Cox Peninsula—I will say it again—which was started by Sir Robert Menzies, particularly so we could get into Indonesia, and they should be able to hear it in Jakarta right now. Of course we should be ending de jure recognition. Of course there should be a war crimes tribunal. And of course we have to do everything we can to support our troops and support East Timor. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the motion on East Timor being debated today. I acknowledge Senator Bourne's contribution. I can say to her that, from discussions I have had with Senator Payne, I do understand what that trip to East Timor was like and the difficulties you witnessed. Even though you said it is odd to say you enjoyed it, I can understand that you would and I do not think it is particularly odd to say that at all. It must have been a fascinating experience, and I agree that you were very lucky, as was anyone who had the opportunity to witness it.

speech.para: It makes you think twice about the people who complain intermittently when elections are held about the bother of going to cast a vote when there are people who are prepared to die to have that opportunity. It just seems incredible really. But come next election, Senator Bourne, you will strike someone and I will strike someone who will give us a mouthful about why we are not worth voting for and why they should not have to go to the bother of casting a vote and having the chance to have a say in how their lives are run.

I want to spend most of my time today focusing on the contribution that the Australian Federal Police made prior to the need for the UN Security Council resolution that we are debating today—prior to the need for us to be sending a peacekeeping force into Timor. As I am sure we all understand, the Australian Federal Police formed a significant portion of the UNAMET contribution that was in Timor. The Australian Federal Police responded in a very timely fashion when first approached by the government in April this year to provide personnel for a possible contingent. People may not realise the sort of work and logistical changes that need to be made in order to get people ready. I understand it from a police perspective dealing with 50 people, so I can magnify it to a certain extent to imagine what the Defence Force might have had to go through.

There was a time when we were not sure if the contingent would be required and the appropriate planning was made. On 25 May, 50 members began training for the deployment to East Timor. Then in June, the former AFP general manager, Alan Mills, was selected by the United Nations to head the civilian police contingent of UNAMET.
