That contin gent consisted of 272 police from a wide range of countries, and I might mention some of them: Ireland, England, the United States, Canada, New Zealand, the Philippines, Malaysia, Sweden, Mozambique, Japan, Pakistan, Russia, Uruguay, Zimbabwe, Bangladesh, Austria, Thailand, Brazil, Nepal, Egypt, Korea, Ghana and Senegal. That highlights what Senator Bourne said—that the view being expressed about what should happen in Timor is not a view that is entirely an Australian view; it is very much an international view.

The Australian Federal Police provided training in Darwin for all of the police contingents prior to their deployment to Timor. On 21 June the first deployment of police personnel to Timor commenced, with all of them being successfully deployed by the beginning of July. All in all, 50 Australian police were deployed across all regions of Timor—that was 50 out of the 272, in addition to the leader, Alan Mills, whom I have mentioned.

It is important to understand what this UNAMET contribution did. It ensured that the ballot could be properly conducted, that people could safely get to the polling booths and cast their votes unhindered—other than by the occasional ill-advised journalist—and that the votes would be properly counted. That was a very significant contribution because that is what allowed for this overwhelming expression by the East Timorese that they wanted independence. If you do not provide a mechanism for a free and fair ballot, if you do not provide a mechanism to ensure that the ballots are properly counted, you cannot rely on that expression of view. We are able to rely on it because of the United Nations civilian police force that was there.

I will just give you a couple of examples of what happened on the ballot day. The ballot was held on 30 August. During this ballot, one of the locally engaged United Nations staff members was stabbed by militia members during the escort of ballot boxes duties. There were significant efforts made by two Federal Police members to resuscitate that person, who sadly later died. Those officers were themselves endangered by ongoing gunfire into their residence. From that time on, all of the members endured various degrees of difficulty, none of them minor—conditions which we here I am sure can only imagine. In many cases, they witnessed the death of people whom they had been working with and developed friendships with over the weeks they had been there. They were deprived of their own liberty, in many cases being under siege within their own compounds. They gave refuge to the sick and the needy and administered first aid to those where they could.

As we all know, with conditions deteriorating in East Timor it became necessary to evacuate the majority of UNAMET personnel. But what many people perhaps do not appreciate is that a number of the AFP contingent, including its commander, Mr Alan Mills—who, as I said, had previously retired but had then come back into one of the most volatile tasks that the AFP could offer—volunteered to remain at the UNAMET compound in Dili to ensure the safety of some 1,600 refugees who had sought United Nations sanctuary. Those volunteers had a very clear view of what would happen to those refugees if the final UNAMET people left. Such was the dedication and devotion of the AFP members and the courage they displayed in fairly adverse conditions and despite grave threats to their personal safety. We could see these happenings on our televisions from the comfort of our offices here or in our lounge rooms at home—but watching those things occurring in Dili on television is entirely different from actually being there and putting your own life at risk to ensure that other people's lives are in some way given a greater chance.

It should be noted that the AFP had trained a further 50 contingent members who, under normal rotation, were to replace the first 50 who had been sent there. Despite the non-deployment of these personnel to East Timor, 17 members of that detachment were deployed to Darwin where they provided essential support to the United Nations and the Northern Territory Police service in assisting with the relocation of refugees from Dili to Darwin. In summary, it was a very profes sional and dedicated job by the Australian Federal Police, of which I am sure all Australians can be proud.

It is important to conclude by highlighting how many other people also have played roles—smaller, sure, than the Defence Force are playing now, and smaller than perhaps the Federal Police played by being there. Nonetheless, people ought not to watch their television sets and imagine that forces just fly into Darwin and it is all easily handled. Take Customs, for example. You might think, `Well, what could they possibly have to do with the sorts of activities that are going on in East Timor?' Obviously in order to handle the inflow of East Timorese and UNAMET personnel and to handle the inflow of goods, arms and weaponry that might come in here before going to Timor, we needed a number of things done. Regulations needed to be changed, and changed very quickly. So somewhere in buildings around Canberra there were people working quite late at night to ensure that their task in this effort was completed and completed on time.

We have had assistance from people in Customs—only 20 of them; not many. But what I am trying to highlight is that I am sure this kind of contribution is replicated in other departments all around Australia—people who, having had an hour's notice, agreed, left their homes and families and went up to ensure a smooth transition for the people coming in and out of Darwin who, admittedly, have a much more important role.

In conclusion, I again congratulate the Australian Federal Police on the job that they have done in this. I agree with the motion, and I wish our troops well who are there. I also highlight the role that has been played by a whole lot of other people who do not normally get mentioned.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the motion on East Timor which has the unanimous support not only of the Senate but of the Australian parliament. The issue of East Timor is one that has been before the Australian parliament in one form or another since 1975. Those of us who have had involvement in appropriate committees of the parliament—I, myself, particularly as a longstanding member of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade—have been dealing with the East Timor issue. Not only has that issue been dealt with as a particular reference of that committee I have just mentioned, but also it has been before the parliament itself. One has to recognise that it has been an agonising issue for all of us on both sides of politics.

speech.para: In early December 1975, when Indonesian soldiers marched into East Timor, Australia was facing, and involved in, its greatest constitutional crisis. The Governor-General had sacked the Whitlam government on 11 November, a caretaker Fraser government was in place and the subsequent election did not take place until 13 December. So at that particular time, Australia was utterly preoccupied with its own constitutional problems. Also at that particular time, I do not believe matters were helped by the then deputy leader of the coalition, Mr Anthony, saying, `We do not want East Timor becoming the Cuba of South-East Asia.' Such remarks, in my view, were intemperate and only encouraged the Indonesians to take the action they did. We were in no position to respond diplomatically in the lead-up to the Indonesian invasion or in the immediate period afterwards.

By the late 1970s, the Fraser government had accepted the incorporation of East Timor into Indonesia as that country's 27th province. The Labor Party at that time opposed that acceptance. When we came to government we had a lengthy debate at the 1994 national conference of the Labor Party and reluctantly accepted the incorporation but still demanded that there be an act of self-determination for the East Timorese people. That act was a long time coming and, of course, only took place two weeks ago. But with various episodes occurring in East Timor all through the eighties and nineties, many of us in this parliament as well as in the Australian community were led to express grave concerns about the treatment of the East Timorese people—that clearly they did not want to be incorporated into Indonesia and wanted to have their own community, their own culture and their own independent country.

In 1991 I remember there being considerable outrage not only in Australia but also around the world at the so-called Dili massacre, when probably well over 100 unarmed East Timorese who were peacefully demonstrating were massacred by the Indonesian army. At that time, I was chair of the Human Rights Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I remember our holding a special public hearing at which evidence was given by one of the survivors of the massacre, an Australian aid worker who was in Dili on that day. We also had the showing of a film which had been taken secretly of the massacre in the cemetery, with the aid worker describing his own observations of the event, who did what to whom and how dreadful it was. The Australian parliament was one of the first in the world to expose what actually happened in Dili on that dreadful day way back in 1991.

In 1992 the joint foreign affairs committee conducted a major inquiry into Australia's relations with Indonesia. I led that delegation to Indonesia. We requested a visit to East Timor; we were refused on the grounds that it was not secure for us to visit. I think that that was more to do with the fact that the Indonesian government was embarrassed by the fact that a lot of East Timorese may have taken the opportunity to indicate to the Australian delegation their support for independence.

While we were in Indonesia, Mr MacKellar, the then deputy chair of the committee, and I had an almost two-hour conversation with the then Vice-President of Indonesia and head of the armed forces, General Try Sutrisno. We spent most of that time arguing about Indonesian policy in East Timor and the need for the Indonesian government to substantially reduce the armed forces they had based in East Timor that were part of the problem of significant human rights abuses. I must say the discussion was not successful in one sense—they did not reduce the number of soldiers—but I think it was useful that, at that level, this very senior member of the Indonesian government and head of their armed forces knew Australia's strength of view on this issue. Later that night, quietly—and, I must say, secretly—my colleagues Laurie Ferguson and Colin Hollis and I had a meeting with a number of East Timorese students who were living in Jakarta and who gave us a briefing on what was happening in East Timor. I have to say that it was a particularly moving occasion for the three of us to get first-hand information about what was going on and the treatment of the East Timorese people.

The parliament of Australia has on and off, but quite consistently, been debating and dealing with the issue of East Timor. When we debated the Timor Gap Treaty, the future of East Timor was debated. Whenever there has been some aspect about human rights in our relations with Indonesia, East Timor has always been part of it. Some people said that the real issue was that we should not have any dialogue at all with Indonesia, that we should declare our complete opposition so that we did not support the incorporation and that we should put our relationship with Indonesia on hold and freeze it. I do not think we could have afforded to do that, though the moral issue was very difficult. Indonesia will always be our nearest neighbour. With 200 million-plus people, as the biggest Muslim country in the world and as the third or fourth most populated country in the world, it is impossible for Australia not to have an ongoing dialogue and relationship with Indonesia, whatever the rocky parts of that relationship are.

The real issue is to work out how far we can push the envelope on human rights and democratic issues in Indonesia overall, as well as in East Timor, and that is an argument about degree which this parliament has been having for well over 20 years—since the invasion of East Timor. But we have also had this argument on the issue of general human rights abuses in Indonesia. Whatever it does to our relationship with Indonesia, I do not think that we should back away from the fact that, when the human rights of individuals in Indonesia—particularly their political human rights—are removed or reduced, we should take up the call as a democratic country to defend those people.

As part of the delegation's visit in 1992, we raised the fact that at that time there were human rights abuses in Aceh. In our report, if people care to read it now, we said that we estimated that over 2,000 people in Aceh province had been killed by the Indonesian military over their dispute for some form of autonomy. We also found that in the early 1990s the Indonesian government was still executing people who were involved in the so-called coup of 1965. More than 25 years after the event, people were still being executed in Indonesia. When we raised this with the Indonesian government, they said, `Our review and our appeal processes take their time in our country,' which makes our lawyers look positively speedy by comparison. But we did raise those issues.

I know other parliamentary delegations have consistently raised human rights issues. Despite the fact that we now have a very difficult relationship with Indonesia which needs to be rebuilt, we should not give up the right to criticise or raise human rights issues with Indonesia—or with any other country. I remember that when an Indonesian member of parliament said we were being too tough on Indonesia I pointed out that the then Australian government had raised human rights abuses with the American government over their use of capital punishment in the United States. There seemed to be a very high proportion of poor, black Americans being executed in America, whereas if you were a rich white you could always find a way to escape capital punishment.

As others have said, I strongly support the Australian men and women who will be serving in East Timor, and they go with my best wishes and those of everybody else. It should be noted that 57 years ago the East Timorese people supported for almost a full year the Australian Independent Company—the 2/2nd, a commando unit—and later other units in their guerrilla campaign in Timor against the Japanese forces. The only reason that the Australian commandos lasted so long before they were withdrawn was that there were the support of and sacrifices made by the civilian population of East Timor. Although the East Timorese people may say it is a little late that 57 years later our soldiers are now returning to help restore their country to peace and order to enable them to proceed to being an independent country, I still say that it is better late than never.

I suspect that many of those veterans who are still alive in Australia from those commando units who were in Timor for almost a year in 1942 would be delighted to see Australian service men and women returning to East Timor to help that country establish itself after the terrible events of the last two or three weeks.

I would also point out that on my visit to Indonesia in 1992 the delegation had the opportunity to lay a wreath at Oeseau Village outside Kupang in West Timor, which is where a number of Australians were killed in fighting the Japanese in February 1942, at a memorial maintained by the Timorese people in memory of those Australian soldiers.

The issue now faced in East Timor by the international peace enforcement group led by Australia is, of course, to restore peace and order, to enable the East Timorese people to again have some confidence that the rest of the world will not let them be murdered, raped and pillaged by the so-called militia. I am sure the Australians service men and women and the other international forces will do that job and do it well, even at some risk to themselves. Unfortunately, we may sustain some casualties. That will be very sad, but I think all Australians understand that this is a commitment that has to be made.
The next very important issue that must be dealt with is UN Security Council resolution 1264, the resolution to establish the force to go into Indonesia. In paragraph 7 on page 2 it says:
7. Stresses that it is the responsibility of the Indonesian authorities to take immediate and effective measures to ensure the safe return of refugees to East Timor;

We now have calculations that several hundred thousand East Timorese refugees are in West Timor, on the island of Flores and on other islands that they have fled to—or have been taken to—to escape the mini holocaust in East Timor. It is paramount that those refugees are able to return as soon as possible to East Timor. Even though there is not much left of East Timor in infrastructure, we have to return the people to make sure that the country has a viable future. If we do not return those refugees, then the militia have half achieved their own objective, and that is to not allow a viable East Timor to be established as an independent country.

We have to ensure that the Indonesian government does not allow militia forces to dictate in the refugee camps who can return or to threaten people not to return, and that is a must for the Indonesian government. It is in the UN resolution. We and all of the other major countries represented—particularly the permanent members of the UN Security Council, led by the United States of America—must not back off when it comes to putting our influence on the Indonesian government so that these refugees can be safely returned to East Timor to establish their independent country.

It is clear that not only do we have a commitment running into hundreds of millions of dollars to maintain our service people in East Timor to return peace and order but we are going to be faced over the next couple of years within our aid program with having to spend several hundred million dollars a year to re-establish the infrastructure so that East Timor can be a viable independent country.

There has often been a debate in Australia about the level of foreign aid that we give. Often, unfortunately, if there have to be cutbacks for fiscal reasons in the budget, foreign aid often takes the first hit, because Australians are not directly beneficiaries of it. But we will be beneficiaries of expending several hundred million dollars on restoring East Timor's infrastructure to be a viable country. If we do not, we will then have an enormous refugee problem in the region, which will be even more costly to resolve. Several hundred million dollars in infrastructure, humanitarian and development aid over the next couple of years will result, in my view, in a very good return and be cheap at the price. The government should not be mean-spirited in making that money available in foreign aid.

We also have to understand that, as a result, Australia will be required to make a commit ment to East Timor for many years to come. It may be a requirement that we have service people and Federal Police there to maintain security. In particular, I imagine over the next decade or more we will be asking schoolteachers, nurses, doctors, other humanitarian aid workers, development workers—people with particular skills—to go to East Timor and help build the country to make it a viable entity.

At the same time, though, we have to work on re-establishing a relationship with Indonesia. We must ensure that Indonesia becomes more democratic, and that the decision in their parliament in the coming election of their president reflects the election result that took place two or three months ago.

talk.start.para: —How can they do that? It was only 30 per cent.

—I would suggest that somebody who got 35 per cent or 32 per cent of the vote is a more likely representative of the people than somebody who did not even stand at the election. Even if it upsets some forces in Indonesia, our view is that electing a president who has not gone to a general election of only three months ago really does give a very bad signal about where that country is going.

speech.para: I know that this may be seen by some Indonesians again as Australian paternalism. It is not Australian paternalism. It is actually making it clear that the Indonesian people have expressed a view in an election where a number of people stood for election to be the President. If, in one form or another, one of those candidates is not elected—and, I would have to suggest, if it is not Sukarnoputri—I really think that the country will have considerable difficulty convincing a lot of people around the world that it is on the right path to having a more democratic form of government. We should not be backward in expressing that view—because, overwhelmingly, Indonesians want that as well.

At times, people tell us that we are interfering. I do not think we are interfering when we support the popular view expressed in a democratically free election that took place only a couple of months ago. Whatever the case and whatever the difficulties ahead, all of us in this parliament and in the Australian community know that, whether we like it or not, we are going to have to slowly but surely rebuild our relationship with Indonesia, because we have no alternative. The alternative is too awful to contemplate. We have to have a relationship with the Indonesian people and we have to encourage them in their development and in the development of a more open and democratic society. That will bring peace to the region more than will any other development. I hope that in the years ahead this parliament and the governments of Australia can, in a constructive way, build a relationship again with Indonesia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The Australian Democrats are proud to be associated with the motion we are debating today. We support the motion, which acknowledges East Timorese independence and the UN resolution in relation to peacekeeping forces and humanitarian support. Of course, we send our best wishes and support to the Australian troops.

speech.para: As the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Lees, emphasised in her comments, support for the brave Australian men and women who have gone to East Timor is pretty much universal. Clearly, there is cross-party support in these chambers for those brave men and women. We very much applaud their commitment not only to their nation but also to peace in the region and the upholding of human rights.

The primary focus of the world's response to the situation in East Timor following that overwhelming vote for independence has been on bringing about peace and resolving the massive humanitarian crisis which has developed—and it is quite right that our emphasis should be on that. Clearly, some of today's speeches have focused on the role to be played by Australia and, of course, the United Nations in bringing about peace in East Timor. Certainly, the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Lees, and our foreign affairs spokeswoman, Senator Vicki Bourne, have made reference to these aspects. Obviously, Senator Lees highlighted the signifi cance of the UN, the issues surrounding the UN in this day and age, and its importance in the global community.

I was particularly proud to hear Senator Vicki Bourne's comments in relation to the strong history that the Australian Democrats have on the issue of East Timorese independence. Clearly, our party has long supported independence in that region; and I am very proud to acknowledge the work of former senators from the Australian Democrats in this place, whether that be Senators Macklin, Mason, McLean, Vigor, Chipp, Coulter and Powell or many others who have all spoken against the Indonesian occupation of East Timor. Our party policy has long reflected that. What is so unfortunate—and we have expressed this on a number of occasions, including in the speech by our previous speaker, Senator Bourne—is that it has taken so long for Australian governments of either persuasion to shift their ground on this issue.

Turning away from the sometimes shameful history of this nation on this issue to the future, I would like to focus on justice for, and in, East Timor and in particular on something to which Senator Bourne alluded, and that is the issue of war crimes trials. On Friday of last week, the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights released a damning report on the human rights situation in East Timor. For many people, this was just another in the series of distressing reports on human rights abuses in that region. But the report is far more significant than that. It is evidence of a massive and fundamental change in the nature of the High Commissioner's work.

Mary Robinson, the High Commissioner, has adopted an approach which has managed to sustain an international focus on human rights. As the situation in East Timor rapidly deteriorated following the announcement of the referendum results, the High Commissioner consulted with the Secretary-General of the United Nations and decided to visit Indonesia. She flew to Darwin and Jakarta to assess the situation and she met with the relevant parties. She was briefed by UNAMET CIVPOL officers, military liaison officers, the evacuat ed UNAMET international and local staff and their families, and UN volunteers.

In Jakarta she also met with the Indonesian President, as well as senior government representatives, the chairman and members of the Indonesian Human Rights Commission, civil society leaders, and Xanana Gusmao, the leader of the East Timorese independence movement. These meetings were extremely influential. They were an influential step along the path to the approval of UN intervention by the Indonesian executive government.
Mary Robinson's report also details some of the more recent human rights abuses. At the risk of repetition, I would like to quote a couple of rather telling sentences. The report says:

According to reports from Kalyanamitra, women were raped and sexually harassed by militia and Indonesian military in Dili between the 7-10 September. Sexual violence allegedly also occurred during the forced movement of people to West Timor. Reports have been received that many women were raped by militia on a boat taking displaced persons to West Timor from Dili. Furthermore, information has been received that women are being raped in the camps in West Timor.

This is not intended as an indictment of Indonesia or the Indonesian people but perhaps of a number of individuals in Indonesia and East Timor. These reports, as many people would recognise, are distressingly similar to reports which we have heard from places like Somalia, Rwanda, Chechnya, Kosovo and many other places. We have heard some incredible stories, and I have no doubt there are more to come, from those parliamentarians in the delegation that visited. They would have been aware of, and would almost have witnessed at first hand, some of these tragic occurrences.

One of the major questions that must now be resolved is how the international community can and will actually respond to these reports. The first step is obviously to bring about peace to the troubled territory of East Timor. Reconciliation and justice are far more complex issues and are quite clearly central to the long-term social and political health of East Timor.

The processes cannot be rushed, but it is significant that they have been raised at such an early stage. Discussions on the role of a war crimes tribunal are just beginning in relation to East Timor, but in a place like Cambodia the need for justice continues to be a central theme in society. It is gratifying to read that the Cambodian Prime Minister has acknowledged the importance of justice in his first speech to the United Nations, but it is clearly important that this process is viewed as fair, impartial and just by all parties. The establishment of international war crimes tribunals provides an important demonstration of the concerns of the world community and the need for an impartial perspective. I can only hope that this horrific situation provides further impetus for the establishment of a permanent international criminal court.

It is very important that we start gathering evidence of alleged crimes as soon as possible so that we can minimise the loss of important testimony and facts, and to ensure that responses do not become further clouded by the complexities of the political situation. There is a long history to the circumstances in East Timor and swift but fair justice will be crucial in building a future.

It is difficult to understand the motivations of the militias and the extent to which they have been directed and/or supplied by the Indonesian military. I have no intention of finding people guilty in this speech, but there are many questions to be resolved about their involvement. From all reports, it appears that there has been a level of systematic control and coordination of the militias and we do need to find out who those people are who are responsible. To quote again from the High Commissioner:
There is overwhelming evidence that East Timor has seen a deliberate, vicious and systematic campaign of gross violations of human rights. I condemn those responsible in the strongest possible terms.
We should all concur with those sentiments. This must not continue any longer.

We must also remain conscious of the need to build the institutions of law and order in East Timor as a major contribution to peace and security. This is something the former speaker, Senator Schacht, alluded to in this debate. This is not going to be easy, but this is one of the fields in which Australians have proved that we have expertise and experience. Australians were primarily responsible for the creation of a law and justice system in Somalia during the United Nations deployment there. We recruited and trained civilian police officers and built a respected legal system. I also acknowledge the words of Senator Vanstone in her speech earlier when she talked about the effectiveness and the superiority, if you like, of law enforcement officials in this country, especially those who went over to supervise the election process. We need to be mindful that a central part of our role is clearly to assist in establishing a civilian framework for law, order and government.

I am well aware that the words and actions of Australians continue to lead to increased tensions between Australia and Indonesia. I am certainly not trying to contribute to that perception. Australia has had an excellent relationship with Indonesia over many years. In retrospect, I think it is unfortunate that some of our relationship appears to have been based occasionally on silence and acquiescence. At this difficult time I must also draw attention to the dramatic changes that have occurred within Indonesian politics and society during the last two years in particular. Throughout Indonesia there has been very dramatic political change. After 30 years of government by President Suharto there is now a new willingness to discuss politics and some of the less desirable practices of those years. I fear it will be a long time before there is peace and trust among the Indonesian people.

It has been a very difficult time of transition in Indonesia, with pressures coming from so many different directions. From the South-East Asian financial meltdown to the spread of ethnic violence across the archipelago, Indonesia has been through some very difficult times. The political situation in Indonesia remains complex and almost opaque to outsiders. In particular, few of us understand the pervasive and multifaceted role of the military in Indonesia. This is not the time to analyse recent Indonesian history, but I need to remind Australians that Indonesia is only part of the way through that transitional period.

Earlier this year it was unthinkable that the Indonesian government would ever enter into an agreement about the future of East Timor. We have now moved far beyond that and, despite complications, there has now been agreement about the presence of United Nations forces in East Timor. In a sign of how far the Indonesian government has travelled on some of these matters, it must be noted that the Indonesian military has only admitted to earlier military casualties in East Timor in the last 48 hours.

We now need to assist the East Timorese in developing a future. I hope that we can take a much longer term view of our involvement in East Timor than we usually do during a humanitarian crisis. I certainly echo Senator Schacht's words. We will be involved, I hope, for a long time and we should begin with that thought in mind. Urgent humanitarian and security needs must be attended to, but we must always be sensitive to the need to build a viable society for the future. Education and training must be at the centre of our response. It is not enough to shower problem situations with donated food and shelter in the short term. Real aid is long term and constructive, rather than diversionary. I think all Democrats and others in this chamber would agree with Senator Schacht's comments that aid should not only be available for the medium to long term; we should think very carefully when we are approaching budget time and lopping funds from our international aid budget, especially in this region. So let us help build the new nation of East Timor with sensitivity and care.

I have acknowledged the role of my party in this debate and that of former Democrat senators such as Colin Mason. I would like to pay tribute to many people who have worked so hard to bring the plight of the East Timorese people to world attention. It is certainly not a comprehensive list, but a number of people have had my admiration in this debate over a number of years. I should acknowledge Senator Bourne, who is sitting at the back of the chamber, and Jim Dunn, who is in the parliament at this very moment. He can be justly proud of his long-term efforts—no doubt now to bring peace as well as autonomy to the region. I also acknowledge the work of people like Andy Alcock, who comes from my home state of South Australia and has been very much involved in the campaign for a free and independent East Timor. He has been working particularly hard in the last couple of weeks to provide support for refugees, to galvanise that wonderful expression of support for the East Timorese people that we have seen in the community and to call for peacekeeping forces in the region. Jim Aubrey has worked in the state of Victoria to bring about freedom and peace in East Timor. I also mention Kath O'Connor, Jefferson Lee, Max Lane, Andrew McNaughtan, Pat Walsh, Vacy Vlazhny and Ken Fry. I have already acknowledged Colin Mason but, with Senator Bourne sitting at the back of the chamber, I feel compelled to do so again. Others include Justice John Dowd, Jill Jollife, Gordon Macintosh, the late Allen Missin, Tom Uren and the old warrior, Paddy Kenneally. There are many others—

talk.start.para: —Julian McGauran.

—I will leave that to you, Senator Ferguson. Most importantly, of course, there are the patient and gracious people of East Timor. We must never remain silent in the face of human rights abuse. It has taken Australia too long to respond to the pain of East Timor. People must always come before profit, and people must come before short-sighted views of national interest. Along with my other Democrat colleagues, I commend the motion before the chamber. We are proud to be associated with this motion for the reasons that I described earlier. Most importantly, I end by expressing my support for those Australians serving with the multinational force and by reiterating our full confidence in them. We look forward to seeing them home safely.

—I rise to give my wholehearted support to the motion relating to East Timor that is before the chamber today. Unfortunately, I am rather sad because, in the speech made by the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives, which was repeated here in the Senate by Senator Faulkner, partisan politics reached another low ebb today. Some of the content of the speech that was made by both of those leaders in each of the chambers was in stark contrast to Senator Lees, who spoke, I thought, with maturity and bipartisan support, wholehearted support, for the decision taken today by the government to move this motion.

speech.para: I listened as carefully as possible to the speech that was made by the Leader of the Opposition, and it was rather two faced. He initially started by saying how important it was that we support the decision taken by the government and then highlighted all the reasons why he believes that that decision should never have been needed to have been made, and I will just make a couple of comments as to why. Mr Beazley attempted to rewrite and revise history and, indeed, his own position in relation to the East Timor situation. He said only last week in a doorstop:
We said at a very early stage, there needed to be an effective peacekeeping operation for a vote. And that if there wasn't certain consequences would flow.
He also said the day before in Adelaide:
If we had had control of the situation we would have made sure that the peacekeeping arrangements matched the threat. This is not hindsight. We were saying it at the time.
I would suggest that Mr Beazley read a bit of recent history because, on 10 February in a doorstop in Canberra, he said:
I would be against the overseas deployment of Australian troops in circumstances where there's not agreement within a community that they wanted a peace keeping role performed.

If that is not a rewrite of history, I do not know what is. One week ago he said, `We would have had peacekeeping arrangements in place,' when fewer than six months ago he said he would be against `the overseas deployment of Australian troops in circumstances where there's not agreement'. He also said on 3 March:
And this requires a very considerable effort on the part of the Indonesians to ensure that that does not occur.
There he is talking about the activities of the armed militia. A little later, on 6 April in Perth, he said:
But the issue of stabilisation on the ground in the first instance is fundamentally a problem for the Indonesian authorities and they need to act.
There is no talk of a peacekeeping force there; there is only talk of what the Indonesians should be doing. A little later on he said:
. . . you could never get a peacekeeping force here in time to do that.
There he is talking about the disarming of the militia. He went on to say:

It has to be done by the Indonesian military and the Indonesian military has to get ownership of this, if that is at all possible. But, in the long term, as the Labor Party has said repeatedly, we don't rule out Australian troops as being part of a peacekeeping operation at all.

That was only in April, and there was nothing about what he said the other day—that they would have had a peacekeeping force in operation. He was asked only as recently as 15 July: is it time to bring in United Nations peacekeepers? What was his answer? He said, `You would want to be guided by the United Nations now on this.'

This is Mr Beazley's attempt today to rewrite his own position and, in other instances, to misrepresent the position of the Prime Minister and the Australian government. Only last Friday Mr Beazley claimed that East Timor was not raised in the Prime Minister's visit to the United States in July, when he said:
That visit clearly required the Prime Minister to discuss the security issues of the region immediately around us and he failed to do so.

That claim is abjectly and totally wrong. If he would care to take note, on 12 July, the Prime Minister spoke at a doorstop interview with Fran Kelly about discussions with President Clinton on Indonesia and East Timor and said that the issue had been discussed at very great length.

The situation today is that Mr Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, has suggested that their position in relation to peacekeeping would have been totally different from the government's. In fact, he has gone against all the things that he said earlier in the year by making a claim to suit his political argument of today, which I thought was very faint-hearted support for the motion that is before us today.

A little over 3½ months ago, I was very fortunate to lead the Australian observer delegation to the Indonesian elections—the first free and democratic elections in Indonesia for over 30 years. That was an experience in itself because I saw the enthusiasm of the Indonesian people who had the opportunity to register a first truly democratic vote. That means that virtually nobody under the age of 60 had ever exercised a truly democratic vote in that country, and it was certainly an experience that I will not forget. We need to remember that that election was brought about because of the overthrow of President Suharto and the promise that was made by President Habibie that elections would be held.

I have to say that, of the 25-member delegation that went to those elections, not one person from any side of politics could fail to be impressed by the effort that the Indonesians put into that election in trying to achieve democracy. Within three months, in that great archipelago of islands—over 10,000 islands stretching for nearly 5,000 kilometres, from halfway up the Malay peninsula to the Irian Jaya boarder with Papua New Guinea—they put in place an election process that required 330,000 polling stations and some 660,000 independent monitors. They put all the framework in place in that time which enabled them to have what I believe—and I am sure that Senator Woodley would agree—was a truly democratic election.

The Indonesians showed, with their enthusiasm for that election, just how important democracy was to the people on the ground. I think a total of nearly 90 per cent of those who registered actually voted, which made Indonesia the third largest democracy in the world, behind India and the United States. We have no doubt, having been there and observed it for a couple of weeks, that it was democratic.

Of course, democracy goes a certain way and it provided the framework for the elec tion. Interpreting the results of that election was always going to be the most difficult part of the process, because in fact nobody got an absolute majority. Unlike Senator Schacht, who said that someone who got 30 per cent of the vote or the majority of the vote should be disappointed if they did not become president, I am quite sure that if there was a coalition of other forces amongst all of the other parties that were there that came up with over 50 per cent, then we would have to recognise that that came about because of the free and open democratic elections that they had.

The overriding issue, even at the time we were there at the elections, related to East Timor. We quite often asked, `What about East Timor?' A number of people asked, `What do you think about East Timor?' It was a totally different situation, because in Indonesia we had an election that was conducted by the Indonesian government; in East Timor we had a referendum presided over by the United Nations. Because it was presided over by the United Nations, it was not accepted in the same way that the election in Indonesia, which was done by the Indonesians themselves, was accepted by the people concerned.

The situation in East Timor was one that I am quite sure was of concern to the Indonesian people. I say this genuinely, because when you have this enormous archipelago of islands and you have unrest in a number of provinces like Aceh, Irian Jaya, Sulawesi, Ambon and then in East Timor, I can understand the concerns of that nation. However, the election was held and the referendum result was overwhelming. The overwhelming result meant that there was always going to be a reaction from the Indonesian people, and I do not think that anybody anticipated the reaction would be as strong as it was, particularly because of the overwhelming result.

It is very important that in the case of East Timor, in the case of Indonesia in general, we do have ongoing, concrete relations and good relations with this large democracy in our area. When you have 210 million people, political stability in South-East Asia is of the utmost importance to both Australia and the whole of the south-east region.

One can only hope that the introduction of the peacekeeping forces, which we are supporting in this motion today, leads to political stability and that all of the unfortunate events that have happened can be remedied in the best way possible. Those Australians serving in this multinational force have our total confidence and they know that the political process in Australia is supporting them all of the way—not just with a few sentences at the start of the Leader of the Opposition's speech but with genuine political support for the process and the fact that they have gone away.

Senator Julian McGauran, sitting on my left, has been a very strong advocate of freedom for the people of East Timor. He has been passionate about it for a number of years. I know the events that are happening in East Timor must be of particular concern to him, because I am quite sure that he would have liked the transition to independence for East Timor to have been a peaceful one. We ought to acknowledge that over a long period of time, certainly since I have been in this chamber, Senator McGauran has been an outspoken supporter of the independence movement in East Timor. I am quite sure that the result of the referendum is one which heartens him greatly.

There are a number of other issues that I would like to raise, but I am aware that there are an enormous number of speakers on the list and if everybody spoke for 20 minutes we would be here until about 2 o'clock in the morning, so I want to give my colleagues an opportunity to speak too.

A lot has been said about the armed forces and the troops that have gone to East Timor. We certainly wish them well and hope that they have a safe return to Australia. Without going overboard about the role of the troops, they are members of the armed forces and this is what they are trained to do. It is not as though we have suddenly plucked a group of people out of the Australian nation and said, `We would like you to make a sacrifice and go to East Timor.' The Army and the people that are involved in East Timor are doing the job that they have been trained to do.

Together with Senator Quirke, who I notice is in the chamber, I was fortunate enough to do a tour of the defence bases in northern Australia in July. We could not fail to be impressed with the readiness of the troops in both the 1st Brigade in Darwin and the 3rd Brigade in Townsville. I am quite sure that those professional soldiers who choose this career and know that events such as this are likely to require them to serve their country overseas—whether in a peacekeeping role or another role—are ready, and I know that they will do the job well. I am sure my colleagues would agree with me in saying that I hope that their presence in East Timor is effective and that they do the job that they are trained to do well. And we certainly hope that they have a safe return to Australia when that job is done.

The real question is: when will that job be finished? I for one believe that it will be an ongoing commitment for a considerable period of time. To actually get East Timor back into a situation where they can protect themselves—when all of the things that have happened and the destruction that has occurred in the last two weeks is put right—is going to take some time. I think we have an obligation to make sure that we do everything that we possibly can to ensure that that rehabilitation and their peaceful occupation of their own country is something which they can look forward to with some confidence. This motion before the chamber has my wholehearted support in every way. I certainly hope it is a long time before we have to pass another such motion in this Senate.

talk.start.para: —Before I start on the main substance of what I want to say here today, I want to wish the men and women of this particular force that has gone into East Timor all the best. Whatever lands they come from, I think we in Australia should thank them for the services that they have embarked upon and will provide to the people of East Timor, especially those Australian soldiers, both men and women, who will be up there for some indeterminate time in the future at considerable risk to themselves. It is a necessary job. I fully support the deployment. I fully support the motion before us here today. For democratic countries to deploy forces overseas is one of those episodes in life that is very, very difficult. And let's not muck around about this: it is a very dangerous peacekeeping operation. I think peacekeeping is a very difficult task. But the task that these people will fulfil, and I think will fulfil well, is a much more difficult task. They deserve our full support and at least from me they are going to get it.

speech.para: A couple of things need to be said about this. There has been some argument here today about the relevance of history and how we got into this situation and whether or not it is worth raking over the coals to see if we can learn some lessons. I think it is necessary to rake over these coals and pull out some of the lessons. I almost thought of starting here today by asking for a moment's silence—silence for all those poor people in East Timor who have been raped, who have been burnt, who have been robbed and who have been mutilated and murdered in some of the worst circumstances, not necessarily in the last 22 days since the ballot but indeed for many, many years—for decades—and not just during the Indonesian occupation of that island.

I must say that, despite the fact that the Australian government has recognised the incorporation of East Timor within Indonesia, I, for one, never have. I must also say that the Portuguese role in that part of the world was not exactly an exemplary one. The Portuguese colonialists were some of the worst. Indeed, in their time up until 1974, Portugal had three or four what could only be described as brush fire guerrilla wars in Angola, Mozambique and, to a much lesser extent, Timor. The people of Timor understand what torture is all about. They had some good teachers—the Portuguese. Then after that they had the Indonesians.

I think we ought to have had a moment's silence too for the bureaucrats in this town in particular and for the politicians, I am sad to say, on both sides of politics who, for one reason or another, either did not want to admit or it did not suit them to admit the real nature of that regime to our north. Since the 1960s, defence and foreign affairs analysts in this country have perceived that the only threat to this country could come through the Indonesian archipelago, not from the Indonesian archipelago, and in fact I agree with that assessment. I think the Indonesian army and the Indonesian state is much more set up for its own internal security—and I will come back to that in a moment. But the perception around this town and around government was that whatever we had to do it was necessary to keep in sweet with the Indonesians because this would be the way any threat to Australia must necessarily travel.

If you take that premise and then take it a bit further, you wind up doing a few other things. Firstly, you start turning a blind eye to a few things that are going on up there. There has been an awful lot of that in several regimes in this country and amongst bureaucrats. Lately we have been finding out that intelligence assessments, even from quite lowly levels within the service, were being doctored as well. In fact one of the reasons the Americans are not too happy with the present Howard government in this country is that they are not too keen on doctored intelligence: they prefer to know the bad news.

There has been a progression of people in this country who did not want to know the bad news, did not want to believe in it. With wishful thinking they had hoped that Portuguese East Timor would slide into the Republic of Indonesia and the problem would go away. In a sense, that possibly could have happened. If the Indonesians had not gone in there with the brutality that they did, if they had not gone in there and fought a 25-year war, if they had not gone in there and treated these people the way that they did, it may have just worked out. I think as recently as maybe 18 months or two years ago, despite the fact that something like 20 per cent or more of the population of this province had died violently as a result of these military escapades since 1975, it still could have been incorporated into broader Indonesia. I think that, had the Suharto regime offered autonomy on the conditions that Habibie did, the East Timorese probably would have grasped at it, but it was not offered to them.

One of the problems in this whole debate is the misunderstanding of the nature of the Indonesian regime itself. Indonesia is not this homogenised group of people that we in this country anticipate or expect. It is a series of provinces. We are now starting to see the Republic of Indonesia as being Java in the centre—the powerhouse, the largest populous island—with a series of other provinces which, in varying degrees, have some level of autonomy but not very much. In essence, Indonesia is a Javanese empire. As a result of that, any attempt to have a situation where one of the provinces is demanding autonomy and independence is something that is feared in Jakarta. It is feared in the real power structure of Indonesia, because the real power structure of Indonesia is in the military and in the elites that dominate that country.

I sincerely hope that the signs which are starting to come of Indonesia getting its democratic act together will continue. I sincerely hope that all those bureaucrats who said that we do not understand Indonesia and that it is really a state in transition are right. I think that, in a sense, belatedly, they probably will be. Once the people of Indonesia have had a taste of some democratic government—and indeed they have now—they are probably going to want more. It is going to be very difficult for the new regime to be stood over by the military like this one has, but I do not think we should have any illusions about the role Australia has played since 1974. Our assumption that this province would slide straight into Indonesia and that that would suit us in this end of the world was fanciful, and fanciful in the extreme. The one group of people who should have been consulted about this and were not were the East Timorese. They have made it crystal clear that they see a very different future.

We also need to look at the lessons from the immediate past days, weeks and months. Again, I do not think it is a very good story. We turned a blind eye for 24 or 25 years to what was going on in Indonesia because we thought we always had a spin on it. Even when a couple of hundred people were shot in a cemetery in the worst circumstances you can imagine, Australians were running around the place saying, `Well, look, it could've been worse,' or `We don't know the extent of the damage,' or `Look, the army's a bit out of control,' and all the rest of it. We just do not understand how armies operate in provinces where they have to garrison against the will of the population. You can pull out a dozen societies where this has happened in the last 50 years, and it is always the same story—military reprisals, military oppression, torture. The whole scene is all there. It should have been obvious to blind Freddy what was going to happen after the last six to eight months. It was a bomb waiting for someone to light the fuse.

I do not know how seriously I can take politicians who tell me that they thought there might be a little bit of trouble after the vote came down but that, at the end of the day, the Indonesian military had promised that they were going to look after the place, like they have looked after it for the last 25 years. The militia—and the evidence is now coming out quite clearly—were armed, financed and directed by the Indonesian military, by TNI or its predecessor, ABRI. It takes a lot to dispossess 300,000 people. It takes an enormous effort to shoot 20 per cent of the population of a whole province. It takes proper organisation in a country that does not have much, other than the Indonesian military, to be able to do the wanton destruction that has been done there in recent times.

There are a couple of things about this for which we in Australia ought to hang our heads low. Firstly, I refer to the assessments that came in which were doctored and the broad belief that somehow or other these problems were not going to lead to the most horrific violence and, in the words of Mr Downer, a holocaust. Indeed, I find it somewhat surprising that we did not put the same pressure on the Indonesians three or four months before the vote. I heard today that the present government's spin on that is that there would not have been a vote and there was no way that the international community was going to be allowed to put a peacekeeping force into East Timor. I do not know whom that is meant to influence, but it does not do much for me. The reason it does not do much for me is this: the Indonesians would not have allowed this force in there today—it would not be in there now—if the Americans had not picked up the phone and told the Indonesian government what was going to happen if they did not do it. The reality of this is that this government has been fiddling around while East Timor has been burning. What is more, while the people who were going to burn it were openly threatening with the matches and the fuel that they were going to chuck all over the place, very little was being done here in Australia.

I am grateful that the military in Australia took this exercise seriously. Indeed, when Senator Ferguson, myself and a couple of other people visited the bases to the north of Australia, it was quite clear that our forces were preparing for this particular peacekeeping mission. I am proud of what I saw up there. I hope I will be proud of the result. I am sure I will be. But one of the worst episodes in this whole sorry saga has been the last so many months when we could have picked the phone up and properly briefed the Americans about what was going to happen in East Timor and we did not do it.

It was another example of wishful thinking that somehow or other the regime up there would not sanction and would not do the terrible things that we have seen in the last few weeks. What was that based on? What assessment or premise could anyone use to come to that conclusion? There have been 24 years of brutal, violent repression and, all of a sudden, there were going to be a few flowers of spring. It did not happen and it was never going to happen. Only people here in Canberra—the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Prime Minister and I presume all of the bureaucrats at the top end—thought so. Somehow or other they do not want to deal with the East Timor problem because they like a nice stable world, where things go quietly for them and we can spend less on defence. We all agree with that. But at the end of the day, the stability we have had at this end of the world for 50 years has gone. That world is not here anymore. It was not here three or four months ago.

You hear about war crimes trials and this, that and the other. I think there will probably be some war crimes trials. There certainly ought to be in this exercise. How that will unfold I do not know, but I can tell you that there are a few blind Freddies around this town who ought to be called to account as well. They ought to have known. If they did not know, they have no IQs and should not be in the jobs they are in. At least 7,000 to 10,000 people are no longer with us in that poor province because we did not take the game seriously, and we did not take it seriously early enough. I can thoroughly understand our allies being angry with us. They see a group of people who want just to bury their heads in the sand. There are ostriches all over this world that are trying to find out how the Prime Minister and the foreign minister can bury their heads so deeply in the sand.

What has happened here this year is an absolute disgrace. Although we are here today very importantly debating a resolution of support for our soldiers, I think we have to draw the lessons out of this whole exercise. We have to confront bad news when we see it, tell our allies and give them frank and proper assessments. If we are not up to the job, we ought to put people in there who are. The other lesson in this whole episode is that, while it might be convenient and it might suit—to put it in nice words—our geopolitical ambitions at this end of the world to say that colonies like ex-Portuguese East Timor can just be slipped into Indonesia because that is going to be cheaper for us—and it certainly would have been—I am afraid that what is easy for us is not necessarily what is right.

I want to finish off today by saying that I get a tremendous boost from the people of East Timor. They were shot at and beaten by the Portuguese. They were shot at even more and beaten even harder by the Indonesians. They got up and decided that after a couple of hundred years of this they had had enough, so they were going to risk their hand at a vote. I think they knew what was coming. They voted accordingly that they had had enough so that their children in the future could pick the place up. It is not a very wealthy place. I am told that the average per capita income there is about $US50 a year. They did not have very much to start with, but they knew that, with one last titanic struggle, they could get free and make some determinations for themselves in the future. I admire them for that, because there were not too many people standing there. There are a few more now. These people have been sold out and sold down the river for many years. For them to get up at the end of the day and say, `We've had enough of this. We're going to stand up for ourselves,' is something that I can be proud of.

talk.start.para: —In this debate today about the situation in East Timor, I want to begin where Senator Ferguson was in his speech and to simply refer to the fact that I was part of the delegation which monitored the general election in Indonesia in June. I support what he said. Everywhere we went, the Indonesian people were obviously celebrating the fact that they were voting for democracy. I want to underline what Senator Ferguson, as the leader of that delegation, said. We were received with open arms by the ordinary people of Indonesia, we were feted and we were seen as the guarantee of their ability to vote in that general election.

speech.para: So what has happened? In answering that question, I want to make a very clear distinction between the ordinary people of Indonesia and the Indonesian military and elite leadership. We must make that distinction if, in the future, we are going to restore our relationship with the people of Indonesia. I certainly hope that we can restore that relationship. While I acknowledge the contribution that our own forces will make in East Timor, that contribution has been well covered today by other people, so I am not going to dwell on it at any great length. The Democrats certainly support our soldiers. I pray that they will not only accomplish their mission but eventually return safely to these shores.

I want to remind the Senate that, as Australians, we contributed to the training of the Indonesian army for many years in this country, knowing—as Senator Quirke has very eloquently pointed out—not only what the Indonesian army was doing in its own country but that in our own region most defence forces are not put in place to defend their nations against external threat. Most of the so-called defence forces in our region are in fact used to oppress their own people.

I want to remind the Senate who supplied the arms for the Indonesian army. The largest supplier of arms in the world today is the United States. Forty per cent of the total arms sales to the developing world has been supplied by the United States, and the second largest supplier of arms to developing countries is the United Kingdom, which supplies 25 per cent of arms to developing nations. When we are talking about military contributions, we ought not to forget these facts. We also ought to learn from them.

I want to recognise a young man—he is younger than me—who is a member of the Brisbane Catholic worker community, a man by the name of Jim Dowling. For many years he has protested publicly about the training of Indonesian soldiers in Australia and about other issues of social justice. He is today in prison for those protests. He was arrested last year at the Canungra Army Base for protesting there about the training of Indonesian soldiers in Australia. He is tonight in jail in Brisbane for those protests, and he is on a hunger strike. I want the Senate to understand what it has cost some people in Australia to continue this witnessing.

I also want to place on record the contribution of the churches and individual Christians to the people of Indonesia over many years. I admit that in many countries the contribution of the churches is not always an even-handed one or even one that we could commend. But for the people of East Timor, and generally for the people of Indonesia, both the Roman Catholic and Protestant churches have made significant contributions. I recognise here just a few people whom I have met and who have informed me about the situation. It is worth putting their names on the record even though, in doing that, I leave out many more who should be mentioned. We all recognise the contribution of Bishop Belo and of many Roman Catholic priests and religious sisters in East Timor. They have paid for that contribution with their lives. I recognise people like Helene and Gerry Van Klinken, who are friends of mine; Professor James Haire, who was a missionary in Indonesia for many years and who has been working closely with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade because of his contacts there; Father Gerry Hefferan, who is working in Darwin at the moment with the refugees from East Timor; Brother Paul Toon, who set up the East Timor office in Brisbane; and Reverend John Barr from my own church. They have helped me to understand the situation. Some of the information which I put on the record now comes from them.

They all spoke about the situation in West Timor, and it is important that we recognise that situation. I am told that there are now about 30 camps in West Timor with upwards of 200,000 refugees. Those refugees are experiencing many problems, especially if they are related to pro-independence activists. The food in many of those camps is extremely restricted, particularly for those who are recognised as being pro-independence. Many of the men are missing, and those camps are still under threat from the militia and the Indonesian military—particularly those who are now fleeing East Timor themselves, who are a threat to the people in the border regions. Little has been done to disarm the militia in West Timor, and they are presenting a very serious threat.

The UNHCR has told us that safe haven visas are being blocked by the Indonesian government and military for third-party nationals and also for a number of religious sisters who have applied for these visas. In one camp there are eight toilets for 12,000 refugees and in another camp five toilets for 9,000 refugees. Many do not have beds and are sleeping on the ground. The water supply in many of the camps is contaminated. I understand the provincial government in West Timor is trying to get a grip on the situation. There are some very good people amongst the West Timorese who are desperately trying to help the refugees in their midst. But the militia still seems to have a free rein to continue its terrorist activities.

Another issue I wanted to address was the issue of Muslims versus Christians. There are some Christians in Australia who very simplistically seem to think this is what the whole conflict is about. This is a very simplistic analysis and is simply not true—although some information has come to me that the military have tried to use traditional tensions between Muslims and Christians to make the situation worse. There is information that some Muslims from Ambon have been brought to East Timor to make up at least some of the militia. The National Council of Churches of Indonesia reported after a visit to Dili that one militia leader admitted being transported from Ambon to Dili along with five others in order to continue the terrorism in East Timor. However, the military have not only used Muslims against Christians; there is plenty of information that the Indonesian military set up at least one fundamentalist Protestant Church in Dili to try to counteract the influence of the Roman Catholic Church in East Timor.

So it is far too simplistic to describe this as simply a religious conflict between Muslim and Christian, or between Protestants and Catholics for that matter. It is a dreadful situation and the Indonesian military must bear the brunt of the blame for what has been going on. Not only is it not a religious conflict, but also most of the Protestant clergy in East Timor—as with the Roman Catholic clergy—have been supporters of the independence movement and some of them have died as well.

Although I am conscious of the time, I will tell the story of Reverend Fransisco as told by Joy Balazo from the Uniting Church. Reverend Francisco was shot only a few days ago, and I will read a little of the story. `Please tell people what is happening to us,' were the last words of Reverend Fransisco de Vasconcelos Ximenes. That is what he told a staff member before they parted ways after martial law was declared in East Timor on 7 September.

The Indonesian military sponsored militia shot Fransisco only two days later as he led his people to the safety of the Timorese mountains. He was the General Secretary of the Christian Church in East Timor and in the absence of the moderator, who was taking refuge overseas in fear for his life, Fransisco was also the acting moderator of this church, which has approximately 30,000 members, both Indonesian and East Timorese. I simply wanted to put the lie to the analysis by some people in Australia that at the heart of this is some kind of religious conflict.

Another issue I want to raise in my contribution is the issue of Indonesians in Australia. There are a number of stories of the fear Indonesians are experiencing in our country. That in itself gives us pause as we begin to understand how they feel about our attitude to them. We must ensure that those who are resident here are not treated as perhaps some Australians might fear they would be treated in Indonesia. I know of some Indonesian families in Brisbane who have packed all their belongings and are ready to flee Australia because they fear what might happen to them. I am not going to tell you their names, but they are known to us.

An Indonesian lecturer at Sydney University who has been there for many years has received death threats from within Australia. Indonesian students at Griffith University conducted a friendship day last weekend. They were very apprehensive about this, but I am pleased to say that the friendship day went off very well. It is good that, along with the stories we might hear about Indonesian people in Australia who are fearful, there are also people who are able to offer their friendship and break through those walls of fear. Let us ensure that those kinds of things do not continue in our nation through any kind of jingoism that might be present within our midst.

To save time, I would like to incorporate a letter, which I have shown to the various whips, which I received from the Uniting Church just this afternoon. It will put on the record some of the things which are happening in West Timor particularly, and it does make some good suggestions about what should happen. I believe it would be helpful for the Senate to have this letter on the record, so I seek leave to incorporate it.
Leave granted.
The Uniting Church in Australia
Unity and International Mission
Level 5, Piccadilly Court
222 Pitt Street
Sydney
(PO Box A2206, Sydney South, NSW 1235)

21 September 1999
Senator John Woodley
Parliament House
Canberra
Pages: 2
Dear John

Warm greetings from the Uniting Church National Assembly. I have just been in contact with Kupang, West Timor. My contact is Rev Dr Tom Therik who is the Rector of Artha Wacana Christian University. He is co-ordinating a program to provide relief to displaced people from East Timor who are residing in refugee locations in West Timor. He is also involved in providing a network to protect East Timorese who are being hunted down and killed by the militia. I understand Tom will be interviewed tonight on the ABC `Lateline' program.
Tom mentioned a number of points:

(a) Pro-autonomy militia are still searching for people who are suspected as being pro-independent. Tom says this action must be stopped and he calls on the Indonesian government to recognise and protect the right of East Timorese people to be pro-independent.

(b) The border area of West Timor with East Timor (Belu Regency) has to be demilitarised as there is no indication that an independent East Timor or the multinational peace keeping force will present a threat to the people of West Timor.
(c) A war crimes tribunal must be established to deal with the crimes against humanity arising out of the conflict in East and West Timor.

(d) A process has to be developed where displaced East Timorese now in West Timor are able to make a decision to return to East Timor if they wish to. This must be an independent process which is free of intimidation. Tom suggest such a process should be facilitated by Indonesian and foreign personnel. Under the current situation, people who say they wish to return to East Timor are considered to be pro-independent and their lives are at significant risk.
(e) International attention must also focus on West Timor. `A resolution to the East Timor issue cannot be solved without dealing with West Timor' (quote from Tom Therik).

I also just spoke with Jamie Isbister from World Church Service (National Council of Churches). Jamie has just returned from Indonesia. He was in West Timor last week. Gam raised the following issues:
(a) The UNHCR must be able to establish a presence in Kupang and Atambua (border region of West Timor). Safe access to refugees must be given to UNHCR personnel.
(b) Militia must be removed from all refugee locations and all militia must be disarmed in West Timor.

(c) It is important to recognise the role of the church in West Timor as it provides a pivotal role in supporting and protecting East Timorese refugees. Major aid organisations and NGOs are not able to operate in West Timor. The church has an extensive network at the grassroots level and is able to be effective in assisting East Timorese people.

(d) Requests that the Australian government work in consultation with the church both in Indonesia and Australia. The National Council of Churches and the Uniting Church in Australia maintain close contacts with church workers on the ground in Indonesia. It is important that opportunities be provided to the NCCA and UCA for extensive consultation with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and AusAID.
Thank you for this opportunity to provide you with information. We are deeply committed to the people of East Timor and Indonesia and we greatly appreciate your assistance with these matters.
Yours sincerely
Rev John Barr
Indonesia Area Secretary
Uniting Church in Australia National Assembly

talk.start.para: —I want to close my contribution tonight by reading part of a lament for Timor which was written by Laurel Barr. The lament is a very telling one. It was used at a service of worship last Friday at the United Theological College in Sydney. It is a lament or, if you like, a prayer for the people of East Timor. The lament closes with these words, and I think they make a fitting ending to what I have said:

speech.para: Save them in their distress. Move in the hearts of the evildoers. Stay the hands of those who would kill.
Beat the machetes into ploughshares.
The Spirit of life flickers in the darkness.
May a flame of compassion and hope burn on the island of Timor again.

talk.start.para: —Yesterday's deployment of Australian troops in the UN multinational peacekeeping force, INTERFET, to East Timor marks a turning point for Australia in more ways than one. It marks a line in the sand in our relations with one of our nearest neighbours and some of our oldest allies. It challenges our strength as a military force as we engage in real-life armed service on foreign soil for the first time in more than 30 years.

speech.para: But there is also the opportunity for Australia to reaffirm its position as one of the leading diplomatic, political, economic and military powers of South-East Asia through the restoration of calm in the eastern provinces of Indonesia and the subsequent establishment of an independent East Timor. In the meantime, the situation remains tense. Australia will need to instigate a delicate balance between using whatever force is necessary to rid the region of malevolent violence and unrest and diplomacy as Australia attempts to restore fledgling relations between a fledgling independent East Timor and Indonesia, between Indonesia and Australia, and between Australia and one of its oldest Pacific allies, the United States, whose reluctance to fully support a UN multinational peacekeeping force with ground troops caused strain and comment.

Despite almost 78.5 per cent of East Timor's 450,000-strong electorate voting in favour of independence on 30 August, the following period unleashed untold horrors by militias and their military supporters which we saw on our television screens on a nightly basis and which branded itself into our collective consciousness. The will of the East Timorese people must be allowed to take effect.

As Australians, we have made clear our protest at the persecution of the East Timorese people, particularly in respect of East Timor's geographic, cultural and economic importance. I know that I speak for all Australians when I restate in the strongest terms my earlier condemnation of the murders, forced removals and other acts of violence perpetrated against the East Timorese people.
At the National Party Federal Council on 11 September, I moved a successful motion in strong terms. Let me quote it:
