This Federal Council of the National Party of Australia, in acknowledgment of the debt of gratitude felt by many Australian families for life-saving assistance rendered by the people of East Timor to Australian personnel during World War II and the validity of the 30 August 1999 vote on self-determination in East Timor, as verified by Australian and other UN observer delegations:
(a) deplores in the strongest terms the murders, forced removals and other acts of violence perpetrated against the people of East Timor;
(b) applauds the courage and determination of the Australian Federal Police, UN and aid personnel and all others of good will in Indonesia in their efforts to alleviate the humanitarian emergency;
(c) endorses the continuing effort of the federal government in seeking an international resolution to the crisis;
(d) calls on Indonesian authorities to take urgent and immediate action to restore civil order and secure the safety of all citizens in East Timor;

(e) expresses its disappointment at the reluctance of the United States of America, as a long-term Pacific ally, to fully support a UN peacekeeping force, and urges the US Congress to become closely associated with an international solution; and
(f) requires the Australian government to maintain at an appropriate stage of readiness a force of arms sufficient to play a significant and effective partnership peacekeeping role in East Timor.

The Indonesian government and its military have an obligation to all people of Indonesia as it is presently constituted. They must ensure that this obligation is met by ensuring the safety of all Timorese, irrespective of their politics, ethnicity or home province. This obligation is also recognised in the Security Council resolution authorising the INTERFET deployment to the territory.

Australia's bond with the East Timorese people has never been so apparent as it is now. I think it is important that we do not lose sight of the human face of this conflict and the lasting impact that it will no doubt have on the East Timorese and their friends and relatives in Australia, particularly in Darwin. I spoke last night in the Senate on the support given so generously by so many volunteers and public servants. We only to have look at the ties between the countries to understand just how close to home the atrocities are. As a Territorian, I am particularly conscious of them and the evil and criminal actions that were so patently obvious. Darwin is just 730 kilometres from Dili. Darwin is physically closer to Indonesia's capital, Jakarta, than it is to Australia's own national capital, Canberra. Similarly, our ties in terms of friendship and culture with both Indonesia and East Timor span back to World War II, when a debt of gratitude was expressed by many Australian families for life-saving assistance rendered by the people of East Timor in particular to Australian personnel.

Following the Asian financial crisis and the end of the Suharto era in May 1998, rapid social, political and economic change has occurred throughout Indonesia. Coincidentally, the Northern Territory in particular has spent the last 10 years developing relationships with the various players in the region. With those relationships comes responsibility in terms of commerce, health, education and, of course, maintaining a secure, peaceful neighbourhood for all concerned. Although Australia is now dealing with arguably the most intense military situation in decades, the openness of those past discussions now stands us in good stead for the future. It provides the hopeful basis for dealing with human rights abuses and maintaining relationships of integrity with people demonstrating goodwill.

The lasting effects of the current conflict will be apparent on both sides of the Timor Sea for decades and, most likely, for generations to come. East Timorese people will face real social problems in the future—re-establishing homes, educational facilities, commercial enterprises and even the most basic infrastructure we take for granted here in Australia. Very large numbers of East Timorese have been displaced. Australia, and the Northern Territory in particular, will be heavily involved in aid and assistance to the East Timorese for years to come.

It is on that point that Australia must always maintain at the forefront of its thinking the reality that we are dealing with real people with real lives in our neighbourhood. We have to remember that an incorrect decision could cost many lives, whilst the correct one could save many and set up a positive future for the East Timorese. Australia has a real social responsibility to do right and to be right on human rights. We are now not only in a peacekeeping mission but in a humanitarian mission as well. Australian troops can be doubly proud of the fact that not only are they doing what is right for the Timorese people by maintaining the peace and assisting with getting the independence process back on track but also they are part of a vital humanitarian effort that will save thousands of lives.

Even before the current events unfolded, Australia's defence forces, foreign affairs and intelligence officers had been instrumental in preparing a robust response to the potential for the collapse of law and order in East Timor. Australia, through the federal and Northern Territory governments and the Australian Defence Force, from as early as March of this year, has planned for the deployment of troops and equipment to strategic posts in Darwin in anticipation of a peacekeeping role. In April this year the Northern Territory government published a capability statement of the Territory's potential for support for East Timor. That planning was both prudent and prescient.

Darwin, currently Australia's strategic centre, is now set to become the focal point of the international community as it greets the spotlight as the main military base for the INTERFET force. Darwin, with its provision of defence support to incoming troops as well as its immediate and willing response to the plight of the East Timorese refugees, has showcased the range and efficiency of its services and the crucial support role it will play in the next few months for Australian and international troops in the lead-up to the United Nations peacekeeping role.

Although I acknowledge the skill and the preparatory work put in by the Australian Defence Force in the Northern Territory in past months, make no mistake: Australia's defence forces face a real risk of serious casualty. However, I note that East Timor's resistance leader, Xanana Gusmao, has thanked Australian soldiers for their presence on the ground, while other groups have pledged assistance to our troops. There is also the incredible support garnered from the 14 or so other countries working in partnership as INTERFET. But with risk comes opportunity—the opportunity for Australia to make another historic contribution to the peaceful transition to an independent East Timor and to do the right thing in humanitarian terms. The impact of this deployment has obviously been great on the Northern Territory community. But while it is sad to see our troops leave the safety of home, it is heartening to see the outpouring of support and gratitude for those who have become such an integral part of Northern Territory life so quickly. It is imperative that this cooperation and goodwill continue.

Australia, Indonesia, Portugal, the United Nations and, most importantly, the people of East Timor must look to the future. There must be a long-term solution that will promote stability and promise an economic future for the region. Consultation and mediation between all players involved are vital. In the immediate future we will need to see the reconstruction of infrastructure. Already there has been a disruption of services which will need to be restored to ensure accessibility to important services within the various regions of East Timor. Recent events have had the potential to disrupt the momentum and the integrity of the relationship between Australia and Indonesia. Nevertheless, the Australian-Indonesian relationship is a long and close one that will stand the test of time. The questions Australia needs to ask—ones well worthy of reflection—are: firstly, how do we restore peaceful relations with Indonesia; secondly, what are the longer term issues Australia will need to face in its peacekeeping role; and, thirdly, what is our commitment to the new independent state of East Timor? In the wider sphere of Indonesian nationalism, the November parliament will provide a new slant on the picture. Very obviously, once the new parliament is constituted, a new flavour of government will come to the fore, providing an opportune time for Australia to reaffirm that the Javanese administration, and its strongarm military tactics, will no longer be acceptable.

Australia needs to guarantee that its influence and responsibility come to bear to ensure that the Indonesian puppet-masters do not have the upper hand in any new democratisation within Indonesia. Australia must play a visionary role that underpins its commitment to human rights and restores the peaceful atmosphere in our immediate neighbourhood. As a senator for the Northern Territory—the most crucially important strategic centre in this matter—I trust that the efforts to restore peace and security by military action, under the leadership of the United Nations and Australia, will be successful and will ensure the climate for the necessary reconciliation to which we all aspire.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in this debate today because I have had quite an interest over a long time in what has been happening in Indonesia and in particular in East Timor. As chair of the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee, I have been involved in an inquiry into East Timor. Also, through the estimates process I have been involved in placing many questions on the record on East Timor and the operations of Indonesia within East Timor.

speech.para: One of the things that surprised me today was the fact that there has been a call from some of the people on the other side for bipartisanship. I believe in bipartisanship. I just wish I could have had that bipartisanship shown to me during the estimates process on 9 June, when the government did everything that they could to try and shut me down and stop me from asking some very incisive questions on the issue of East Timor. So let us get our facts straight. If you look at the estimates of 11 February, 5 May and 8 June this year, you will see that I had great cooperation from the government in questioning people from the Department of Defence and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Come 9 June, things were starting to get hot and the government could not handle the issue. Every attempt was made to gag me, but I persisted in asking a range of questions at that time. So much for bipartisanship—but I believe it is an issue that should be approached in a bipartisan way. It is an issue that affects us in a great way in that we have 210 million people on our doorstep in the large nation of Indonesia and we have 800,000 people or thereabouts in East Timor, who are struggling for the very threadbare necessities of life.

One should not underestimate how these people have been torn apart, ripped asunder, by the pillage and the carnage that has taken place at the hands of the TNI and the militia in East Timor. No-one should have any doubt whatsoever of the fact that these people have lost every trace, every vestige, of what we would consider basic human decency. It will be extremely hard to rebuild in that environment, particularly when you take into consideration that these people voted in favour of becoming an independent state or nation in their own right only on 30 August. But if you look at the 5 May agreement that was signed by the Indonesian Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Portuguese Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Secretary-General of the United Nations, article 7 gives them some hope of the prospect of a peaceful transition after their vote. Article 7 says:

During the interim period between the conclusion of the popular consultation and the start of the implementation of either option, the parties request the Secretary-General to maintain an adequate United Nations presence in East Timor.

We went in there as Australians and told them that we would do everything within our power to see that this was maintained. They believed not only us but others that they would be delivered a peaceful environment in which to live after their striving for independence over a long period. But, of course, the TNI had other things in mind for these people. The TNI had premeditated and well-planned the looting, the carnage and the pillaging that took place within one week of that vote having taken place. It was something that was not just thought up in the week prior to the vote for independence; it was something that—from the evidence that I have heard through an inquiry that I am involved in— was well and truly in place over a long period.

The fact that we failed to protect these people, the fact that we failed to put sufficient pressure on the United Nations and on the United States—who are the big players in the field—and the fact that we failed to deliver to these people a safe environment post the ballot is something that we will have to live with and regret for at long time to come.

The fact is that we are not the major player that we are trying to make ourselves out to be. There is no doubt in my mind and in the minds of many of the experts that have appeared and given evidence before the committee that I am involved in—though I do not claim to speak on behalf of that committee tonight—that it was quite clear that, unless there had been US involvement early, the Indonesians were not going to respond purely and simply to our pleas. We needed the United States to be the trigger, the party with the big clout to get in there and make the Indonesian military—and, to a lesser extent, civilians—respond in a positive way.

Of course, we were found to be wanting. We were found to be lacking in that area. Whilst the United States are playing a reasonably low-key role at this stage, one can only hope that they will continue to apply pressure and to keep a presence in this whole issue. Without their force, one could only see that the whole situation in East Timor could go completely wrong in the future.

Having said that, some very positive people have appeared before the committee that I am involved in. One notable group was Paxiquest, who are professional conflict resolution consultants. Whilst they may well earn a dollar out of it—and that is their business—they did put forward to us two important points. Firstly, that all the parties in the conflict must sit around and resolve the conflict together. You cannot exclude anyone, and that is what was wrong with the 5 May agreement. The 5 May agreement excluded one very important group—the East Timorese themselves. You cannot have conflict resolution unless you have the people involved in the conflict actually there.

We now have a real need to have all of those who are involved in the conflict in East Timor involved in the process of resolving the conflict that exists, leading to the proper establishment of the rule of law. It was put to us by Paxiquest that, if this is not carried out in the proper way, then we will undoubtedly have an ongoing saga of problems in East Timor for years to come. If the processes of conflict resolution and the establishment of the rule of law are not put in place properly in the first instance, then the long-term hopes for a peaceful and emerging independent East Timor are indeed very doubtful.

The other point that I want to make is that there is a real need to secure the border with West Timor. Whilst I have not been to Timor, it has become quite clear to me that the border is very blurred. Of course, this could allow for easy movement between West and East Timor of those militias who have sought sanctuary so far in the West Timor province of Indonesia. One can only hope that sufficient pressure is applied to ensure that that border is secured, so that we do not have unnecessary incursions occurring across the line. Of course, one takes for granted that one will see those people who have been forcibly removed from East Timor repatriated to their homes in East Timor to live a reasonable lifestyle.

The other thing—and with so many speakers to follow I am conscious of the time—that is of concern to me is the decision by this government in its early days to wind back the operation of Radio Australia and, in particular, to cut back the operation by shutting down the antenna at Cox Peninsula near Darwin. Undoubtedly, that was clearly something that was completely misplaced. If one had Radio Australia operating at Cox Peninsula, then a different view may well have been projected into Indonesia and also into East Timor.

I do not believe that the people of Indonesia are understanding what ordinary Australians are saying in this debate. One must understand that most Australians are not anti-Indonesian. They are very much anti the antics of the TNI. There is no doubt about that. They are very condemnatory of what the TNI, the Indonesian military, have done but not of the Indonesian people. Yet that view does not seem to have got out to the ordinary people in Indonesia.

Also, if we had a proactive Radio Australia—which was always respected for its independence, not being an arm of government, like so many broadcasters overseas are, such as Voice of America and the likes—this vehicle could have been used quite successfully to put into the East Timorese environment much about what was really happening. But, of course, that was cut off with the government's decision back in 1996 to close down or severely curtail the operation of Radio Australia, particularly through the Cox Peninsula.

The only other two things I want to mention go to the issue of our relations with Indonesia. As I have said, the problem is not with the Indonesian people. The problem is with the TNI. It has to be clearly understood that we need to have good relations with Indonesia. I know that Senator Payne probably would agree with me that the evidence we have heard in the committee was that there is a need for good relations between Australia and Indonesia. It is absolutely vital for our future and also for the future of East Timor. What we need to see is the development of good relationships not only between Australia and East Timor and between Australia and Indonesia but also between East Timor and Indonesia. Of course, that is a Herculean task in its own right. No-one should downplay the need for good relations with our near neighbours.

The last point that I want to make is about a concern that I have in respect of aid. I am concerned that, when it comes to putting aid into East Timor, there will not be the proper coordination and prioritising of aid to be given. There are many people out there who are very well-intentioned and have a great desire to put aid into East Timor; but I have a fear, from some of the evidence that I have heard, that the aid may not be prioritised in the right way or that it may not be the right aid in the first place. So I make a plea that, if we are going to help the Timorese people once we have established a safe environment, we give them prioritised aid and the right aid, so that we do not have aid agencies and many good organisations falling over themselves and duplicating and wasting the aid, which will be very precious indeed within East Timor.

Last but not least I want to say that, like many others, I wish our defence forces all the best in their involvement in East Timor. They have not gone in as a peacekeeping force, as a number of people think. They are there for peace enforcement and peacemaking. There is no doubt that there is quite a difference between peace enforcement, peacemaking and peacekeeping. They have gone into a hostile environment, and I feel for their families. I know that they are well trained and capable people in their own right, and they deserve the support of all of us in the hard task that they have undertaken. They should not in any way feel that they will not be welcomed back to these shores. I think that that message needs to be said over and over again, because these people are going in to help, as I said, a nation that has been stripped of everything—a group of people, many of whom have not only lost their dignity but had every last vestige and trace of humanity taken away from them. So the peace enforcement defence personnel who are there currently have a hard task initially to establish a safe environment but an even harder task to then ensure that peacekeeping can be maintained for the long period that is going to be required to bring about a revitalisation of the East Timor nation so that the people there can live with the respect and dignity that we take for granted.

talk.start.para: —The last few months have demonstrated to us just how vulnerable aid workers are when they operate in war zones. Steve Pratt and his colleagues are testimony to the way that hostile governments can bite the hands that feed them. We go into East Timor this week with a grave fear that our soldiers and our aid workers will be likely to be singled out for attack by the militia and the military as they try to assist the very people who have been terrorised by that group. We are all gravely fearful for the estimated 150,000 people who have disappeared or who have been forcibly removed from East Timor. Militias who have operated in East Timor are perpetuating their terror in West Timor, away from any protection that the Australian troops might provide.

speech.para: I think we have good reason to fear for the lives of those people. Reliable sources say that the militias are searching for independence supporters and that they have taken men and boys from camps to unknown fates. Apparently they are now being asked to indicate to local authorities whether they wish to return to East Timor or to become permanent transmigrants in West Timor. Of course, in these circumstances, saying that they want to return would be putting themselves at some risk. ACFOA reminded us this week that there is no safe access to West Timor for international aid workers, who have been harassed and threatened by militias. Local Indonesian, church and non-government organisations are completely overwhelmed by the huge number of people in extreme need. ACFOA says:

The militias are also terrorising local West Timorese residents. They roam the streets, pillage shops and market stores. Local NGOs and church groups hold grave concerns that serious violence may break out in West Timor.

I want to take the opportunity tonight to take a few steps back and to talk about Australia's overseas aid programs and the situation for East Timor. Some months ago, Jose Ramos Horta explained to me why it was that East Timor was not ready for independence. He said that the country had almost no professionally trained people; they had no airline pilots at all, very few teachers and very few professional people of one sort or the other. He said that the level of schooling was very low and there were very few opportunities for East Timorese to go on to university.

In 1998-99 Australia provided just $7 million in direct assistance to East Timor. We have provided only $45 million between 1980 and 1999—that is almost 20 years. Of that, $13 million has been given in emergency and humanitarian aid, $21 million in water supply and health projects, $8.9 million in agriculture and just $400,000 in education projects. Only l2 East Timorese students have been given postgraduate scholarships to study in Australia in subjects such as economics, public sector management and agriculture. The population of East Timor was estimated to be 906,000 in 1997. Our aid last year works out to be just $7 for each East Timorese. I would like to pose the question: what exactly is the Australian economy gaining in terms of oil from the Timor Gap? I suspect it to be much more than $7 million a year.

Three-quarters of the formal economy of East Timor is controlled by non East Timorese. Non East Timorese occupy the majority of senior administrative, technical and professional positions. Let us look at why this is the case and let us look at the education system in East Timor. Fifty-six per cent of women and 39 per cent of men in East Timor are illiterate. In 1983 the illiteracy rate was 80 per cent. In 1997 only a quarter of the population over 10 years of age had completed primary school, seven per cent junior high school and five per cent senior high school. Only 1.4 per cent of the population had completed tertiary education of some form, not including those educated overseas.

Since 1975 the Indonesians have significantly increased the number of schools in East Timor. By 1996 there were 62 kindergartens, 763 primary schools, 112 junior high schools, 37 senior high schools, a polytechnic and a university. But there are few supports for those educational institutions, the quality of teachers is extremely poor—most being inexperienced graduates from outside East Timor. Seventy per cent of secondary school teachers are non East Timorese. Presumably, they have now all left the country.
The AusAID submission to the Senate inquiry into East Timor says:

The current and future training needs of East Timor are vast and span basic primary, secondary and tertiary levels, vocational training, training for government administrators and upgrading for teachers and medical personnel.

Of course, that submission went in before the devastation of East Timor. The difficulty in taking students from East Timor into our scholarship program is apparently the low level of education and the difficulty of finding people who meet the academic requirements for entry.

Australia gave just $30,000 between 1992 and 1997 to support polytechnics in Indonesia, including one in Dili. One wonders just what one can buy for $30,000 over that period of time. We are spending $3.4 million over five years to provide vocational training in East Timor and, over the same period, $51 million for Indonesia for training in good governance which is intended to cover East Timor, but the figures cannot be separated—nor, presumably, can we be sure that the money will get through to East Timor.

There is little doubt that the financial crisis in Indonesia has exacerbated levels of poverty in that country and that East Timor has suffered in that respect more than most parts of that country. East Timor is poorer now than any province in Indonesia. The health problems in East Timor reflect that poverty. The AusAID submission to the Senate inquiry into East Timor notes that the common diseases there are respiratory infection, malaria, influenza, diarrhoea, tuberculosis and skin problems. Infant and maternal mortality rates are among the highest in Indonesia. For every 1,000 live births, 124 children under five years of age die, and 55 per cent of children under five are malnourished. While the number of health centres is relatively high, their quality and location mean they are hopelessly underutilised. Without significant donor support, rural health services are likely to deteriorate as health staff at district level and above, particularly doctors, are non East Timorese and continue to leave. In March this year, there were only 81 GPs and no public surgeons in the government health system in East Timor. Only 19 of these were indigenous East Timorese.

Apart from a small amount of funding for local non-government organisations, AusAID has not had a long history of direct support for health in East Timor, even though East Timor is one of our closest neighbours. We have contributed to water and sanitation projects. We also funded a tuberculosis program through Indonesia to train health workers and provide research into tuberculosis drug resistance.

The immediate needs of the East Timorese are of course for security, food, medical assistance and shelter. A population in which half its children are already malnourished cannot last long hiding in the mountains without food. The delay in reaching the estimated 35,000 who fled from Dili and other burning towns may have already devastated their number.

The logistics of getting aid into these people and the refugees in West Timor is daunting and no doubt every effort is currently being made to reach the people in need. I do not criticise the Australian government, which is funding the Red Cross, Care Australia, Community Aid Abroad, Oxfam and World Vision to deliver emergency relief. It is my hope, too, that Australians are digging deep and contributing generously to that effort. The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs is contributing to the relief operation and all Australians would hope that this aid can save what is left of the East Timorese. But I think it is now time for us to take stock and to look well into the future for the needs of the East Timorese. To say that East Timor has been neglected in the past by Australia is an understatement. We know that East Timor will need an enormous amount of assistance to rebuild even the minimal infrastructure that it once had. The political climate in Indonesia is such that no doubt East Timor cannot look to Indonesia for assistance to do this.

East Timor will need assistance from Australia in institution building and this means in politics and government, the public sector, legal and criminal justice systems, and health and education services. They will also need assistance in establishing media and other telecommunication services. They will need help with family planning, reproductive health and economic development in families and villages as well as in the nation as a whole. East Timor's electricity supply came from Bali and was very easy to shut down in the recent conflict. Building energy infrastructure and providing clean water and sanitation must be a high priority once East Timor is made secure.

It goes without saying that Australia's aid budget must be increased. This should of course not come from other aid programs, including humanitarian aid programs in Indonesia. Australia's defence cooperation budget with Indonesia is worth, I understand, $7.88 million. Diverting this money into East Timor would double our 1997-98 budget. The Democrats have said again and again that it is important that we maintain good relationships with Indonesia to ensure the continuation of economic and human rights reforms, and we do not want to jeopardise Indonesia's transition into democracy.

We have also said it is important that we do not nurture anti-Indonesian sentiment towards Australia. We must make it clear that we do not support the Indonesian military's action. We understand that it is not the fault of the vast majority of Indonesians that there has been slaughter in East Timor on such a huge scale. We do not, however, need to join with Indonesia in military exercises. Jose Ramos Horta expresses the need to distinguish between government policy and the will of the people. He has said:

We, the East Timorese, were on the receiving end of 23 years of Australia's betrayal but we never expressed any anger or resentment towards Australia and we never confused between what is the diplomatic position of the government with the position of the Australian people.

I think now it is time for us to repair the damage done by those 23 years of betrayal and for us to invest in East Timor. It will be costly but the East Timorese have paid with their lives in an effort to be free of oppression and terror. I think this is the least that we can do.

talk.start.para: —In speaking to this motion this evening, I firstly want to indicate my pride in the strength of the Australian leadership of the INTERFET and indicate that I am indeed very proud of all those Australians making a contribution in the force. At this time I, as with many other speakers this evening, also think of their families and their loved ones. They also deserve our recognition and support at what is a very difficult time.

speech.para: We will have up to 4,500 ADF personnel in East Timor in this operation and it is not an easy task that they are facing. I read today's stories about their successful arrival in Dili with interest. But in the coming days and weeks, as the force fans out across East and West Timor, we have no idea what they may encounter. The state of much of the rural areas is unknown to us through lack of communications, and many of these areas were previously militia strongholds.

As we keep an eye on the safety of our Australians we will also look, I hope, to the safety and wellbeing of the East Timorese—proud, gentle, strong and now independent; a people who have in the past weeks and the preceding decades paid the ultimate price for the freedom and democracy that we take for granted.

I was particularly struck with the bitter irony of the world's perspective on democracy at the recent local government elections in New South Wales. As people moaned about having to drag themselves to their local polling place to cast their vote, I thought to myself, if only you could have seen what I saw in East Timor on the morning of the popular consultation—people walking with their children for miles and miles in the night to polling booths, to be there when they opened and to cast their vote, and then melting back into the countryside.

My experience as a member of Australia's official observer delegation from Thursday, 26 August to Wednesday, 1 September, puts this motion today into perspective for me. I want to express my thanks to the Foreign Minister, Alexander Downer, for the opportunity to participate in that delegation. I describe it as, so far at least, the most extraordinary experience of my life. People keep asking me what it was like, and I keep failing to find the words to describe it.

The delegation was led by my National Party colleague the Hon. Tim Fischer, with the Hon. Laurie Brereton and Senator Vicki Bourne as the other parliamentary representatives. There were three non-government organisation representatives—Pat Walsh from ACFOA, Rae Perry from the Victorian Local Governance Committee and Anne Wigglesworth from CARITAS—and three DFAT officials accompanying us from Australia—Stephanie Schwabsky, Anthony Pearce and Kirk Conningham.

We were officially accredited as observers by Jeff Fischer, Chief Electoral Officer of UNAMET, to observe the ballot on polling day in accordance with the code of conduct as specified by UNAMET. I am international observer No. 1348, for the record. The guide to observers at voting centres was very clear: firstly, only registered voters, observers and UNAMET workers were allowed inside the 200-metre perimeter of the voting centre; secondly, the observer has freedom of movement but must not interfere with the voting process; thirdly, the observer must not go near the voting screens; fourthly, the observer should report serious breaches of the voting process to the DEO; fifthly, the observer must not speak to voters before or after voting; and, sixthly, the observer must not speak with local UNAMET staff. The role then was to provide independent international scrutiny of the ballot process to support a free and fair ballot.

I want to record some comments about the popular consultation, as it was styled, because, notwithstanding the tragedy and the horror of the past two weeks, the ballot process remains as an important and permanent reminder and record of the determination of the East Timorese to stand up for themselves, to turn out in record numbers of 98.6 per cent, to vote with a very high level of formality and to vote overwhelmingly for independence.

The review of the process of popular consultation is, I guess, highly coloured by understandable feelings of desperation at the plight of East Timor—not just now but for over 20 years—and most starkly, recently, their treatment at the hands of the militia and, therefore, the Indonesian military involved in these groups. But I think that a base political debate like that chosen by the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives and the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate today will not serve to assist one single desperate East Timorese person. Those people and the future of their nascent independent nation are my primary concern.

The considered remarks of Senator Bourne earlier this evening about the history of this tragedy, in contrast to the arid diatribes of Senator Faulkner and Mr Beazley, place a valid historical perspective on the record from a long-term committed campaigner for freedom for the East Timorese.

The Australian delegation observed, in their respective roles, Australian UNAMET, civil, political and electoral staff and CIVPOL officers from the Australian Federal Police. To a person, their work was being carried out in difficult, challenging and, for many of them, also dangerous circumstances and they brought enormous credit to Australia in the way in which they each performed their roles.

I think it is also important to record the quality and the value of the program put together by DFAT staff in Jakarta and Dili. It was an extraordinary effort, given the fraught environment in which Ambassador McCarthy and Consul General James Batley worked every day.

We arrived in Dili to continued campaigning in the streets, with truck convoys and milling people—mostly boys and young men—and, on that particular day, violence in the Becora area leading to some deaths and certain injuries. But so quickly was the situation shifting and so sensitive were senior officials in reporting to us on the violence that, between visits to the police chief at the POLRI headquarters and the East Timorese military commander, efforts to obtain an accurate status report were fruitless.

The very personal element of that tragedy was brought home to us the next day in the village of Baucau. It was supposed to be a quiet day. Permission had been given for one side to hold a closing ceremony for the campaign but it had turned into an unauthorised rally. So we arrived in town to trucks circling the village covered in campaign colours, a lot of noise, a lot of dust, a lot of colour and movement, and a fairly healthy degree of tension. We were very well briefed by Australian CIVPOL and UNAMET, who were very generous with their time in that difficult context.

But one of our meetings with a local official was stopped by an ear-piercing cry from one his staff from just outside our meeting room, followed by anguished sobbing. As it transpired, that gentleman's brother had been killed in the previous day's violence in Dili. And it is actually quite difficult to explain to the Senate how it feels to find yourself spectating, as it were, on a personal tragedy like that.

On the Sunday before the poll, we attended 6 a.m. mass in Bishop Belo's compound. Of course, that compound no longer exists and several members of his church community have been killed tragically. There were hundreds and hundreds of people at the mass—families, the young and the old, many nuns and priests. At the mass that morning there were several people wearing black armbands—people whose family members had been killed in Dili in pre-poll violence. If we needed another demonstration of the strength and unity of those people before the ballot, that mass, with hundreds of children singing, the solemnity of the communion and its all-pervasive emotion, spoke volumes.

Again near Baucau, at one of our polling booth observations in a village called Ailili—which means `sweet water'—we met an Australian UNAMET electoral official who was training his local workers for polling day. They did a role play for us, showing what you would do if you had an old infirm voter, and one of them did that; and what you would do if you had a blind voter, and one of them pretended to be blind.

The East Timorese UNAMET workers were incredibly proud of what they were doing, but they knew the risks. The Australian UNAMET official told us that, as they had received their UN IDs, they asked whether that would make them more identifiable to those opposing the ballot and therefore more vulnerable. The simple answer to that question was yes.

We heard extraordinary stories in Dili from journalists from all over the world, but particularly from Australia. I think it is important to make a special mention of the extraordinary efforts of all of those journalists to tell the stories to the rest of the world and to keep doing that long after their personal safety was under threat.

We ate breakfast one morning with a British journalist who had escaped with an Australian colleague of his from the area of a militia attack on the village of Memo near Maliana. Memo is divided into two levels, upper and lower. The British journalist described how the militia had burnt lower Memo to the ground—the homes, the vehicles, everything—and that the villagers of lower Memo had fled.

I did not realise at that stage that I would, in fact, visit Memo on polling day, but I did. We drove past the burnt-out homes on the Monday—they were still smouldering in some places—and past the destroyed vehicles. We came to a polling booth with long queues of people standing in the hot sun waiting to vote. They had come back—past their burnt-out homes, past their destroyed village—to cast their secret vote for the future they wanted for their people.

In another area, Ermera, we met several Australian CIVPOL and UNAMET staff. In later days, from the poll on, those Australian CIVPOL were involved in leading the defence of the UNAMET office against the militia—protecting the ballots themselves, protecting the international and local UNAMET staff and getting them safely back to Dili in a convoy. As I understand it, they did not just do that once, they did that again when they finally left Gleno later in the week.

Their bravery, their determination to do the job they had been asked to do as members of the Australian Federal Police in UNAMET, their efforts and those of the many other Australian CIVPOL in East Timor, are acknowledged but I want to record that again here, as someone who saw them in this environment, who saw the work they were doing and who saw the immense contribution they made to that process.

In another village, Aileu, Australian UNAMET and CIVPOL were running electoral training and working every day on ensuring the safety of the ballot, particularly one young female Australian CIVPOL, who was using her language skills in Bahasa to assist in managing what was a very tense situation in a nearby village.

Local UN workers were clearing and preparing the local school for polling day and, again, were enormously proud of the job they were doing. There were other young children from the village who were watching curiously from outside the classrooms, although I admit they may well have been watching us—a particularly curious delegation in this small village in East Timor, given the couple of Australian senators, an AFP agent, a couple of DFAT officials, associated drivers and hangers on. I am sure it was the first time they had ever seen the like.

There was one very young girl there with her little nine-month-old sister, Lia, who was very taken with the fact that some of the DFAT officers could help with speaking Bahasa. Her nine-month-old sister certainly did not look nine months old. If you put an Australian baby and her side-by-side at the same age I think you would be quite surprised. I cannot help wondering where people like that actually are.

We met some American nuns from the Maryknoll order who were speaking to us in almost sanguine tones about the activities of the local militia and the fact that they knew that 100 automatic weapons had been delivered into the village in the preceding days and that this was the battle their community may have to face.

I want to briefly record some experiences of polling day and put those on the record. Let me start with leaving Dili at 3 a.m. to travel to Maliana and seeing hundreds and hundreds of families walking through the early morning hours in the pitch black, carrying toddlers, breastfeeding babies as they went, just quietly and patiently making their way to the booths. But coming up the road towards the main polling station in Maliana, seeing literally thousands of people outside the local hall just quietly waiting to vote was a physically jolting experience. That was an expression of democratic purpose which was simply stunning in every sense of the word.

Maliana was expected to be a trouble spot and it certainly had been. Many Australian MLOs and CIVPOL will attest to that. It certainly went on to be, given what has occurred in Maliana and environs since the poll. But, at that stage, the greatest danger to voters was being crushed by the wave of people behind them waiting to vote. That polling station was also controlled by the Australian CIVPOL who, in consultation with the local Polri, kept good order for the day.

As a politician, sitting in a chamber like this, it is almost impossible to imagine the feeling of being asked at 6.30 in the morning to check that a ballot box is empty before it is sealed and polling commences, when there are thousands of people outside waiting for you and your colleagues to do that.

They voted under a sign that said in Bahasa and Tetun, `UNAMET guarantees that your vote is secret.' No wonder some people elsewhere in East Timor were, and I will use the word `concerned', about an Australian journalist at another polling station going from person to person in the queue asking them how they were going to vote. Every time I think of that I am reminded of provision 5 of the UN Code about not speaking to voters before or after voting.

In the booth at Maliana one voter took everyone's attention. It was an enormous hall and he was a very old man who was profoundly crippled. He had sticks under his arms, his legs were permanently bent in a sitting position. He had to vote at the station furthest from the door because that is where he had registered. In what seemed like an excruciatingly long time, he made his way to the voting position, he was given his ballot paper, he was assisted appropriately by UNAMET officials and he voted. He could have gone straight out the back door—very effective efficiency from very valuable UNAMET arrangements to come in one door and out the other, particularly when there are 3,000 people waiting to come in behind you. But he insisted on turning around and going back on his sticks the full length of the voting hall because he had just passed what was for him, from my observations, the most important vote of his life. He intended to make sure that people out the front knew about it.

The other polling station in the Maliana district was a chapel in the hills, but it was an area from which most voters had fled their homes. But on polling day hundreds of those displaced people came back to vote. They lined the hillsides and they queued patiently in the road to participate in a popular consultation.

In fact, by the time we arrived mid-morning at Balibo, the Mexican UNAMET electoral officer at the second of the polling stations in the school there reported that they were 75 per cent through their voter number, such was the enthusiasm of the voters and the efficiency of the UNAMET process. But he also reported that they had done training with their local workers the previous day and that local militia had stoned the roof of the school for the duration of the process. The day before the ballot: continuing intimidation and continuing efforts to undermine the process.

To UNAMET we had asked, day in and day out, many questions on voter education and on intimidation preventing people voting. Those questions were answered by the results: 98.6 per cent voter turnout and 78.8 per cent support for independence.

I have watched with growing horror the events of the past week and I understand the anger of those who campaigned for so long. I have never before had the experience of receiving phone calls to tell me that somebody I had met, somebody who had assisted a delegation of which I was a member, had been killed or was missing. That is just one of the reasons I find it hard to answer the relatively simple question about what the visit was like.

I want in closing, though, to look forward. Our argument is not with the vast body of the Indonesian people but it is with the perpetrators of the crimes and the brutality and the violence. The East Timorese who are in West Timor, taken to camps both voluntarily and forcibly, need our humanitarian assistance. I, for one, want them to know that we are determined, through the appropriate war crimes forum, to pursue the perpetrators of the barbarism and outrage against their people.

I saw the East Timorese take the most extraordinary step on 30 August, and for those of us who claim to support and protect democracy, the really hard job for us starts now. In the reconstruction of the society, let alone the physical nation, the East Timorese must be involved at the ground level. This is their nation we will help to rebuild and they must play the fundamental role in that.

Many, many more men will have been lost to the community in the abomination of the last 20 days. For the society to reconstruct itself, much of the burden will necessarily fall on the shoulders of the women of East Timor. The United Nations and government to government processes do not always take account of that. But in this case, we should.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to incorporate my speech in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
I wish to associate myself with this motion.

I have been a member of Coastal East Timorese Support group on the N.W. Coast of Tasmania for approximately eight years and have been a supporter of their search for independence for some time and this is still my view.

However its is not the legitimacy of their quest I will examine here today for none of us would question a nations right for self determination but the need to understand the Indonesian predicament with in the context of East Timor.
This should not been seen as an excuse for the horrendous actions of the militia or some sections of the Indonesian military rather an acknowledgment of what we have all known for some time.
That is that Indonesia is really one country in name only and to often the popular comments fails too or gives a superficial analysis to this occurrence.

Additionally the Indonesian army is not one army but has many factions and since the departure of Suharto has the potential for deep political division that may have implications for the future for true independence for East Timor.

Until November there is no legitimate leader in Indonesia and many other players in the Indonesian political system have made no commitments to East Timorese independence. Indeed Megawati has stated "East Timor cannot be decided by Mr Habibie's Government because it does not have the legitimacy to do so."

Thus there are warnings, as there were prior to the vote in East Timor that the vote may not be recognised, this in large part will depend on who rules Indonesia after November and the rest of the world's williness to apply consistent pressure on the powerful economic groups in Indonesia that are often the same people that control the military.
It seems that the Howard government placed too much importance on the close relationship that Australia had with the Indonesian government.

Even if this was true under Suharto and possibly true of Habbie the ability of the latter to truly deliver was severely compromised after the Indonesian election and will not be settled until the ratification of the election in November.

Thus questions naturally arise regarding our rush to agree with the Indonesian Governments desire to have the East Timorese election prior to the ratification of the Indonesian election. It could be assumed that Indonesia's design was to have an escape clause built in.
As there was a period of months between the Indonesian election and the choosing of the president it should come as no surprise that a period of internal instability in Indonesia was highly probable.

Given the likelihood of instability why would the Indonesian government schedule the East Timor election in the middle of that instability knowing that even if there was a vote for independence it would be months before the vote could be legitimised.

Thus it becomes clear that the most probable motivation for Indonesia to allow the East Timor election was an internally driven political agenda not a genuine concern for the sovereignty of the people of East Timor.

The question that is more serious is not necessarily related to internal domestic designs of Indonesia but what appears to be a lack of understanding of the political climate of Indonesia by the Howard Government or even worse political expediency.

Only one of these explanations can be used to explain why Mr Howard and Mr Downer were so willing to give in on their original request that suggested the best outcome would be achieved not by rushing into a feel good election, but by encouraging a gradual handing over as a part of a process moving towards an election.

This point of view supported the opinion of Xanana Gusmao who suggested that a ten-year time frame might be appropriate for a smooth transition toward East Timors independence. Gusmao knew that the vote was only a small part of truly gaining independence for his country.

He realised that most of the public service, teachers, and health workers were Indonesian nationals that a sudden withdrawal of expertise and infasructure could lead to internal chaos setting the preconditions for a protracted civil war in his country.
That is why a man that has fought for independence for over twenty years was prepared to wait another ten.

Thus the Howard governments reluctance to support Gusmao's point of view should be seen as a politically driven decision with a quick resolution being the desired outcome rather than a considered policy based on the long term interests of the East Timorese.
In closing my observations I do support the involvement of the multinational force lead by Australia and thank the United Nations for finally authorising the existence of such a force.
And I add my voice to many others supporting the sons and daughters of our nation for their safe return.

talk.start.para: —The motion before the Senate today and before the House of Representatives is a motion which enjoys, I think, the unanimous support of both houses. From the contacts made with me and with my office by members of the public, there is no doubt that the motion enjoys the support, overwhelmingly if not unanimously, of the Australian people. It is clear from the responses that I have received in the last two weeks to the abhorrent violence, the actions of the militia and those behind the militia, and sections of the Indonesian military that the Australian public were horrified. It is also clear that a great many members of the Australian community wanted Australia to do what was probably the unthinkable, and that was, irrespective of the wishes of Indonesia, to commit troops to East Timor. That would, of course, have created the opportunity for those within the Indonesian military and sections of their community who oppose independence for East Timor—and who, indeed, opposed the democratisation of Indonesia that occurred, at least in part, earlier this year—to take steps to put back, at the very least, the democratisation of Indonesia, if not the aspirations of the East Timorese and the process of independence in East Timor. It would have caused irrevocable harm to the relationship between Australia and its near populous neighbour, Indonesia. It was unthinkable.

speech.para: Indonesian citizens should understand that, just as Australians rejoiced in moves towards greater democracy in Indonesia earlier this year, we also rejoiced in the decision of Mr Habibie to grant residents of East Timor their right to determine their future democratically. It is also clear that elements of the Indonesian military disagreed with that decision and that they are in large part responsible for what occurred in East Timor leading up to the UNAMET controlled ballot and during the two weeks that followed it, prior to the agreement by the Indonesian government for the introduction of the multinational force to restore peace and security in East Timor.

We all want to express our full support for the Australians who will be serving in that multinational force, together with our full support for members of the military forces of other countries that will serve alongside Australia's armed forces. We want the men and women who represent us and the men and women who represent other countries in that force to serve without loss of life and without harm, and we sincerely hope that is what occurs. Of course, there are grave concerns that that will not be the case.

There is no doubt that the Australian community has full confidence in our men and women who will be serving in that force and those who provide the infrastructure support for that force back here in Australia. It will not be possible for that force to do its job properly without the support that is provided from Darwin and the rest of Australia, and other forces will rely on that base in Darwin for their continued functionality in what was the province of East Timor and will soon, I am sure, become the independent nation of East Timor.

We talk about democracy, and this chamber and the House of Representatives demonstrate part of Australia's great tradition of democracy. On many occasions we talk about the problems that our economy endures, and the opposition has made it plain that it feels that there are significant problems in the Australian economy today and that there are many indicators of this—which I am not going to seek to enumerate now. The opposition believes that the short-term effect of this government's failure to properly manage the economy will lead to a situation in this country where there is an increasing gap between the haves and the have-nots.

There are many economic consequences of this government's actions which might be dwelt upon, but while the cost of economic mismanagement in Australia must lead to falling living standards and fewer opportuni ties for our children, most of us will survive. Australians will have a chance to throw this government out. We are still in a democracy. Victoria on Saturday proved that, if we needed proof. We still have a chance to recover the economic ground lost under the stewardship of Mr Howard and Mr Costello. The errors made by this government in managing the Australian economy can be overcome. But, tragically, the errors made by Mr Downer and Mr Howard in relation to East Timor cannot. The opportunity to play a proper, effective and responsible role in the safe transition of East Timor to independence has now been lost for all time. We, along with many other nations, must now deal with the devastation that has been inflicted on these people.

At the beginning of February this year, Mr Brereton called on the Howard government to give a clear, in-principle commitment to contribute Australian civilian and military personnel to a United Nations monitoring force in East Timor. Mr Brereton said at that time that Australia had a historic opportunity to do the right thing by the East Timorese people, and he was right. However, within a few weeks the government strategy for East Timor became clear because, speaking on the ABC AM program on 15 March, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer, indicated the government's approach. He said:

We hope that there won't be a need for a peacekeeping force because if you need a peacekeeping force, you need a peace to keep and peace first has to be negotiated and we hope that when peace is negotiated it will be a peaceful peace that won't require a peacekeeping force.
I remind senators that that is a direct quote from Mr Downer.

This was not a plan to assist East Timor. It was a strategy built entirely on hope. It is also clear that the government knew well what would happen after the vote was taken. Mr Howard, Mr Downer and Mr Moore knew well that pro-integrationist militia, actively supported by the Indonesian military or elements of it in East Timor, were certain to carry out further violence. Yet Mr Downer's plan was a hope for a peaceful peace.

The advice the government received on this matter was correct. At the beginning of this year, just nine months ago, East Timor had a population, some say, in excess of 800,000 people. East Timor had a political structure at a national, regional and local level. East Timor had effective religious leadership and the social security that was brought to it by that religious leadership. And East Timor had an economic infrastructure in place. At the beginning of 1999, the social, economic and political ingredients for self-determination were—although inadequate—present in East Timor. All of that has now been destroyed.

The population in East Timor is now widely dispersed, with the exception, of course, of those who have been killed. People have been forced across the border into West Timor. They have fled into the mountains, pursued by the militia, to seek safety there. And some have had to be evacuated to Australia. The church has been destroyed and many priests and nuns murdered. It is no longer a safe haven to be in a church in East Timor—or at least one could say that for most of the country, if not all of it, up to today. The social infrastructure of the East Timorese community has gone. The economic infrastructure has been destroyed.

Australia's capacity to properly respond to this heightened crisis has also been compromised by this government. The administration of the Defence portfolio under Mr Howard has fared just as poorly as the economy. The Department of Defence has experienced the same negative, short-sighted approach to public administration that has become the trademark of Mr Howard's prime ministership.

Look, for example, at the conditions of service of military personnel. The vast majority of allowances paid to our soldiers, sailors and air men and women are designed to compensate them for the unique circumstances of service life. Let us not forget that most members of the ADF are below middle income working men and women economically and are unable to access normal industrial laws. They are often on call 24 hours of every day, seven days a week. They are also subject to the Defence Force Discipline Act. They are never paid overtime, but they work it on a regular basis. They are told where to go and when to go. As we have seen over the past week, service personnel can be sent to a potential or actual conflict without notice. They must immediately put their personal interests, their obligations as husbands, wives, fathers and mothers, to one side in the interests of the nation. These are not normal working conditions, by any stretch of the imagination, but this government has sought to treat them as such.

The Minister for Defence, Mr Moore, has had little interest in and even less understanding of the employment conditions and needs of the 56,000 troops for which he is responsible. When the shadow minister for defence, Mr Stephen Martin, asked him about the impact of the government's policy on youth wages and the ADF, he said:
The government policy on defence pay rates is well known.

Full stop. He has no idea how service personnel will be affected. Clearly, Mr Moore sat through the cabinet debate on this matter and did not ask how thousands of service personnel might be affected. When Mr Moore was asked about low income families in the ADF and the application of the fringe benefits tax, he said that this was a matter before the cabinet so he would not comment. What sort of rubbish is that? Again, he sat through the debate about this matter in the cabinet room and, again, he either did not understand or did not care.

Mr Moore endorsed the value of FBT entitlements being grossed up on the group certificates of defence personnel. The fact that many would be denied access to government payments to which they were rightly entitled as a result of this decision was clearly of little interest to this minister. He did not understand or ignored the fact that the FBT appearing on the group certificates would also mean an increased financial obligation on separated personnel through the Child Support Agency. This minister and, before him, Mr McLachlan have also seen the decline, almost to the point of crisis, in Australia's ADF medical support capacity. Both have applied unrelenting pressure to downsize and outsource what is an essential component of our defence effort.

While Mr McLachlan and then Mr Moore set about undermining our defence capacity, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer, was talking up a key regional security role for Australia. The rhetoric about our role and responsibilities in this region from Mr Downer was way out of line with our strategic defence capacity.

Since coming to office in March 1996, and despite all Mr Downer's talk, the Howard government has set about developing what is no more than a stay-at-home defence policy. This is the starting point for the ADF as we belatedly accept our responsibilities in East Timor. Not only is the Australian Defence Force now significantly under-resourced, the failures of this government in the lead up to the vote for independence in East Timor have made the task we now confront far more difficult.

The consequences of the failure to ensure security for the East Timorese people prior to the vote has been laid before us on the nightly television news. The cost in human lives and suffering has been shocking. Not only has there been unnecessary loss of life and great suffering, but the economic and social infrastructure of East Timor, as I said earlier, has been all but destroyed.

There are two tasks the government must undertake as a matter of priority. It must immediately investigate the activation of elements of the Australian Defence Reserve Forces to assist in the peace enforcement process in East Timor. Because of the extent of the devastation in that country, our role will be both extensive and protracted. The resources that will be required are well beyond our present full-time capacity. It is essential that our reserves be put on an appropriate state of readiness.

Unfortunately, Mr Moore's failure as minister is further highlighted by the fact that the government failed to fill half of its recruitment target for the reserves last financial year. Figures released yesterday show that the Defence Reserve was left 2,300 short of its goal of 4,760 vacancies. The government is now, after the event, looking at ways to fix that problem.

The government must also review the defence budget. We are now faced with the financial demands of securing and rebuilding East Timor, but we are also confronted with the financial consequences of the block obsolescence of defence equipment. The savings from the Defence Reform Program were more than subsumed by increased personnel costs well before the demands of East Timor.

The government is seeking a national consensus in support of its action to support what is left of East Timor and it wants a bipartisan approach. There must also be a bipartisan approach to defence policy generally, and that includes the level of resources that we as a nation want to commit to our defence effort. The regional political landscape has now changed, arguably for the worse. There must therefore be a full and open debate on what sort of defence force this nation now needs to not only ensure our security but to enable us to play an effective role in the region in which we live. We cannot afford to allow our strategic defence capacity to fall well short of our regional defence obligation, as has happened under the management of Mr Moore and Mr Downer.

Finally, and importantly, we must now commit whatever is required to the rebuilding of a devastated East Timor. We have an obligation given that we, after Indonesia, bear a heavy responsibility for what has happened in East Timor. We need to think outside of the square in terms of what we do and look to providing actual support for rebuilding the infrastructure of East Timor in the provision of building materials and in the provision of skilled labour to rebuild part of that economy. One thing that we have to make sure of is that those who sought to destroy this country's infrastructure and economy forever are not rewarded. We must show those who sought to punish the East Timorese for the exercise of their democratic right that the outcome is a better society than the one they destroyed.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in harmony with all of the voices that have spoken today in favour of the motion on East Timor. In speaking to this motion I would like to refer the Senate to a recent message of solidarity from the indigenous leadership of Australia to the East Timorese people. In that message the leadership made the following comments:

speech.para: We express our solidarity with the East Timorese people and their leadership in their enduring fight for self-determination.
We also express our abhorrence at the continuing genocide in East Timor.

The Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders of Australia believe the international community must now act decisively to ensure the fundamental human rights of the East Timorese are restored and their democratic vote for independence is validated.
The people of East Timor must be allowed to exercise their right to self-determination without further bloodshed.

It should be understood that Article 1 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and the International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights both affirm the rights of all peoples to self-determination.
By virtue of that right, they should be free to determine their political status and free to pursue their economic, social and cultural development.
This is clearly understood by all Indigenous peoples around the world.
It was clearly expressed by the people of East Timor on August 30.
Their collective voice should now be heard loudly and clearly.
Every death in East Timor is one too many.

It is also important to note that, in addition to this message of solidarity, indigenous people have expressed to me their personal feelings of solidarity with and commitment to the East Timorese people. Les Malezer of south-east Queensland, and ATSIC Commissioner Geoff Clarke, said to me only last week that they would be prepared to sign up and don the khaki greens and to make their own direct contribution. I think that there are many indigenous people in Australia who feel equally passionate about the situation in East Timor, and that bodes well for the future.

Today, I would like to call on the Australian government to continue to show its leadership in relation to the rights of the people of East Timor. The Democrats believe it is important that, as well as focusing on what needs to happen in the immediate future, we as Australians also have a responsibility to ensure that the foundations for the restoration of the rule of law are put in place as soon as possible. This is the first crucial step that must occur if we are to seek peace and security as an outcome and to return this as a gift to the people of East Timor.

Restoring the rule of law is not a simple or quick exercise. In addition to contributing our own forces to the UN authorised peacekeeping forces, we also need to consider what longer term contribution we can make to ensure that, once peace is made in East Timor, it can be maintained by the East Timorese. This will require an effective justice and police system to be put in place. It will require the rebuilding of public infrastructure and public services to enable economic and social development to occur once again, but it will also require a significant injection of investment capital. If called upon, we as a nation should be ready to assist. But, following the overwhelming desire of the East Timorese people for independence, all of these developments will need to take place in the context of the East Timorese being able to exercise their right of self-determination.

A peaceful solution to the conflict in East Timor cannot be achieved without respect for human rights, and these rights include the right to self-determination, freedom of opinion, expression and assembly, and the safeguards of due process of law. The right of the East Timor people to self-determination lies at the heart of the struggle for fundamental human rights, as it does for all peoples. The people of East Timor continue to demonstrate their enormous courage and determination to exercise their fundamental right to self-determination, and that is an inspiration to me personally and to many indigenous peoples who are struggling in their own countries to achieve the same outcome.

In partnership, we need to offer every assistance to the East Timorese people to lay the foundations for their future development and independence. Planning with the East Timorese leadership needs to start now. As one person who is grappling with the pain and the errors of the past in my own country, I have great empathy with the East Timorese people. Like us, they too are faced with the challenges of achieving reconciliation, reconciliation amongst the civilian population who supported East Timorese independence and those who advocated autonomy under Indonesian sovereignty.

There must also be reconciliation between East Timor and Indonesia and between Indonesia and Australia. I would like to refer the Senate to the words of the UN Secretary-General, Mr Kofi Annan, who said recently to the Indonesian government:
It is your chance to settle the question of East Timor peacefully, it is your opportunity to launch a new era of reconciliation.

The Australian Democrats believe that this call applies equally to the East Timorese people and the Australian nation. The Democrats, therefore, beseech the parties to engage positively and constructively to seek out the path of reconciliation, to put the mistakes made by each party in the past and to focus on building a stable future.

The Democrats would also like to recognise the enormous contribution of the East Timorese under the guidance of Mr Xanana Gusmao. It has astounded even East Timorese activist Mr Jose Ramos Horta that the East Timorese resistance forces that have spent the last 24 years fighting a guerilla war against the Indonesian armed forces are now sitting in containment areas, despite extreme provocation.

While the Indonesian armed forces have violated the UN agreement, terrorising the population and harassing the United Nations mission, the 3,000 members of the Falantil resistance movement have strictly obeyed the UN agreement. Their orders have been to remain in their containment areas and not to attack, except to defend themselves in response to Indonesian advances.

It is this combination of visionary politics and discipline that has exposed the brutality and injustice of the Indonesian armed forces in East Timor. Had the resistance forces responded in anger after 5 May, the inevitable bloodshed would have been cast instantly as civil war, potentially tempering the moral outrage and frightening foreign governments away from committing troops to what appeared to be another intractable conflict.

The maturity and discipline of the East Timorese forces since May this year augurs well for the transition to democracy, the restoration of law and order and respect for civil society through the democratic processes. It is also a very positive sign that the leader of the East Timorese, Xanana Gusmao, commands the respect of his people and exercises his authority in a manner that befits a world leader. He is in fact a leader in our midst. It is a leadership that I believe is the calibre of Nelson Mandela.

In closing, I would like to draw attention to the plight of the East Timorese refugees in Australia, West Timor and other places around the world. My heart goes out to these people when I imagine how it must feel to be driven from their homes and their country under threat of violence and death, not knowing when they will be able to return and what they will return to. Many of them carry with them horrific memories of the tragedy that has befallen their country, their families and their communities.

The decision by the Australian government to head the peacekeeping force now in East Timor offers hope to the East Timorese people in a very dark period of their struggle for independence. It is a sign, I believe, that Australia will be there with them. We must now ensure that our support is strong, unwavering and generous.

To the Australian men and women who are in East Timor now with the peacekeeping forces, I want to send my best wishes and support to them for their commitment to upholding peace and human rights, because that is admirable in our region. We have every confidence that they will achieve their mandate.

Finally, I would like to give special mention to the East Timorese community in Australia, which has worked so tirelessly and resolutely to provide a voice for their brothers and sisters in East Timor. May their patient struggle and commitment to their country and the goal of independence be rewarded in the very near future. I believe that their reward will come in the happy smile of a child.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the motion which is before us today in this chamber. I note that we have now been debating this motion continuously since 2 o'clock. There have been many fine contributions made in this debate, although I do not agree with some points that have been made, and I will deal with those. At this stage, considering the time that we have been here, it is worth repeating the motion which, in its first part, says:

speech.para: (a) notes the overwhelming choice for independence exercised by the East Timorese people on 30 August 1999;

In dealing with that component of the motion, certainly my sympathy and my feelings go out to those East Timorese who have suffered incredible injustices since they exercised their choice for independence. I am sure that every Australian would join with us in expressing that sympathy.

I am proud to say that the Australian government has accepted its responsibility, and coming out of that we will see a rebuilding of East Timor over time and I believe we will see true democracy operating in that country. It will not be easy; it will be difficult. Considering the loss of life and the loss of infrastructure that has occurred, it will take them a long time to recover—if they ever do. But it will be part of the process that the East Timorese have been seeking for many, many years. It is going to require enormous help from the Australian people, not only through financial assistance and our peacemaking role but also through the communication that we can provide to them as a people. The second part of the motion states:
