(b) welcomes the United Nations Security Council resolution 1264 authorising a multinational force to restore peace and security in East Timor, protect the United Nations' mission in East Timor and facilitate humanitarian assistance;
I shall deal with some aspects of that later in my contribution. The final part of the motion reads:
(c) endorses Australia's agreement to the United Nations Secretary-General's request that Australia contribute to and lead the multinational force;
(d) expresses its full support for the Australians serving with the multinational force and its full confidence in them; and
(e) looks forward to their safe return.

In listening to the contributions of Senator Faulkner and the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, I had real difficulty in believing that they were saying what they were saying. What did come out of what they said was their real embarrassment over the agreement Mr Keating signed with President Suharto some time ago when Mr Keating was the Prime Minister of this country. It was an agreement that did not go to cabinet; it was unilaterally decided at that time by the then Prime Minister, Mr Keating. It was really an agreement about peace at any price. Unfortunately, I can only describe that agreement as corrupt appeasement; it could not survive.

I think the motivation behind what Senator Faulkner and Mr Beazley, the alternative Prime Minister, had to say came out of their embarrassment at what occurred at that time. The criticisms that were delivered there today need analysing very carefully. What Senator Faulkner was saying was that Australia should have gone into East Timor unilaterally and declared war on Indonesia.

talk.start.para: —That is outrageous, Senator.

—That is the impact of what he said today. First of all, to go in there, you needed an agreement with Indonesia. President Habibie, as Prime Minister Howard has already said on a number of occasions, made it totally clear before the referendum took place that the answer to that question was a definite no. Further, we needed to go in there with the support of the United Nations. At that particular time, there was not any hope whatsoever—despite the efforts that were made by the Prime Minister, by Mr Downer and by others—of getting the support of the United Nations. Even if we could have got that support, I have no doubt that it would have been vetoed by China or Russia or both. Of course, we now have their support.

speech.para: Had we taken the action suggested, which I do not believe was a practical or sensible answer to the situation which was before us, it would have pre-empted the decision. And you can bet London to a brick that President Habibie would have called off the referendum and it would not have taken place. When you look at these things and get emotional about them, you must also look at the facts and at what you can achieve in going where you want to go. That is the reality that was faced by not only Australia but the rest of the world.

When agreement was finally reached, at the end of the day it only took, as I understand it, 16 days after the referendum was held for an agreement to be reached to put a peacekeeping force in place, which is by far the fastest time that a peacekeeping force has ever been put in place through the United Nations. In fact, some have taken well over 12 months. Unfortunately tonight we do not have the time to go into all of those. But it was very important that 1264 was a chapter 7 resolution. It had the support of China, it had the support of Russia and it had the support of numerous other Asian countries, including Singapore and Malaysia, in terms of what had to be done, but it also gave the Australians and the other partners in this peacekeeping force the right to defend themselves when they were going into a very difficult situation. I think it would be quite irresponsible for Australia to put our service men and women in a position where they did not have that right.

In the last eight years of the Labor government, who was it who regularly and consistently cut defence spending in terms of our capability? When we got into government what did we do? We froze further cuts to defence spending and we also started rebuilding our defence forces—a task that is going to take some years yet and which is certainly, unfortunately, hurried along by this particular decision.

We must also look at the importance of what has occurred in Indonesia in recent times with their elections and the importance of the development of democracy there and the protection of democracy and the right of the East Timorese to make their decision and have that protected, which we are doing. But I want to say to my many Indonesian friends in both Jakarta and Denpasar: I hope the situation is resolved quickly and successfully and I hope the new found democracy in Indonesia survives as equally as it stands and survives in East Timor.

In saying that, I note that it is incredibly important that the linkages, the many joint ventures, which exist between Australia and Indonesia survive. Some years ago I was invited to an expo in Jakarta at which there were some 200 Australian, mainly Western Australian, businesses which had partnerships or joint ventures in various parts of Indonesia—mainly in Jakarta but some in other parts. I think it is very important, as we come out of this, that these particular developments—which are important to Australia, important to Indonesia and important to East Timor—get back on their feet as quickly as possible.

I also want to say to my many Australian friends and business colleagues in joint ventures all over Indonesia: may you continue, albeit with difficulties, and may you soon be back to normal. I think it is important that we understand that those people are now living in a very difficult situation. They are Australian citizens. They are making a contribution to both the economy of Indonesia and the economy of Australia and they are very important to both countries in the future. It is incredibly important—in fact it is imperative—that the situation there be stabilised as quickly as possible.
Finally, to our service men and women and the support staff, I look forward to your early, safe return at the completion of a job well done.

talk.start.para: —I found myself interjecting on the last contribution and it was simply due to the suggestion—even a faint whiff of a suggestion—that the Labor Party would be interested in proposing we go to war with Indonesia. While we might have points of dispute here, I think it is very important that we place on the record that it never was and is not now the intention of the Labor Party to suggest that it was appropriate to consider war with Indonesia. I think the Labor Party's concern has been the slowness with which support and protection has been offered to the people of East Timor.

speech.para: I do note that a number of people commented that this is the quickest peacekeeping group that has ever been assembled—16 days or so during which time, as we have noted, goodness knows how many East Timorese have lost their lives, have lost their homes, have lost their possessions. So it is expedient maybe from one perspective; devastatingly too late from another. And we all know that. That is the tragedy that is East Timor and it is why today in both houses of this parliament we are debating this very solemn motion:
That the Senate—
(a) notes the overwhelming choice for independence exercised by the East Timorese people on 30 August 1999;
(b) welcomes United Nations Security Council Resolution
(c) endorses Australia's agreement to the United Nations Secretary General's request that Australia contribute to and lead the multinational force;
(d) expresses its full support for the Australians serving with the multinational force . . .
(e) looks forward to their safe return.

That is not a complete reading of the motion but it highlights the points. There are just a few points that I want to make. First of all, I join in supporting most of the contributions, certainly the contributions made by my colleagues, and in large part the comments made by others in this chamber—but not those points that are scathing in their attack on the Labor Party nor any comments that would suggest the Labor Party intended war at any time with Indonesia.

The concern I wanted to raise first of all is the interesting and I think remarkable response of the Australian people to what happened in East Timor following the ballot. It was widely reported and understood by the Australian population that something like 78 per cent to 80 per cent of East Timorese people had voted for independence and, as we know from following the preparations for the ballot, at considerable risk to themselves. It may well be a judgment on the Australian people. I think it is and I am proud of it: `Oh, well, that is the result of the ballot,' so you accept it and get on with it. That is certainly the behaviour in this country in the largest part.

I do not quite know really why Australian people reacted so unanimously across the country in outrage to the disregard of that ballot result in East Timor and the murder and mayhem that followed that result. But react they did and feel very angry they did at the seeming impotence of government and the United Nations to move in and do anything about it. I suppose that is also why so many people in this country wanted to support, or at least acknowledge with applause, the actions of the union movement in Australia to move so quickly, for instance, to boycott or picket outside Garuda Airlines and to refuse to load and unload shipping.

I note that there has been no negative comment about union activities. Perhaps one should never say `no' and `never', but I have read almost none. Most of the people I have heard in the community have said, `Well, good on them. At least they did something.' What is more, as some people said to me, the unionists made a point and put no Australian lives in jeopardy. It is also important to take the opportunity to acknowledge that it is one of the things the union movement does and it is often a contribution to our community that most people do not acknowledge—that is, outside wages, working conditions and industrial relations, the union movement plays a considerable role in a much broader social agenda.

Most Australians were very proud of the contribution of the union movement to the voice from the Australian people that described our distress and disgust at the response to that ballot in East Timor. All Australians are extremely pleased that there now is, following the United Nations resolution, a multinational force to restore peace and security in East Timor. I have not seen or heard anywhere any voice raised in protest at this action. Everyone has breathed a collective sigh of relief that at last it is under way and that it is now on the ground in East Timor and beginning to deal with the extremely difficult situation there.

I would also like to acknowledge Major General Cosgrove, who seemed to be at pains to pour water on any attempt to throw petrol at him. In relation to any of the questions that might have been asked or any of the challenges put to him, he said, `No, we're not going to fight. We're not going to stir things up. No, that is not our role at all.' It would be very edifying for all sorts of people to watch the interviews with Major General Cosgrove as he very calmly, very reasonably and very directly pointed out what he understood the role of that peacekeeping force to be and how he intended to go about doing it. In particular, he was clear about the relationship of that force with the Indonesian military. He knew, and made it clear, that the force had been assembled following the acceptance of Indonesia of its establishment and its presence in East Timor. There is not a war between the Indonesian military or the Indonesian people and that force. That needs to be made clear, and Major General Cosgrove did make it clear.

One of the other things that I wanted to particularly note is that Major General Cosgrove regularly referred to the `men and women' in our Australian contribution to the multinational peacekeeping force. For the record, I note that not everybody does. I hope everybody prays for our sons and their safe return, but I would like to think that they prayed for our daughters too. I would like us to acknowledge that there are men and women in the multinational force serving overseas in Dili and that we do not talk only as though our armed forces are men. It has changed and it needs to be recognised. The major general recognises it. I think it is very important that everybody else does too.

I have been listening in my office to the contributions today and I note any number of people who have referred to the men and women, but it seems to me that others have slipped up, and reference to men only or to wives at home is not a sufficient description. There are actually wives serving with the Australian force in Dili. We have to worry about the husbands at home, to say nothing of the mothers and fathers. I do not wish to labour it or make it a tedious point, but I think we should acknowledge the contribution of our men and our women. We do hope for the safe and speedy return of our men and women, of our sons and daughters. That, I am sure, is the sentiment of the largest number of Australians.

I was interested to hear some of the last comments of Senator Crane. I want to endorse them. Whilst we should look at the importance of assisting East Timor and the East Timorese people and whilst the first and immediate challenge is to make life safe and healthy for them—that is, that there be sufficient food, that there be clean and potable water, that there be sanitation and that there be housing and protection over their heads so that slowly East Timor can establish itself again as a viable group of communities across their territory—at the same time we must not overlook any number of friendships and connections with the people of Indonesia. It is a shame that a number of people are reporting the lowest level of relationships between these two countries.

While that might be the official line or it might be the case, there are many thousands—indeed, the vast bulk of the Indonesian population and, as Senator Crane said, goodness knows how many Australians—who would just simply be described as close friends or contacts. We have education. We have trade. We have any number of reasons for Australians and Indonesians to work together. That work is continuing, maybe with some difficulty at the moment. In many cases, perhaps it is not, but it is also important that we acknowledge the importance of maintaining our friendship and our ties with Indonesia. This is a big hiccup in that relationship, but I hope—and I am sure I am joining in many people's views—that that hiccup does not turn out to be a final cut.

Like many who have already spoken, I have also had the opportunity to visit Jakarta and I attended a conference and a very significant Australian trade exhibition while I was there. The enthusiasm and interest in things Australian at that trade exposition cannot be overstated. I also had the opportunity while I was there to visit community health centres and to look at the infrastructure on the ground to assist with women's health. I met with any number of women's organisations. I know the powerful network of Indonesian women in not only community services such as the provision of child care but also so-called small business, but many of them are running businesses with considerable turnover each year. In fact, they quite often might be described as much larger than small business. I hope that those connections can also be sustained and maintained through this extremely difficult period.

I am interested that there has been a large amount of perhaps disparaging comment about the efforts of former Prime Minister Keating to establish close ties with Indonesia. There was talk of treaties that were not worth the paper they were written on. I find it quite interesting that people can be so disparaging about the establishment of such a treaty and then so outraged when the piece of paper is torn up. If it was not worth terribly much when it was established, I am a bit surprised that it is worth so much outrage when it is torn up. It is interesting that efforts have been made over time to make sure that we have closer and closer ties with Indonesia and with an emerging democracy in Indonesia. I would have thought that a lot of us would argue about whether the balance has been right over time. Many of us would say that, from time to time, that balance has not been quite right, but I do not believe that all of those points need to be so readily dismissed.

With the best will in the world, there have been efforts to try to make sure that regional relations in this part of the world are fruitful, productive and constructive. I hope this continues. In particular, I note that in our motion we express full support for the Australians serving in the multinational force. I have already mentioned that briefly. I would also like to think that we were expressing our full support for our allies as well as for the Australians who are participating in that multinational force. I think it is, as most people have commented, much better that it is a broad multinational force rather than one made up of a single country or two or three countries. Perhaps, by definition, a UN Security Council resolution would require a multinational force but, while our resolution does not expressly address our appreciation of the contribution of our allies, I think it is the intent. Anyhow, I make that comment for the record.

It is another layer in the building of a network of close relations with our Asian neighbours. We have been strengthening those relations over a number of years through a series of different forums. This is perhaps not the nicest forum that you would look for in establishing or strengthening those networks, but it is to be noted and appreciated. In particular, the deputy of this multinational peacekeeping force is from Thailand and so we should acknowledge the contribution of Thailand and our other neighbours, in particular those from the local region—if you can use `local' to describe that region.

This is not a cheerful motion. It is about recognising those young men and women—from whichever country they come but in particular from Australia—who have taken up the challenge given to them by the politicians to go and serve in East Timor. While we are full of appreciation, we also have some trepidation. We are concerned that this is not an easy task. It is a task of considerable risk. We want to know that all those Australians who go will return.

It is not the same as previous peacekeeping forces that Australia has been involved in, but one has to say on past record that Australia's contribution to peacekeeping and management of peace is extremely good. There is something about the reputation and the record of Australians in Somalia, Namibia and Cambodia that should give us considerable heart. Australians are often sought after to contribute to multinational peacekeeping forces. It is recognition of not only our close relationship with Indonesia but also our past reputation and record in that area, and that should give us some comfort. That does not lessen the danger at all, but it means that we can expect a good return from the Australians serving in this force.

I join very strongly in the wishes of support and appreciation to all Australians in the defence forces who have chosen to serve, particularly those who have gone overseas to East Timor, in this multinational force and who contribute to its maintenance and ongoing upkeep. We are talking about a grave matter here today. It is a sobering motion and one that, in the fullness of time, will possibly turn out to have a satisfactory outcome. It is in place, though, because of appalling atrocities and tragedy in East Timor over the past months and, some would say, over the past 25 years and more. I join in wishing our very best to all those serving, particularly with the Australian multinational force. I also hope that we will see all of those contributors safely return to Australia and that we will see peace in East Timor—a real peace that allows people to live fruitful, constructive lives in the re-establishment of a thriving East Timor.

talk.start.para: —I also rise to speak in support of this motion. It is an important motion because it is an important time in Australia's history, as many commentators have noted. In such a circumstance, I think it is appropriate that, despite the significant number of speakers who have addressed this motion, I also give voice to my views and put on the record not just my views and some aspects of the views of my party but also what I, as a representative of Queensland, believe are the strongly held views of a significant majority of the people of Queensland in relation to the East Timor issue.

speech.para: The motion starts by noting the overwhelming choice for independence which was exercised by the East Timorese people on 30 August. That in itself is a significant component of the resolution and of the issue that we are debating. We are not just debating, speaking in support of or addressing the issue of the here and now—the issue of Australian peace enforcement agents going over to East Timor to try to put an end to the killing and suffering that is occurring there. In a sense, we are talking about the history of East Timor—particularly over the last 24 years, although also prior to that—and the future of East Timor.

It is not just some historic motion where we make noble speeches to mark this moment of great import; it is a time where we should put on the record and put forward views that are about not just what has happened in the past. Once the immediacy of establishing security in East Timor has passed, it will be an ongoing and important task of this parliament and other people in the nation to explore in more depth the mistakes and the failings of Australia's attitude and approach towards East Timor in the last couple of decades so that we do not repeat those mistakes. It is also important that we ensure that we use this moment to tie ourselves as a nation to our responsibilities not just now but into the future. That is probably more important because of the failings of our nation in the past.

The fact that the choice for independence by the East Timorese people was so overwhelming after such a comprehensive and extended period of oppression says it all. It highlights not just the great perseverance and patience of the East Timorese people over a time when the land was under occupation but also, in a fairly condemning way, the policies of Australian governments since 1975 that turned a blind eye not just to the occupation of East Timor—which is an issue in itself—but to the undeniable, repeated and extensive evidence of atrocities committed. That is probably one of the more unfortunate aspects of the current situation—that whilst the extent of killing and suffering at the moment is perhaps higher than it has been in the past, it is certainly not an isolated incident. It is not the first time that there has been widespread terror vented upon the people of East Timor by forces that are aligned with or part of the Indonesian military. We as a government—and, to an extent, as a parliament and a nation—have chosen to turn a blind eye to that because we felt it suited our immediate diplomatic, political, economic or trade interests. The chickens have come home to roost on that issue, and that is causing some difficulties for us as a nation and as a government at the moment. But these difficulties pale in comparison with those being experienced by the people of East Timor at the moment.

It shows again the absurdity and the hollowness of the approach of previous Australian governments. Whilst this is not a time for going too much into a condemnation of previous policies or into shallow political point scoring, it is nonetheless appropriate to highlight those failings to ensure that we do not repeat those mistakes and that we examine exactly why we allowed ourselves to go down that path. We all have to bear some responsibility, regardless of the various positions we may have taken as individuals, for allowing things to get to this particular situation. As a member of the Democrats, it gives me pride to belong to a party that has consistently, since its inception, tried to highlight the suffering of the East Timorese people and the injustices being perpetrated against them. We will continue as a party to keep that tradition strong as we embark on the next important phase of trying to offer assistance and support to East Timor as it develops into an independent nation.

If I could add an extra part to this motion—along with noting the choice for independence, welcoming the UN Security Council resolution and endorsing Australia's agreement to it, expressing our support for the Australians serving with the multinational force and looking forward to those Australians' safe return—I would add an extra section looking forward to the establishment of a strong, free and independent East Timorese nation. When that day arrives, as it inevitably will, it will be a day of some significance for the people of East Timor but will also, as many other nations have shown over the years, highlight the importance of perseverance and patience in the continuing fight for human rights, justice and self-determination. Many other nations in the world have highlighted that, in the darkest hours when the forces that are arraigned against people can seem overwhelming, sometimes—sadly not always—justice does prevail. Whilst justice still has a bit of a way to go before it prevails here, we are finally on the right track.

I would like to pay tribute to those Timorese who have persevered and fought for so long. So many have lost their lives already not just in the last few weeks but over the last couple of decades. I am paying tribute to their perseverance and sacrifice but also to those in the Australian community who have tried to offer support and to stand by the Timorese. The Catholic Church, in particular, has been a significant force in the region in trying to maintain hope and keep the flame burning.

Community Aid Abroad—which I mention partly because of my own involvement with it—is an organisation that has suffered a bit of pain because of its insistence on maintaining involvement in East Timor in sometimes very awkward circumstances. But because of the role that it played, along with many other non-government organisations, it was able to provide better information, intelligence and assistance to the East Timorese than more official and much more well-resourced channels were able to. We have seen that again in recent times. Those organisations that have been active on the ground and that have not developed a culture of denial about the reality of what people are experiencing but have continued to try to give voice to the truth as they see it have been much better placed to ensure that need is able to be met as quickly as possible in urgent situations such as have occurred recently.

As the Democrats spokesperson on veterans' affairs, I would particularly like to offer my support and encouragement to both those in the Australian Defence Force and those allied personnel who are currently involved in East Timor. I also mention other people recently returned from East Timor—not only from the Defence Force but also from the Australian Federal Police—who performed a very courageous and important task in providing some protection in very dangerous circumstances.

It is most likely that in the future Australian forces will play more and more of these peacekeeping and peace enforcement roles, which are crucial roles. I think the Australian Defence Force needs to be resourced to operate in that particular capacity rather than in other capacities that are a bit more outdated. I hope the Australian government will ensure that, when those defence personnel return from their service in this region, they will be adequately looked after in recognition of the service they have provided. I take particular note of Senator Crowley's comments and reinforce the fact that it is not just brave men of the Defence Force but brave men and women of the Defence Force who are serving in East Timor. I would also like to offer our support to the families of those serving members, because it is obviously a nervous time for them in these circumstances.

A few other issues are worth re-emphasising even though I am sure other speakers have already emphasised them. I highlight the importance of humanitarian aid and the aid budget not only in relieving immediate suffering but also in providing a platform and a foundation for development into the future. The best aid is all about providing a foundation that people can build on to determine their own futures.

It is crucial that extra aid assistance should not be taken from other areas of the aid program. Areas that are further away from Australia, such as Africa, often tend to fall from people's consciousness. However, we need to maintain our commitment to those areas as well. While increases in the aid budget and, if necessary, in the defence budget need to be explored further, the money should not be found from cutting other expenditure such as social services. We should not be taking from one area of need and moving it across to another.

Like many in this chamber and in the Australian community, I have been involved in rallies and forums in relation to East Timor in recent weeks. I was privileged to be able to address a particularly powerful rally that packed the Brisbane City Hall the weekend before last. One issue from that rally which concerned me was that such instances and circumstances may lead to an increase in general anti-Indonesian fervour around the country. I would like to caution and guard against such an approach.

I certainly would not like to see a cutback in Australian aid which aims to assist the disadvantaged in Indonesia and to assist Indonesia in building its democracy and an equitable economy. I do not think it is helpful to have a blanket type of backlash against the Indonesian nation or Indonesian people in general. The atrocities in recent times and even going back over the last couple of decades have been actions of the government and the military; they have not been actions of the Indonesian people. I do not think it would be helpful at all for people to foster a blanket anti-Indonesian feeling in response to recent circumstances.

I would like to briefly address the issue of refugees, which is another area that I have responsibility for on behalf of the Democrats. We have seen a response from this government offering safe haven to some people from East Timor. I have spoken a number of times before on my concerns about the limitations of the safe haven program, particularly the fact that it prohibits people from being to apply for any other form of visa—including a refugee visa or permanent humanitarian protection—whilst they are on Australian soil. I believe that is a significant flaw in the way that Australia's safe haven visas operate. Whilst they are certainly better than nothing in terms of ensuring that people are removed from immediate danger, I have concerns about such a dangerous principle.

Refugees firstly suffer the trauma that has forced them out of their homes and away from the place where they live, but often an equal trauma on an ongoing basis is the lack of control that they have over their own futures. To constrict people's futures in such a way by leaving something as basic as their place of residence completely up to the whim of the government or the minister of the day is potentially unnecessarily adding to that trauma. I think virtually all of the East Timorese people who have come here recently would be keen to return as soon as possible to Timor. Having waited so long for independence, I expect very few of them would want to miss out on the development of a new nation. But that should be their choice, and it should not be restricted or curtailed so comprehensively.

In discussing the issue of East Timorese refugees, it is necessary to highlight the ongoing circumstances of refugees or potential refugees—that is, people who are applying, or have applied, for refugee or humanitarian recognition in Australia. That recognition was applied for by some of them many years ago and, through an extended process—which perhaps even now continues—they have been dragged right through the courts. Responsibility for this belongs to a government that has tried to build on Australia's absurd approach to the Indonesia-East Timor relationship in saying that these people are citizens of Portugal and should have the ability, and be required, to seek asylum in Portugal rather than in Australia. Not only does this highlight the absurdity of Australia's approach over many years to East Timor and Indonesia, but it also highlights what I would call an ongoing lack of compassion in our approach to many aspects of humanitarian policy.

As I have said many times, this is not an easy area, and a lot of factors have to be balanced. But I believe that a basic humanitarian and compassionate approach to people needs to be put higher up in the equation. I know that the minister talks of important legal principles and precedents being involved in this particular case which concerns a number of East Timorese who are seeking asylum in Australia. Legal principles are important and precedents are important; I agree with that. But the human cost, the human impact, is also important and I believe it has been undervalued in circumstances such as this. I know that many of those who over many years have been involved in this ongoing case have suffered enormous trauma because of what they have had to endure in seeking protection in Australia.

As many other speakers have said on this issue, Australia does owe a particular debt to East Timor. Although that factor does not always fit neatly into legal niceties, legal precedents and arguments surrounding the establishment of principles such as those, that does not mean it should be ignored, swept under the carpet or put on hold for extended periods of time. I would urge the government to reconsider its approach to that issue as well as ensure that the assistance it does provide to Timorese refugees is as adequate as is feasible.

I do congratulate the government on and acknowledge the efforts it has made in recent times. Perhaps it has not made those efforts quite as quickly as I would have liked but, nonetheless, I do recognise the real hurdles that can be put in the way of such actions, and it is appropriate to congratulate the government and acknowledge the efforts it has made in recent times in providing that assistance. However, I do urge the government to extend and maintain that assistance for a long period of time rather than just while the public heat on this issue is on.

In conclusion, I certainly wish the best for our servicepeople in East Timor at the moment. Also, I particularly wish to give a message to the East Timorese that our support and assistance are with you; there is a long way to go, but you have lasted this long and, I am sure, will get there in the end.

talk.start.para: —I start by saying that I was saddened earlier today when I listened to Mr Beazley's contribution in the House of Representatives. I just thought that for once he may have shown himself to be a statesman and actually have approached the issue in a more bipartisan and non-partisan way. But, as is typical, Labor revises history. The revisionist approach to Labor's performance I think did him a disservice. I think when people look back on his contribution, it will be judged for what it was. It was not the best contribution I have seen him make in the House of Representatives or other places. I just felt very sad that he had to take that approach.

speech.para: In recent weeks, the Australian community has witnessed in East Timor the unfolding of events of unspeakable horror. Most honourable senators here have outlined those events and have paid tribute to the resolve and commitment to self-determination shown by the East Timorese people over a very long period of time. Most honourable senators also have reviewed the horrors following the decisive vote for independence and have outlined the situation that exists in East Timor today. I will not go over those matters again, for the sake of brevity and to enable other colleagues to make a contribution without our being here until all hours of the morning.

I just want to seek to highlight the efforts of many Australians, both within the government and the general community, who have sought to extend assistance to the East Timorese—both those in East Timor and those who have fled the violence. It has given me great pride as an Australian to witness the contribution Australia is making to East Timor and its people. There can be no doubt that, without the unrelenting effort and determination shown by the Prime Minister in focusing international attention on East Timor's plight, we would not have been able to galvanise the almost global response we have seen to date. The Prime Minister's actions, coupled with the diplomatic efforts of our foreign minister, Mr Alexander Downer, and the military planning efforts under the guidance of the Minister for Defence—that planning having been put in place months ago—have allowed Australia to take the international lead in the world's response to the crisis and to take appropriate action to stabilise the situation to our north.

The strong leadership of the government in this matter has been strongly supported by the professionalism and dedication of members of the Australian Public Service, many of whom have undertaken tasks demanding efforts beyond what is expected of them normally in their roles. Through the efforts of many individuals in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Department of Defence, Australian Customs, the Australian Federal Police, the Department of Health and Aged Care and my department, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Australia has been able to respond quickly to the changing circumstances in East Timor.

I must say here that my experience as a parliamentary delegate to the Australian Permanent Mission to the United Nations and attending the General Assembly in 1997 made me very aware of the enormous load the Ambassador to the United Nations, Penny Wensley, and the staff associated with the mission carry during the year, particularly during a General Assembly. Defence Force personnel are also attached to the mission, and I know that they would have been under enormous pressure preparing for UNGA and having the overlay of the enormous diplomatic efforts that were undertaken at the UN in the lead-up to the Security Council's decision. I pay tribute to them; I know that Penny Wensley was very involved, the staff would have had an enormous workload and the Defence Force personnel at the UN mission would have also played a leading role and worked tirelessly.

I would also like to pay tribute to the efforts of the Australian police force, which undertook, with other nations, the monitoring of the independence vote and endured threats and risks to their personal safety in assisting those escaping the violence. Along with my colleagues here and in the other house, I would like to pay tribute to the efforts of the Australian Defence Force and those men and women from a host of other countries who, under the leadership of Major General Cosgrove, have taken on the heavy task of restoring peace to East Timor. Many people here today have also commented on the role that the friends, family and loved ones of those people so closely involved play in supporting and encouraging them. As Senator Boswell alluded to earlier, it is no easy task that they are undertaking on behalf of the United Nations; it is one filled with high risks and many challenges, and I pray for their success and for their safety.

How else has the government responded to this humanitarian crisis? Through the efforts of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and the Defence Force—but, in particular, I am focusing on the department with which I am associated—both locally engaged UNAMET staff and, later, those seeking safety in the UNAMET compound were evacuated from Dili and issued with safe haven visas upon their arrival in Darwin. The rapid processing of the arrival of these evacuees and their relocation to temporary safe haven accommodation were undertaken with efficiency and professionalism far beyond the usual call of duty. Some of the officers concerned were given only hours notice to be in Darwin.

They have worked around the clock. I have talked to some of them and I know that they have developed a tremendous spirit working together. They have gone well beyond the call of duty. I pay tribute and take off my hat to them because they have been right in the thick of it. It has meant a disruption not only to their lives but also to the lives of their families. We also forget that, while public servants have gone off to participate either in the peacekeeping force or in caring for the evacuees and assisting with their relocation, their colleagues have shouldered an extra burden in their absence. I acknowledge that and know that many of them have worked extra hard to accommodate the fact that many of their colleagues are missing from their regular tasks.

The systems for the successful evacuation and resettlement were developed during the recent crisis in Kosovo and the evacuation of the Kosovars from the border camps to safe havens around Australia. In my role as patron of the safe havens I will continue to work with the East Timorese. I have witnessed many people within DIMA working tirelessly to meet the demands created by the Kosovo crisis. Members of the department have, as I said, worked beyond the call of duty to establish systems and procedures for the transport, processing, housing and ongoing medical, psychological and everyday needs of those fleeing torture and violence. These efforts have been matched by their many state counterparts in the health, education, police, transport and emergency services who provided high levels of support to the needs of the safe haven communities. Now the fruits of that hard work and personal sacrifice made by those federal and state officials only a few months ago are being used in a new humanitarian crisis, one which is much closer to home and no less demanding in its challenges.

It has been a salutary experience for me, first of all in meeting the Kosovars as they came off the plane straight from the camps in Macedonia and again last Saturday as I met, with the minister, the evacuees coming from East Timor. Always imprinted on my mind will be the two little girls who clutched my hands on Saturday. They had nothing but a plastic bag with a couple of toys that they had been given in Darwin. One of them said to me, in her very limited English, `Thank you.' My heart went out to them when I realised, through an interpreter, that their grandmother had said that they were not sure where their parents were or whether they were alive or dead. It makes one very grateful for all we have here in Australia.

The Australian community has made substantial contributions to the plight of those fleeing persecution and violence, and the outpouring of community support for the previous evacuees has been remarkable. Support has come from community organisations such as the Red Cross, St Vincent de Paul, the Salvation Army, Community Aid Abroad and others, and it has also come from local community schools, service clubs and other organisations which have contributed books, clothing, food, services and other items for the welfare of evacuee groups.

The East Timorese moving into safe haven communities will enjoy the same safe haven visa rights and measures of support as received by the Kosovars. These measures include medical, educational, financial, accommodation, and crisis and trauma counselling. Services will be given by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, as the lead department, the defence forces and other state and federal government agencies. The safe havens at Puckapunyal, Leeuwin and East Hills will become the new homes for the East Timorese evacuees. I know that the Australian community will be as supportive and generous with those East Timorese evacuees as they have been with the previous Kosovar evacuees. I know, too—and I saw this in action on Saturday—that the East Timorese community will be very involved in assisting the East Timorese evacuees. From the level of community concern about the events in East Timor, I have no doubt that Australians will live up to their reputation as a caring and generous supporter of people in need.

Senators will be aware that as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs I have responsibility for the administration of the student visa program. I was concerned to read this morning in the Herald Sun about fears raised by Indonesian students at RMIT that their visas may be in doubt as a result of the conflict. In response to this I would like to reiterate the comments of Minister Ruddock in the House of Representatives that, just as any East Timorese currently in Australia on a temporary visa will not be returned until they can do so in safety and dignity, other Indonesians currently in Australia on lawful visas, such as students, need not be concerned that the government would send them back to Indonesia. I will be arranging shortly to meet with the Indonesian students at RMIT to allay their concerns.

I take this opportunity to reiterate the ongoing benefits to Australia which have been produced by the longstanding exchange of students between our two nations. As well as providing economic benefits, this intellectual and cultural exchange has helped to facilitate a strong relationship between the Australian and Indonesian peoples, manifesting itself in many mutually beneficial ways, including business relationships, tourism, the formation of cooperative linkages and, of course, lasting friendships between individuals. I hope that some of those foundations which have been laid over the years through students studying here and through students who are currently here may help to heal and bridge some of the divisions that have resulted from the events over the last few weeks.

Through the strong leadership of our Prime Minister, ably supported by the government agencies involved at the ground level, the Australian government has provided focused leadership and a strong response at both an international level and a national level to the crisis in East Timor and has provided the East Timorese with a real opportunity for self-determination. I, with my colleagues, wish all of those involved, particularly those on the ground in East Timor in both our own defence forces and those participating in the UN peacekeeping mission, a successful operation, safety and godspeed.

talk.start.para: —Like so many senators have done today, as I rise in this debate my first thoughts are for the young Australian men and women and their comrades from other countries who are being deployed in East Timor. They are undertaking a dangerous and just task. They are performing the duty of the entire world; that is, to protect the democratic human rights of the East Timorese—the right to self-determination and, indeed, the right to life itself. I wish them well. I remember also at this time their families and loved ones at home—their parents, their wives, their husbands, their children. Their hearts are filled with pride. There is also an edge of fear and a worry for the welfare and safety of these young Australians and, of course, for those from other countries.

speech.para: There is another group of young people in this picture as well, another brave fighting people—the hundreds of thousands of East Timorese, many of whom have lost their lives, and possibly hundreds of thousands more whose lives are right now in perilous danger. We must act with all speed and care to protect and save the East Timorese, whether in East Timor or elsewhere in Indonesia, from the terrible danger and terror that now confronts them.

I would also like to draw the Senate's attention to a third group of young people who are far from home. Senator Patterson has just relayed her concerns and the concerns of the government about the Indonesian students who are currently studying in this country. This is a group of young people currently also separated from their friends, family and homeland. Right now these people are also nervous and afraid. I welcome Senator Patterson's comments on behalf of the government as to the value of these students and their role in Australian society. I also welcome her commitment that their visas will not be threatened as part of these difficult times.

However, Senator Patterson must also acknowledge that these students are genuinely concerned and that many of them want to go home. They sense that some Australians are using the current East Timor crisis as an excuse for racist attacks on innocent and decent young people and other Indonesians in this country. Students are telephoning their parents in Jakarta or Surabaya, pleading with their parents to allow them to go home, back to Indonesia. They no longer feel welcome in our country, and that is a matter of deep regret. It is, in fact, a matter of shame. It is a shame which I must say should be added to many other causes for shame in these terrible times. Almost all Australians are not racist, and I think we have a proud record of multiculturalism and tolerance. I would like to add my personal assurance to those parents of Indonesian students who are worried about their children who are now in Australia. These young people are safe and are welcome guests in this country.

I also express my admiration and respect for the brave and long-suffering people of Indonesia itself, for their fight for independence and their own democratic rights. Australians are proud of our small role in supporting the people of Indonesia over 50 years ago. Of course, our efforts were aimed at assisting the Indonesian people to gain their independence after a long, bitter and bloody struggle. We understand, too, that for the people of Indonesia the struggle is not yet over. We watched in amazement last year the brave and resolute actions of Indonesian young people, students and others, which brought an end to the repressive era of the so-called new order, the government of President Suharto. Now Indonesia is struggling to create a new, open and just society, a reformed political system where the citizens can enjoy full democratic rights. We at last can voice their concerns and we can hear their concerns being expressed. We know how difficult that is.

The Indonesian people understand far better than we do how fraught, painful and slow this process of democratisation will be. They know the extent to which the evil and ugly tentacles of corruption and nepotism have insinuated themselves within Indonesian society itself. One of the gravest problems facing Indonesia is that of the role of its own military, whether it be ABRI or TNI. The power and dominance of the military in Indonesian politics and public life is not fully realised by most Australians, nor is the fact that the rest of the Indonesian government—including the current President, Habibie—actually has no control over sections of that army. Nor is it well understood that in Indonesia a deadly power struggle between Habibie, ABRI and the political forces and parties is now under way. The bloodbath in East Timor is just part of a reflection of the ruthless bid to regain and expand its power on behalf of that group within the military in Indonesia.

We know that by far the overwhelming majority of Indonesians are honest, decent citizens who want to put an end to the sickness and uncertainty in their own country. They have also spoken out in solidarity with the people of East Timor. Many union groups, non-government organisations, women's organisations, human rights groups and the like have spoken publicly in support of the East Timorese in their struggle. They have in many cases provided material assistance to funds for East Timor's independence and resistance groups—and, of course, to Fretilin.

Within Australia, similar groups, particularly the ACTU, have played an important role in drawing support to those groups. The ACTU was the first international organisation to recognise the CNRT, who of course sent a delegation to Timor in August to provide practical assistance in the independence ballot. I advise the Senate that one of my staff members, Ms Jane Nicholls, was part of such a delegation. She has been able to provide me with first-hand insight into the horrendous conditions faced by the Timorese people and the pogrom that followed the ballot being declared.

She has been very fortunate to return to Australia, very much as a result of the intervention of the Australian consul in Dili and his staff. I would like to place on record at this time my thanks to Mr James Batley and his staff for their assistance. I might also suggest that, if it had not been for their intervention, Ms Nicholls may in fact not have been able to return safely. I believe that their actions may well have saved her life.

It is important to appreciate just what the situation is with regard to the militia in Indonesia, in particular in East Timor. I believe that the evidence is overwhelming that the Indonesian army have openly and blatantly been arming, training and supporting these so-called militia forces, many of whom are actually TNI and Indonesian police officers in mufti, dressed up as militia members. Alongside the police and military are young men who are hired guns and nothing more. They are young West Timorese and youths from other parts of Indonesia. Some of them are disaffected East Timorese—young people who, for various reasons, are alienated from their own society. They are orphans, street kids and the unemployed. They are young men displaced by the scorched earth policies of the Indonesian army itself. They have been described to me as the deadbeats of East Timorese society, the drop-outs and petty criminals.

We are entitled to ask why it is that these unfortunate young people have joined the militia to engage in such a bloody campaign of terror to thwart their own people's 24-year-old struggle for independence. I believe that the reason is quite straightforward, in the sense that they are paid to do so. The going rate is 50,000 rupiah a day, as I understand it. This amounts to about $A10—a lot of money to people who have very little else to lose, and a lot of money to a person with very few options from West Timor.

The campaign of terror, death and intimidation is expensive, and we are entitled to ask who has been paying for it. In fact, much of the money that has been used to pay the wages of the so-called militia has, as I understand it, been largely counterfeit. I am told that members of the military have brought suitcases full of fake 20,000 rupiah notes into East Timor over the last few months and have been using this worthless money to finance their deadly campaign.

While ABRI is prepared to use unhappy, unfortunate young people to serve its sinister and savage ends, it remains ruthless even in its treatment of these recruits. It will not even keep its end of the bargain with the militia. At least some of the time, these people have been ripped off by the army that they say they support. Militia members are given by the army a steady stream of drugs. An amphetamine known locally as anjing gila, or `mad dog', renders them completely irrational and violent.

There are also reports that the military and police have used press-gang tactics to enlist militia members. Terrified young men report that they have been threatened with death for themselves or for their parents and siblings if they refuse to join the militia. They report that they are constantly under threat of execution if they disobey the orders of ABRI. The lengths to which elements of the Indonesian armed forces have gone to achieve their evil and ruthless ends can scarcely be believed.

Potential dangers have to be faced by UN forces currently in Timor—on a psychological and also a physical level. My thoughts and support and the thoughts of all Australians are with them and their international colleagues. I believe we would all like to see them safely back home when their duty is done, and for that to be as soon as possible.

Indonesia's economic and social circumstances are a matter of grave concern to Australia—Indonesia being our largest neighbour. There is no doubt that the East Timor bloodbath has been carried out largely at the instigation and under the command of the Indonesian armed forces. There is no doubt that sinister intentions remain in some parts of the army to do harm to the hundreds of thousand of unfortunate persons forcibly frogmarched out of East Timor into West Timor and elsewhere. They are being held hostage in concentration camps, and our capacity to help them is pitiful.

ABRI's agenda has to be seen as a claim on holding the real power in Indonesia itself. It has to be understood as an intention to immobilise President Habibie and it will be a major issue in the formation of the next government in Indonesia. Whoever is the next President of Indonesia, that person and their party will be beholden to the military. It is legitimate for some commentators to talk of the situation resembling a military coup.

I do not seek to alarm the Australian public about the situation in Indonesia, but I want to highlight the fact that our neighbour is politically unstable and facing huge economic challenges. The real income of the average Indonesian has dropped by 80 per cent since July 1997. More than a quarter of all Indonesian children have dropped out of school because their parents cannot afford the fees, books and uniforms. International aid agencies estimate that up to half of all Indonesian children will grow up weak, small in stature, subject to ongoing health problems and intellectually incapacitated. These are the hidden effects of the so-called Asian crisis. Indonesia is in fact in crisis. Against the background of this economic crisis, the political instability and volatility that I have referred have been thrown into sharp relief. The dire economic situation only exacerbates the political tensions within that country.

The military is manoeuvring on all fronts to shore up its position. At this very moment ABRI is forcing through the Indonesian parliament the state security bill, which is designed to radically enhance its own powers. This bill grants the military unlimited authority in a state of emergency, which in turn remains legally undefined. It allows for incarceration without trial and the abolition of press freedoms. In fact, it bears strong resemblance to the subversion law of 1963, only revoked last year in the wake of the former President's resignation.

According to an email I received from Muchtar Pakpahan—the leader of the Indonesian Prosperity Workers Union, SBSI, who was imprisoned by Suharto—this new security bill is to be almost the last act of the current parliament in Indonesia. It is intended to entrench the position of the military in politics before the new, more reformist parliament comes in on 3 October.

The current political and economic situation is indeed a tragedy for Indonesia, but it is also a matter of grave concern to this country. We will have to make an urgent and thoroughgoing reassessment of our relationship with the new Indonesian regime which is emerging. We have to reassess some of our approaches in terms of our defence and foreign policy postures within the region. It is important for us to face the new uncertainties in our region.

While I do not regard Indonesia as a military or security threat to Australia and, like most Australians, I remain committed to building and maintaining a sound, constructive, positive relationship with Indonesia and other countries within the region, I have absolutely no time for the jingoism and the xenophobia that is being peddled in some sections of our media. I think it is important, however, that we view the situation in an objective manner and that we do appreciate the difficulties and the volatility of the present political and economic climate within the region. At all times, however, our sympathy and our focus must be on humanitarianism and on the crying needs of the people of Indonesia in their time of trouble.

For the people of East Timor it is hard at this moment to envisage the peaceful, democratic and prosperous future that we all hope for on their behalf. It is important for us to continually work with them to achieve this goal. Their country is in ruins as a result of the orgy of destruction that many have noted this evening. I must say that I am of the view that this situation was preventable. The calls for peacekeepers and for a delay in the ballot until there was stability in East Timor fell on deaf ears. The East Timorese knew what was going to happen. Many could have taken steps to help the people in East Timor, but there was a failure by this government to pay heed to their desperate pleas. The Australian government's ineptitude in these matters has not served this country well—nor the people of Indonesia, nor people of East Timor.

The latest brutality in East Timor is only one event in a long 24-year nightmare that most of us in Australia would find difficult to imagine, given our secure and peaceful lives. No family in East Timor is untouched, if not ravaged, by death and misfortune at the hands of the Indonesian military forces. The tenacity, resolve and the spirit of the people of East Timor—and the fact that they have never given up—are inspiring in themselves. When peace is finally restored and when forced refugees are brought safely back to their homeland from West Timor and elsewhere, then we as Australians must commit ourselves to working side by side with our brothers and sisters in East Timor to help them rebuild their country. This must be a high policy priority for all the parties within this parliament in Australia. We owe the East Timorese nothing less.

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to support this historic motion on East Timor. Even though it is supported unanimously and even though the tragic history of East Timor has been covered by different governments and different administrations, it is a shame that partisan comments have crept into the debate. It is fair to say, though, that all Australians have been both dismayed and horrified at the unacceptable violence and brutality of the militia towards the East Timorese. To the extent that it was aided and abetted by the Indonesian military, who totally failed to prevent these outrages against a defenceless people, history will be the judge.

speech.para: It is particularly poignant that a small and vulnerable community in fact terrorised by this outrage merely wanted to have their independence—and I have made a note here that 78.6 per cent of the East Timorese voted for independence. On any measure of decency owed to other human beings in distress, the terror simply could not go unchecked. It is undoubtedly a reflection of our national will that Australia should have played the role that it has in negotiating a United Nations mandated multinational peacekeeping force. Australians can be justifiably proud of the fact that, in March this year, the government raised the readiness of a second brigade sized force to 28 days notice to move. This has permitted Australia to respond immediately to the United Nations' request to both participate in and lead the multinational force.

Many speakers today have already expressed our gratitude, affection and admiration for those Australians, be they in the armed forces, in the Australian Federal Police or other Australians involved in the United Nations effort. We are proud of you and what you are doing on our behalf. Similarly, the historical, strategic and future implications for our region and our relations with near neighbours, including Indonesia, have been discussed, and I do not propose to canvass these issues as well.

What I do want to speak about briefly has been the subject of many hundreds of letters and emails received in my electorate office—that is, what Australia is doing by way of humanitarian effort. There is no doubt that those Australians who took the trouble to make their views known were and are genuinely distressed at the plight of those dispossessed East Timorese in both East and West Timor. Most understood that, in the absence of a negotiated agreement, it was not possible to either commit Australian troops to East Timor or conduct relief flights over Indonesian airspace in West Timor.

However, it is now possible to undertake a range of humanitarian initiatives. We are faced with a humanitarian crisis of almost inestimable proportions. The violence and terror has generated a crisis in East and West Timor through the displacement of hundreds of thousands of people. It is simply impossible to estimate accurately how many East Timorese people have been displaced within and outside East Timor, but the total could be 400,000 or even more.

Australia, I am pleased to say, has taken the lead in assisting United Nations agencies to get humanitarian assistance to where it is most needed in the shortest possible time. To that end, we have already made an initial commitment of $A3 million. Darwin has become the jump-off point for international relief operations. Australian funded food drops to East Timor began on 17 September, using RAAF planes, crews and logistical support, and will continue, as necessary. Australia is also providing warehouse facilities in Darwin for Australian and international relief supplies with one being used as a logistic centre.

The plight of displaced East Timorese in West Timor is also of enormous concern to Australia's humanitarian effort. Australia is supporting fully efforts by the international community to gain access to displaced East Timorese in West Timor, which remains logistically and extremely difficult. Australian aid to United Nations and other international relief agencies will help support their operations in West Timor. INTERFET will be doing its utmost to create a secure environment in East Timor in which the East Timorese feel safe to return from across the border.

In addition, the Australian government has evacuated around 1,450 people from East Timor under Operation Safe Haven. These are made up of around 1,350 East Timorese internally displaced people—primarily, I should say, women and young children who are not in good condition; at least many of the children are not—75 UNAMET ex-patriot staff, who are mainly Australians and New Zealanders, and 40 UNAMET locally engaged staff and their families.

The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs is the lead agency for both visa and relevant processing and settlement, and Emergency Management Australia, part of the Department of Defence, is working closely with the Northern Territory government and many other agencies in relation to logistical support, and Senator Tambling outlined some of that logistical support being provided in his territory.

Upon arrival in Darwin, evacuees have been transferred to the Marrara Sports Stadium for initial health checks, quarantine checks and immigration clearance before moving to the reception centre where they will settle temporarily. After initial health checks and processing in temporary accommodation in Darwin, the East Timorese will go to existing safe havens that were set up for the Kosovar evacuees in Puckapunyal in Victoria, Leeuwin in Western Australia and East Hills in New South Wales.

Over last weekend the first group of East Timorese were transferred to Puckapunyal. Further transfers will occur in the coming weeks, with dates being determined largely by medical processing times and the fitness and condition of the evacuees. I must say that I look forward to welcoming those who are sheltered in New South Wales.

The services available to the East Timorese are the same as the services provided recently to the Kosovars, which include: accommodation; culturally appropriate food and diet; torture and trauma counselling; clothing suitable to the climate that they are in; medical, dental and nursing facilities; basic education for children; a small allowance of $27 for those aged over 12 years and $10 for children under 12 to cover some personal items; phone cards; English language classes; the availability of translators; and appropriate religious services.

Staff have been working closely with the East Timorese community in Australia to ensure that the evacuees move into an envi ronment that is as comfortable and suitable as possible, given the conditions under which they have been living. All signage, for instance, within the havens has been translated to assist residents. Haven residents will be free to come and go from the havens, and the East Timorese are able to stay with relatives or friends outside the haven, provided they will then, in those circumstances, be responsible for their own financial support. It is certainly hoped that most will remain within the havens, simply because it is thought that they are mostly likely to avail themselves of some of these services if they are actually on the premises or in close proximity.

The East Timorese will be given temporary safe haven visas for an initial period of three months, which will be extended if circumstances require. They will not be required to return home until it is safe and they can return with dignity. As with the Kosovars, the government will extend limited work rights to the East Timorese if they cannot return home in the near future. We are, for the East Timorese, repeating the successful formula used recently for the Kosovar refugees that did indeed receive I think almost unanimous community support.

I did wish to place these matters on the record during this debate because it has been the primary concern of so many constituents who have contacted our electorate offices over the past couple of weeks. It demonstrates Australia's ongoing commitment to meeting the acute humanitarian needs of the East Timorese. The East Timorese have paid a terrible price for their choice for independence and it is now up to the international community to make sure that those who paid with their blood did not die in vain.

Australia is ready to assist, including through reconstruction and development. We have long been the largest provider of development aid and development assistance in East Timor, and this will continue. Australia will be there to assist the East Timorese in the long process of recovery, including achieving reconciliation amongst the East Timorese people themselves. This is necessary to consolidate Australia's regional standing and influence. It is also about building the future for all Timorese and for Australian-Indonesian relations and, indeed, for our own security and stability in the region. I commend the motion to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —I join with the Senate to express our heartfelt emotions and deepest thoughts for our soldiers on their mission to protect the East Timorese people. How obvious it is that these soldiers are carrying on a proud tradition of our armed forces. Like the diggers of old, when questioned on their task, they laconically answer, `We are going to do the job for which we are trained.' Though very late, as our soldiers headed to Dili there was a sense of finally fulfilling our war debt—a debt that matched what we owed the fuzzy wuzzy angels in Papua New Guinea, for the East Timorese in the Second World War helped and sheltered our soldiers at the cost of their own lives.

speech.para: No-one can doubt the world-class level to which our soldiers are trained and equipped. Their early securing of Dili is proof enough. In words, their mission is to go into East Timor to restore peace and stability and to facilitate humanitarian aid. They are also to protect and support the United Nations in supervising the peaceful transition to independence of the territory. But the soldiers' mission in essence is summed up in today's media pictures being relayed back of fully equipped and armed soldiers acting as guardians for the children in the streets.

The reason Australia has taken the responsibility of heading up an international peace force is plain for the world to see. It was the total failure of the Indonesian forces to control the violence and butchery of the innocent by the militia, and indeed the military's own razing and slaughter, which forced Australia to act—regardless of Indonesia's indignation at their nearest neighbour's action.

In the end, this is a moral issue. It is not one directly affecting Australia's sovereignty or welfare. Rather it is all about the defence of a people seeking a just freedom, achieving an infant democracy, then having it brutally snuffed out. And the world in force is with us. Anyone who believes the collapse of the Berlin Wall was a miracle can believe that East Timor's freedom is a miracle. Given all that was involved in East Timor's fight for freedom, and though the path to freedom has been bloody, strewn with martyrs, and so often bewildering, the fact that we have arrived at this point is phenomenal.

For certain, Australia will be changed forever from this experience. Firstly, in terms of our defence forces, military spending will greatly increase and stay high—not just to maintain our present force in East Timor but to further equip Australia for the now changing regional environment and the new role Australia will play. Secondly, just as defence will take centre stage in Australian politics, so will foreign affairs after so long in the wings. It is certain our relationship with Indonesia will not stay the same. It will be chilled for some time to come. It was inevitable that our relationship with Jakarta would be damaged when Jakarta itself left us with no choice but to choose between good relations at any cost or a free East Timor. We chose a free East Timor.

It is not surprising that Jakarta is stunned by our choice as since the invasion of East Timor in 1975 Australian foreign policy had clearly signalled that when push came to shove we would always place good relations with Jakarta ahead of an independent East Timor. To this end I believe the military establishment had calculated that Australia's reaction to the mayhem post election would be along the lines of past policy. Therefore it is a fair conclusion that the military's urging on of the militia to violate people and property was aimed at the military re-establishing sovereign authority over the province, firstly, by provoking a reaction from the armed Fretilin fighters in the surrounding hills and therefore creating a situation of civil war not dissimilar to 1975 and, secondly, that the world would not react beyond diplomacy to the mayhem created in East Timor given past history. On both counts they were wrong.

The Fretilin fighters under order of Xanana Gusmao did not retaliate even in the face of the bloodbath. Consider how difficult this must have been looking down on Dili to see nuns, priests, women and children slaughtered inside churches. And the Indonesian military may have been right in regard to the world reaction, except they miscalculated Australia's tangible reaction beyond the diplomatic channels. Australia's strength counteracted the dark side of the plotters—that is, the militia and the armed forces—and that strength has saved hundreds of thousands of lives and a country.

Much has been said that Australia should have and could have arranged for a UN peacekeeping force to go into East Timor before the ballot so as to prevent any post-ballot retribution. There is no doubt that the result of the ballot was predictable as was the militia reaction to the result. I refer the Senate to a speech I made on 19 April this year following the Liquica massacre in which I stated:

The history of East Timor under Indonesian rule shows that such bloodbaths are never the product of rogue elements. If Jakarta does not orchestrate it, then it is unhindered by Jakarta. The turn of events in East Timor places the country in grave danger of sliding into civil war with, consequently, the abandonment of the independent process—which of course is the prime aim of the militia. There is no doubt that following the abandonment of the independence process there would be an even greater suppression and slaughter of the population.

But even with this knowledge, three factors need to be kept in mind: firstly, the utter betrayal of Jakarta's commitment to the United Nations and directly to Australia to keep the peace; secondly, the sheer magnitude of the atrocities could not be predicted; and, thirdly, the United Nations Security Council was not prepared to support such a force at this time with Russia and China indicating the use of their veto. Tragically we know the price of the failure on all three points.

Australia, though ready itself to send a force, was diplomatically incapacitated. The United Nations made the decision that the ballot should go ahead on schedule. As the UN Secretary-General said, if the United Nations had not accepted a ballot in the circumstances available, the ballot probably would not have happened. In a fine judgment we thought it was not right to take that ballot away from the East Timorese.

For one shining moment the people of East Timor inspired the world as they dressed up to go down to the polling booth for the first time and vote for independence in a peaceful democratic way—something in Australia we take for granted. While we can all pore over the intricacies of this sorry matter starting 25 years ago when the Australian government first waved through the Indonesian invasion and subsequent governments' justification and acceptance of the invasion and all its consequences or we can pore over the intricacies leading to the tragedies coming out of East Timor of late, we must never forget that the Indonesian administration and military are to blame, not us. The end point is that we are in there protecting and the land under our guardianship will be safe and free. While we do not fully know the dangers ahead, we do know our responsibilities and Australia can proudly say, `We are prepared.' We are prepared militarily, we are prepared diplomatically, we are prepared economically and, above all, we are prepared morally.

As we now bury the old constructive engagement policy with Indonesia and formulate a new frank engagement, it is worth now burying many of the errors and myths of the past. Firstly, `the Portuguese were bad colonisers'. Well, they did not leave East Timor in the state of destruction and misery it is in today.
