Further, `Portugal will be contributing infrastructure funds and expertise to rebuild East Timor into the future'. I have no doubt about the genuine warmth the Portuguese have for the East Timorese.

Secondly, `the purpose of the 1975 invasion and the subsequent holding of East Timor by the Indonesians was due to the threat of communism as symbolised by the Fretilin movement'. The truth is that the faith of these people is mutually exclusive to such a regime. All they ever sought was democracy even at the price of martyrdom. And how this faith sustained them in their darkest hour.

Thirdly, `Australia had to prove itself within the South-East Asian region and how we doubted our standing'. This culture grew up within the foreign affairs department, breeding a relationship of appeasement with our nearest neighbour. It was a policy designed to get close to the long-serving Suharto regime to win their confidence. We would therefore be in a position to influence the regime in areas of political, social and economic reform to the advantage of the interests of Australia. Yet, for all this neighbourly bonding, we seem to have gained very little. While carried out in the name of national interest, in the end it was found to be nothing more than a doctrine of feebleness that reaped what it sowed.

In conclusion, it is amazing how this little country has captured the world's imagination with its quest for freedom and fever of faith. But just as East Timor needs us to protect it, maybe we need East Timor to remind us of the value of our safe democracy and to inspire our faith.

talk.start.para: —We are now just past the eighth hour of this debate. Many have made contributions, and I would particularly like to acknowledge the contribution of Senator Bourne which I heard earlier when presiding in the chair. Fortunately, this is a very rare motion that comes before the parliament. It deals with the support of Australia's contribution to and leadership of a United Nations force that is being sent to East Timor of around probably 4,500 troops, not just in a peacekeeping capacity but almost certainly in a peacemaking capacity and almost certainly, I believe, for a long time.

speech.para: I would like to personally take the opportunity to make a contribution. There may be something new in what I say, but I have had the opportunity to visit both East Timor and West Timor. I have had a long interest of participation and involvement in the East Timor groups, particularly on the north-west coast of my home state of Tasmania. I have a more than passing interest in history. I wish to deal with some of the issues, both past and present, as well as look at some of the future challenges Australia will face because of what has occurred in East Timor.

Firstly, I would like to place on record my very best wishes to the men and women in the peacekeeping force who have gone to East Timor. I think this is the first occasion that women in our armed services will be serving in what is a very dangerous situation which could possibly verge on warfare. So my best goes to the men and women and also to their families who are left behind in Australia. I do look forward to their safe return. I would also like to pay public tribute to a very small and very dedicated group, the Coastal East Timor Group, and the local secretary, Barry Hibbard, whom I have known for some 10 years. As I said, it is a very small group, but without his ongoing commitment and dedication I am sure that the issue of East Timor, at least on the north-west coast of Tasmania, would not have had the attention it has received.

As I said earlier, I had the opportunity in 1990 to visit both West and East Timor. The visit was interesting for the contrast between the two provinces. On visiting West Timor, you were immediately struck by a province that was commercially thriving, where the people certainly appeared happy and content and where there was relatively little military presence in evidence. Crossing the border into East Timor, it was a totally different environment. It was then a province of Indonesia that was almost totally undeveloped commercially. The only industry of any kind was basic subsistence agriculture and some commercial plantations, which interestingly used to be run by the Portuguese and were taken over by the Indonesian military. They had a direct commercial stake in East Timor.

talk.start.para: —And the marble factory.

—I was just about to mention that, Senator Macdonald. Senator Macdonald was also on that delegation. The only manufacturing industry at all in East Timor was a marble quarry and factory. That was the only industry that existed. I understand that things have not changed greatly in the last nine years. The other very obvious issue was the dominance of the Indonesian military in East Timor. It was extremely obvious. It struck me as being a military camp.

speech.para: If we look back on the history of East Timor, for the first 425 years it was a Portuguese colony, so there was the establishment of a very distinct history and culture from the Portuguese East Indies. It was a brutal colonial regime. That was followed very briefly by the Japanese occupation from 1942 to 1945 and the very valuable assistance the East Timorese gave to the Australian troops, a number of hundred of whom were in East Timor at that stage and who were assisted whilst the Japanese occupied the country. I might say that the Japanese brutalised the population of East Timor for the assistance they provided to those Australian troops.

In 1975 there was the military occupation by Indonesia with the tacit approval of Australia and, I believe, with the direct approval of the United States. I do not think it was just coincidence that President Ford and his foreign policy adviser, Mr Kissinger, were in the country the day before Indonesia occupied East Timor. In the last two weeks there has been a further example of the horrific brutality of at least part of the Indonesian military and militias.

In looking at the past as a member of a Labor government, at least in my time in this Senate since 1990, we do have to look very hard and critically and reflect on the role of not just the government I was a part of but previous governments—Liberal, National and Labor. We have to seriously question ourselves as to whether we could and should have done more and whether the events of the last two weeks could have been avoided.

It amazes me that a people can suffer so much over 450 years and then, given the opportunity in the past few months to vote in the first democratic election that they have ever participated in, have a 98 per cent voluntary turnout and an 80 per cent vote in support of independence—and that was in an atmosphere of total terror, killing and intimidation in the lead-up to the referendum. It is a wonderful example of the human spirit and an amazing testimony to the human spirit to be free that, despite all that horrific suffering and intimidation, particularly in the last 25 years, they were willing to vote in such overwhelming numbers with such an overwhelming desire for independence.

Before I turn to the events of the last two weeks, we need to draw an important distinction between the events leading up to the Indonesian occupation of East Timor in 1975 and the difficulties that Indonesia faces in other provinces of Indonesia such as Aceh and Irian Jaya. After World War II, when we had a very significant period of decolonisation, it was an accepted principle that colonial boundaries would be respected and that colonies would have the right of self-determination. That was an accepted principle for fairly obvious reasons: if you started readjusting the boundaries of colonies, it would lead to very significant problems.

As far as I can determine, there are only a few occasions when that principle has not been put into practice. One is obviously East Timor. Another is the former colony of Goa, interestingly a former Portuguese colony which I think was invaded by India in 1949, though certainly not in the same brutal way as Indonesia invaded East Timor. The ongoing treatment of the people of Goa has obviously not been anywhere near as brutal, as I understand it. There were two other former colonies: the Spanish Sahara, where there is an ongoing war of independence, and Eritrea, where there has been a revolution for the past 25 years against Ethiopia and their independence has finally been accepted. They are the only four examples where the colonial boundaries and the right to self-determination have not been accepted and acted on by the world community.

The argument is often put that former colonies of the small size and population and the poor level of resources of East Timor cannot survive independently without great difficulty and struggle. Frankly, this is a nonsense argument. It is a nonsense argument for people to be incorporated against their will, as has occurred with East Timor, in the name of stability and anticommunism, as happened at the time of the incorporation, and yet for them to have suffered for the last 24 years in the name of stability and anticommunism. We have to reflect that, if they had obtained their independence at that time, the level of suffering of the people would have been significantly less than has occurred under Indonesian occupation. At least if East Timor had been independent, made mistakes and had to struggle, the mistakes they undoubtedly would have made would have been their own mistakes. It is a totally paternalistic argument to put forward that former colonies of the size of East Timor should be incorporated within the broader nation state. If people want to be free, they have the right to be free and we should respect that.

We had the referendum two weeks ago. There was, however, some clear intention three or four months ago that at least part of the Indonesian military was planning a systematic ethnic cleansing of East Timor if its people voted for independence. Indeed, we have had public utterances from some Indonesian generals that that is exactly what they intended to do through the militias that they had established. There has been some comment in this debate, as there should have been, about the intelligence warnings that were given to the bureaucrats, particularly in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and to our political leadership. It is quite legitimate in this debate—and Senator Hogg and Senator Cook have touched on it—to criticise a policy failure by the government of the day where there has been a policy failure. It is the role and duty of an opposition to point out that policy failure. It is only by learning from those mistakes and correcting them, particularly when there are 4,500 Australian troops at risk fighting overseas, that those policy failures can be accepted, acknowledged and corrected.

As I said earlier, with the events of the past two weeks we have seen a planned campaign of ethnic cleansing implemented by the militias, who are the frontmen of some of the Indonesian military. Of course, it is interesting that the military did not want to get their hands bloody directly. We have seen this campaign of bloodshed perpetrated against the people of East Timor who Indonesia claim are their own people. I would contend that, in the way Indonesia has behaved in East Timor in the last few weeks, it has lost any vestige of moral or political claim that it could have had in East Timor.

I would also like to acknowledge the very deep strength of the Australian people in the last few weeks. Again, it has been wonderful to see the response of the Australian people—their recognition of the repression and the horror in East Timor and their determination to ensure that the democratic will as expressed in the referendum for independence is upheld. I also understand there have been significant demonstrations of support in Portugal. I hope that is followed through with significant financial and practical support to assist the East Timorese and to offset at least to some extent Portugal's neglect, over the 425 years prior to Indonesian military occupation, of its most distant colony. I would also express concern for what I understand is now some 200,000 refugees in West Timor and other parts of Indonesia. If Australia and other countries had not expressed outrage at what was going on in Indonesia, I do not think many of those 200,000 would have survived, and those that had survived either disease or starvation would have been transplanted somewhere else in Indonesia.

This may be a protracted military commitment. I would pose a couple of questions. What happens if the Indonesian parliament rejects East Timor's independence? If it does accept that independence, what happens if it—tacitly, at least—aids militias in their terrorist activities across the border between West and East Timor? No-one would suggest, and no-one has suggested, that any United Nations and Australian military activity can enter into West Timor or any other part of Indonesia—nor should they. I suspect that Australian troops and other UN forces will need to be in East Timor for a significant period of time to defend the developing free republic of East Timor. That will have my personal, ongoing support.

I would like to conclude by touching on a few issues for the future. We should not be blaming the people of Indonesia for what has occurred. I notice there has been some attempt to whip up nationalist fervour on the streets of Indonesian cities. I suspect in part that has to do with the forthcoming election for the new President of Indonesia. I do not believe Australia has—and I do not have—any ill will whatsoever towards the Indonesian people. They are going through their own struggle for democracy. I just hope that the new leadership of Indonesia is able to bring the military, in particular, under some control and to some form of accountability for what has happened.

Whatever happens in Indonesia, I do not believe Australia can have any ongoing military relationship whatsoever with Indonesia for the foreseeable future and certainly in the next five or 10 years. We need to maintain a relationship with the new government that emerges in Jakarta but, at the same time, we need to recognise and respect our own clear cultural and democratic differences. We will need to provide military support and protection to the developing republic of East Timor in the event of Indonesia accepting East Timorese independence not just in words and on paper but by clearly following through with actions to prevent terrorist activity by militias. I also believe there should be a war crimes tribunal established to bring to account the military, some of which engaged in the activities planned and implemented over the last few weeks. We will need a very significant and ongoing aid and assistance program to East Timor. There is literally nothing there; there is nothing left. That program will need to occur, and Portugal should be a major contributor, along with the rest of the international community. Australia has a very major commitment to make there and, again, it will probably be for at least 10 to 15 years.

We should re-establish the Cox Peninsula transmitter to ensure that what is occurring in East Timor—and, for that matter, in other parts of the world—is freely transmitted not just to Indonesia but to other parts of Asia. We will also have to re-examine our defence priorities, particularly in light of the US reluctance to engage more directly and extensively in East Timor. In part, I can understand the US reluctance, given the problems of Australian policy implementation. But we are in a pretty lonely world at the edge of Asia, and that requires a re-examination of defence priorities. We need to re-examine our migration and population policy with a view to significantly increasing our migration. In 25 years the population of Australia will start declining on current population projections. Where that leaves us in the world, particularly in Asia, has very important implications.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —After hearing from more than 30 senators in the debate today, there is not a lot more that I can add in support of the motion before the Senate. My colleagues on this side of the chamber have very carefully and sensitively canvassed most of the issues pertinent to the debate, and I concur with most of what my Liberal Senate colleagues have said.

speech.para: I must also congratulate Senator Sherry on what I think was a very balanced and thoughtful speech. Senator Sherry reminds me of my visit to East and West Timor about nine years ago and of the state of both provinces. His recollections are similar to mine. I recall the stories by locals of the Portuguese regime and—to describe it at its very best—its very wanting governance. I also remember the stories that locals told me of murder and riot as the Portuguese simply walked away from the people of East Timor, leaving them to their own internal turmoil.

I want to congratulate John Howard, Alexander Downer and John Moore on the significant leadership they have shown in the last several months in the interests of the people of Timor and the region generally. I must record, though, that I and many other Australians were disappointed at the arguments of the Labor leader in the other place, Mr Beazley, who used the occasion, which should have been a time for bipartisan support, to enter into a partisan political attack. But I do not want to dwell on that.

I would like to take a short while to focus on the impact of the Timor mission on North Queenslanders. Coming from the north as I do, I recognise that the deployment of soldiers, sailors and airmen from the Australian defence forces to East Timor has a particular significance to the north because Townsville is the home of the 3rd Brigade, the Army's rapid deployment force, 10 Force Support Battalion and the RAAF base Garbutt. A significant slice of the INTERFET peacekeeping force comes from these units from Townsville. Townsville has been described as a `garrison town'. It is that and more. It is certainly true that the defence forces are a special part of our community and, as a community, Townsville feels very deeply the peacekeeping responsibilities Australia has taken on.

The commander of the Townsville based 3rd Brigade, Brigadier Mark Evans, is commanding the Australian contingent and we wish him well in his very significant responsibility. He is just one of many Townsville soldiers and airmen of all ranks contributing to this force in East Timor, and they are all leaving behind spouses, children, parents and other relatives. Like Brigadier Evans's children, many Townsville children will be spending their current school holidays wondering just what dad or mum is doing in East Timor and hoping for their safe return. Families from many other places in Australia will be facing the same mixed emotions of pride, trepidation and concern for loved ones.

Because of this unique sense of community with our local forces, it is with some pride that I recount that two Townsville radio personalities, Steve Price and Dave Harrison, have encouraged the North Queensland community to publicly demonstrate their support for the deployed forces by flying or displaying the Australian flag in their windows for as long as our troops are in Timor. This is a positive and constructive idea from two Townsville media personalities. They mirror northern sentiment by recognising just how important the men and women of the ADF are not only to Townsville but to the wider Australian community. The member for Herbert, Peter Lindsay, and I have been honoured to have been part of this campaign by providing the flags for the cause. I commend this idea from radio station 4TO. Perhaps other senators and members and their local community groups, businesses and media outlets would consider similar initiatives in their home towns.

It is true that Australia has not been traditionally a nation of flag wavers. We have always preferred more measured and private forms of patriotism, but this initiative which puts a focus on our national flag as proposed by the radio station in Townsville is, I believe, an appropriate recognition not only of the community support for the ADF but also of the leadership role Australia has taken on in our region. The good will is not just confined to Townsville or to public personalities. In Bowen, about 100 kilometres south of my home in Ayr, a local group held a rally at which they sold yellow ribbons and raised, I understand, in a very short period some $400 for the International Red Cross humanitarian relief effort in East Timor, while simultaneously recognising the deployment of our ADF personnel. Bowen is, like many other communities in Australia, wanting to do something, wanting to show support. Bowen is a community not without its own difficulties, but that community has shown with this rally a generosity that characterises the Australian spirit. It is befitting of the spirit with which our troops deploy to East Timor.

In Townsville tonight, civic leaders, the ADF support personnel and major religious denominations are banding together to host a candlelight vigil and remembrance service for the community and families of the ADF people in Townsville and East Timor. The leaders behind these gestures would all be encouraged by the positive attitude of the deployed forces and, notwithstanding recent events in East Timor, by the mature and positive approach taken by TNI forces on the arrival of INTERFET.

Australia is a very firm supporter of Indonesia's democratic transformation. We have demonstrated good will towards Indonesia over many years, starting with the support for Indonesia's struggle for independence. Clearly, there have been strains on our relationship with Indonesia in the immediate past but, despite this, Australia's long-term approach to our near northern neighbour has not changed.

We continue to believe that Indonesia is vital to the stability and prosperity of the region, and we have no interest in undermining Indonesia or the peoples of Indonesia. It is for this reason, amongst others, that we wanted to see the East Timor problems resolved, preferably with Indonesia's cooperation. I look forward in the not too distant future to a continuation of our extremely close relationships with Indonesia. I hope, along with most other Australians, that the positive signs of the reception of the INTERFET troops in East Timor by TNI are indicative of the future of the deployment and our longer-term relationship with Indonesia. We all hope that more forceful means of fulfilling the UN Security Council's resolution 1264 to restore peace and security in East Timor will not be necessary.

However, should worst come to worst, the families left behind would also be encouraged, as I have been, by the firm leadership taken already by the INTERFET commander, Australian Major General Peter Cosgrove. Without belligerence, Major General Cosgrove has indicated that Australian and other INTERFET troops will be able to respond appropriately to any threat by rogue militias, should the need arise—and the arrest tonight of some militia people outside the airport clearly demonstrates that firmness. Either way, I am sure that our defence forces are up to the challenge that we as a nation have set them. I know that the professionalism of the Townsville based soldiers, sailors and airmen will do Australia proud. I am sure that they will discharge their responsibilities without fear or favour and will set a solid foundation for the long-term cause of good Australian relations with our regional neighbours.

As a historical aside, in looking through some records of Australian service personnel in Timor during World War II, as I know many other senators have also done, I was interested to see that the main units were the 2/40th Battalion of the 8th Division of the AIF, and the 2/2nd Independent Company. The 2/2nd was hand-picked from units throughout the country because those men showed aptitude for the difficult conditions of Timor. Without being too parochial, I was proud to see that the commander of the 2/2nd Independent Company, or Sparrow Force as it was known at one stage, was a Major A. Spence, a regional Queenslander, born in Bundaberg and living in Longreach at the time of his enlistment. He later won the Distinguished Service Order for gallantry in Timor. I am confident that many other Queenslanders—indeed, Australian service men and women from every state and territory—will echo that proud tradition as mem bers of the United Nations peacekeeping force in East Timor.

Tonight I offer, on the public record, my best wishes and those of the Queensland community for the deployed force and the many thousands of unsung supporters behind the scenes who are so necessary to support the front-line troops. Above all, I offer our support to the families left behind. One quite astute but anonymous local pointed out in the Townsville media recently that we should not allow the families to slip from our thoughts as this deployment slides off the front pages of the newspapers in times to come. The families maintain their commitment to their loved ones throughout the deployment, and it is essential that community support for them should also be ongoing. The tiny gesture of flying the national flag in home and shop windows—promoted in Townsville—will serve to remind us of our troops and the East Timorese people they are helping, until such time as the service men and women are able to return safely home. I commend the motion to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of Senator Ellison, I seek leave to have the text of his speech in support of the motion incorporated in the Hansard record of this debate.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
Speech by Senator Christopher Ellison, Special Minister of State
Motion relating to East Timor, Wednesday, 21 September 1999

Mr Acting Deputy President, all Australians would deplore the bloodshed in East Timor recently where Indonesian militias have reigned unchecked against the civilian population. Although it is gratifying to see the Senate overwhelmingly support the Government's motion this evening it is unfortunate that the Opposition has chosen to attempt political mileage during such a time as this.
Before I address the current situation it is worthwhile to look at the history of the relationship between East Timor and Australia.
Australia's history is to some extent bound up with the Timorese people, and especially with the people of the Eastern half of that island.

In 1942 on Timor, the 2/2 and 2/4 Independent Companies fought an incredible rearguard action against an overwhelming Japanese invasion force. The Australian contingent which was known as Sparrow Force was isolated and the guerilla war that resulted rivals the much better known exploits of the Australian forces on the Kokoda Trail.
As Christopher Wray, the author of Timor 1942, points out:

"The Timorese were impressed by the skill and bravery shown by the Australians in fighting the Japanese and provided them with great assistance . . . Like all guerilla armies, Sparrow force needed the support of the local population to operate successfully. Without this, the ability to remain an effective fighting force or even survive would have been placed in doubt. . . Each soldier soon acquired a Timorese servant who carried his pack and other non military equipment and who would quickly lead him to safety after an attack on the Japanese"
For their support of Sparrow Force, the Timorese paid a very high price. Thousands of them were killed by enemy forces because of their assistance to the Australians.
Two generations later, Australian troops have returned to East Timor. Many Australians would know or have a relative serving in the peace-keeping force.
Indeed, I have a nephew who is serving on HMAS ANZAC and I look forward to him and his colleagues returning safely to Australia to join their loved ones.
I know that all Australians are proud of the Australian men and women who have been joined by international forces in East Timor.

The level of expertise and training of our service personnel is truly remarkable. They handle some of the most sophisticated equipment in the world's armory, and they maintain that famous elan that is the hallmark of Australia's troops throughout a century of conflict.

I know I speak for everyone here today when I say to them that we are proud of the way they are doing their duty and that they have our complete support. Nobody should consider that this will be a soft assignment.
The peace must first be made, before it can be kept—and neither operation is without risk. It is up to all Australians to maintain their support and will during this difficult task.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I speak today as someone who has had an interest in East Timor for sometime. In June 1995, I attended a conference in Portugal in relation to the situation in East Timor. Historically that year, Indonesian Officials met with East Timorese representatives however it was to be another four years before a ballot for self-determination was to take place.

Of course, more recently history has not been as inspiring as that during the War which I have mentioned. Both sides of politics have reluctantly acquiesced in Indonesia's occupation of East Timor, however the Labor Party is now in the process of trying to rewrite history. It is trying to forget that it was Gough Whitlam who encouraged the Indonesians to invade East Timor in 1975.
A quote of Gough Whitlam in the House on 26 August 1975 reads:

"We, for our part, understand Indonesia's concern that the territory should not be allowed to become a source of instability on Indonesia's border. Portuguese Timor is in many ways part of the Indonesian world and its future is obviously a matter of great importance to Indonesia"

Gareth Evans, a former Foreign Affairs Minister declared that the incorporation of East Timor into Indonesia was irreversible" and described expatriate East Timorese in Australia as "a recurring irritant".
As I have said, there was a reluctant acquiescence on both sides of politics and I do not deny that for one moment; Australia sat on its hands for too long.

Of course we now have former Keating Cabinet ministers criticising the Government but what did they ever do to help the East Timorese? It is indeed sad to see the Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, trying to score political points during a time when all Australians should be putting their full support behind our peacekeeping efforts.

It is all very easy for the Opposition to say we should have sent troops earlier. As early as May this year the Prime Minister approached President Habibie with regard to a peace keeping force however that was rejected.

President Habibie agreed to a ballot, after 24 years of occupation and unsuccessful attempts to assimilate East Timor into Indonesia. This was a courageous decision on his part as there was much opposition in his country to this.
The subsequent ballot was free, fair and overwhelmingly representative of the views of East Timorese—78.5% of East Timorese voted for independence.

I must say that in relation to the poll, the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) both performed sterling roles in assisting the UN to conduct the vote—the former in Timor, and the latter in Australia. As the Minister responsible for the AEC, I can say that it has played a great role in the region in assisting in elections.

Prior to the ballot it was just not possible to send in a peacekeeping force without Indonesia's consent. As we have already heard today, even the Leader of the Opposition has previously expressed the view, on a number of occasions prior to the ballot, that peacekeeping forces were neither practical nor necessary.
This Government, however, did attempt to increase the UN police presence prior to the ballot. Most importantly, we brought two army brigades up to 24 hour readiness for a peace keeping role.
It was only after the ballot that sufficient international support could be mustered to bring about the peacekeeping force we have today.

We have been recognised as the leaders on this issue—we now have international support and are playing the key role in bringing East Timor to independence. The role of the Prime Minister, Foreign Affairs Minister, Alexander Downer, and Defence Minister, John Moore, has been pivotal.
We are not anti-Indonesian, we are not anti-Asian but we are pro democracy.
Just last week in my home State, the Australia-Asia Association overwhelmingly expressed its support for the Howard Government's handling of the East Timor situation.
We want to work with Indonesia for a peaceful future not just in East Timor, but in the region.

I have no doubt that the UN peacekeeping force will perform its job with great distinction but East Timor needs more than that. The economy of East Timor is in ruins. The cities and towns of East Timor are deserted at best—looted and burnt at worst.
Rebuilding will require a large amount of money and this Government, in concert with other nations and International bodies, will not shirk its responsibility on this matter.
Rebuilding East Timor is more than just bricks and mortar.
There is a huge diaspora of East Timorese that must be successfully returned—including a large number forcibly evicted in recent times by pro-integrationist militia.
We cannot allow a de facto hostage population to be maintained. In this, we will require the assistance of Indonesia.
Everyone is aware of the prominent role that the Church has played in the lives of ordinary East Timorese, and in their struggle for freedom.
I welcome the day when Archbishop Belo can safely return to East Timor.
Mr Acting Deputy President, the Labor Party should stop trying to score political points. Let us all as Australians put our support behind the peace-keeping efforts in East Timor.
With the grace of God let us hope for the safe return of our service men and women and enduring peace in East Timor.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the motion on East Timor. It has been supported by all members of the Senate and the House of Representatives who have spoken so far in the debate today.

speech.para: It is extremely important that our troops as they go to East Timor—and those who have already arrived—know that they go with our total, absolute support. Their mission is to uphold the fundamental principles of human rights. That is a noble mission, and it is a mission that must be carried out. It falls to our armed forces to do that not just on behalf of the Australian people but, indeed, on behalf of the international community. It is therefore important that this parliament express its overwhelming, total and absolute support for their mission.

In doing so, we reflect upon our commitment to the principles of justice, freedom, security, democracy and the rule of law. In taking this action under the auspices of the United Nations, we demonstrate our commitment to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. The United Nations General Assembly adopted that declaration in 1948. Only last year in December, we celebrated its 50th anniversary. We in the international community at this time are called upon now to back up our commitment with deeds, not just words. The words of that declaration are truly inspiring. Unfortunately, as history, and indeed recent history, has shown, the words have often counted for nought. Just to remind ourselves, it is worth quoting a few sections of the preamble to that Universal Declaration of Human Rights. It states:
. . . recognition of the inherent dignity and of the equal and inalienable rights of all members of the human family is the foundation of freedom, justice and peace in the world

. . . disregard and contempt for human rights have resulted in barbarous acts which have outraged the conscience of mankind, and the advent of a world in which human beings shall enjoy freedom of speech and belief and freedom from fear and want has been proclaimed as the highest aspiration of the common people
. . . it is essential, if man is not to be compelled to have recourse, as a last resort, to rebellion against tyranny and oppression, that human rights should be protected by the rule of law
. . . it is essential to promote the development of friendly relations between nations

. . . the peoples of the United Nations have in the Charter reaffirmed their faith in fundamental human rights, in the dignity and worth of the human person and in the equal rights of men and women and have determined to promote social progress and better standards of life in larger freedom
. . . Member States have pledged themselves to achieve, in co-operation with the United Nations, the promotion of universal respect for and observance of human rights and fundamental freedoms . . .

As I said, they are noble words. Our troops are now actively engaged in giving meaning to those principles. However, if we are to achieve the outcomes contained in those principles for the people of East Timor, it is also important that in this debate we reflect upon how we arrived at this situation—how we arrived at a situation where it is necessary for Australia and the world community to take firm action to rebuild this ravaged country and to protect its innocent people.

During this debate, and indeed in recent days, the government has criticised the opposition for raising real issues of concern about our approach to and involvement in the United Nations conducted ballot. But we must raise them, not to score political points but because we owe it to the people of East Timor and to the people of Australia to examine how and why this tragedy occurred. We cannot just sweep the lives of so many under the carpet and explain it away as an error of judgment or diplomacy. We cannot simply claim that the result of the ballot on 30 August justified the loss of so many innocent people.

Whilst we can today in this debate on this motion take pride in the fact that our troops are now in East Timor to uphold the freedoms which are, as I said, enshrined in that Univer sal Declaration on Human Rights, we must also recognise that mistakes have been made in coming to this situation. The price of freedom is eternal vigilance; it is not the slaughter of many lives and the destruction of a fledgling nation. The oft quoted maxim is true: if we do not learn from the mistakes of history we are condemned to repeat them. If we are going to salvage something out of this carnage, if we are going to really help the people of East Timor and restore their confidence, restore their belief that the rest of the international community will protect them, we must examine these important issues now and in the coming months.

It has been pointed out that there were warnings about the likely catastrophe if the people voted for independence. It has been pointed out that many were calling for a peacekeeping force to be installed in East Timor prior to the ballot on 30 August. Indeed, we recall that the date for the ballot was on a couple of occasions delayed because of the security problems within East Timor. The government's response is that this was tried; that pressure was applied to Indonesia to accept a peacekeeping force prior to the conduct of the ballot, but that they would not agree. It has been stated that it was simply not possible to get Indonesia to accept that proposition. The plain fact is, as events have shown, that we did not try hard enough. The very fact that Indonesia has been forced to accept a peacekeeping force, has been forced to accept the will and the determination of the international community, the pressure particularly from the United States and from the United Nations, demonstrates that, with sufficient pressure, they could well have been put into a position where they would have had to accept it prior to the ballot.

Much has been made of the dogged persistence of the Prime Minister at the APEC meeting in Auckland in pressuring other countries for support. I recognise and pay tribute to the Prime Minister's dogged persistence in those discussions that took place. Much has been made of his determination to pressure Indonesia to accept the peacekeeping force. Much has been made of his dogged persistence to pressure the US into using its influence to get Indonesia to agree to a peacekeeping force. But the question that hangs in the air is—and I do not restrict it just to the Prime Minister—why didn't we try harder before the ballot? Why didn't we see that same dogged persistence and determination evident then? This is not said with the benefit of hindsight. There were numerous warnings, even from the East Timorese leaders, about the dangers of simply relying upon the Indonesian military to respect the result of the ballot and to maintain security.

Today we have heard some government speakers—I recall Senator Newman particularly—who have tried to politicise this debate and deflect criticism from the opposition by claiming that, in our 13 years of government, we never pursued an independence plebiscite. That is true. But, given the aftermath of the recent ballot, I do not think the government should be using that as an argument. I also notice that in recent days the government has endeavoured to make some political capital from this issue by drawing a distinction between their approach to the relationship with Indonesia when they came to office and since and that of the former Labor government. I will not take too much time tonight to debate that at this time, except to draw attention to this government's own white paper on foreign and trade policy, issued in August 1997. I ask government senators and members to read the sections in that white paper on our relationship with Indonesia and the East Timor issue.

talk.start.para: —Why didn't Keating take it to cabinet?

—For the benefit of Senator Heffernan, I will quote from this government's own white paper on foreign and trade policy. This is what the government's own white paper, which was released by Mr Downer and the Hon. Tim Fischer in August 1997, said about our relationship with Indonesia and particularly the East Timor issue. These are the words of this government in its own white paper. I quote from page 62, which says:

speech.para: Australia and Indonesia share significant strategic interests and an expanding structure of consultation and cooperation on strategic issues. This is reflect ed in the historic bilateral Agreement on Maintaining Security, and in the substantial bilateral defence cooperation program. Australia will be working to consolidate and enhance its strategic dialogue with Indonesia.

They are the words of this government's senior representatives, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the then Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Trade, in respect of our relationship on defence, strategic and security matters with Indonesia. The same document says:

Developments in East Timor will remain important in shaping Australian public attitudes towards Indonesia and Indonesia's standing internationally. Australia will continue to encourage the protection of human rights and an internationally acceptable solution to the problem of East Timor, and believes that this would have a positive impact on Indonesia's international relationships. While the overall administration of the Province is primarily a matter for the Indonesian Government to determine, the Australian Government considers that an improved human rights situation, and a greater role in the administration of the Province for indigenous East Timorese would contribute to an overall resolution of the issue.

I invite government senators and members to read the rest of the comments in regard to our relationship with Indonesia in the government's own white paper and to think seriously before they make some of the comments and some of the accusations that they have made in recent days.

Let me also recall the circumstances that have surrounded these events. First of all, we have had, only in a short space of time, the collapse of the Suharto regime in Indonesia. We have had, following that, a movement within Indonesia towards democracy and the holding of elections in that country. However, as we know, the processes of democracy have not yet been completed. They will not be completed until the meeting of the Indonesian parliament in November. We have also seen in that time the relaxation of the imprisonment of the East Timorese leader Xanana Gusmao. We have had also, as a backdrop to this developing situation, the economic collapse in Indonesia.

All of these events happened quickly and, as I said, the process towards democracy in Indonesia is still to be finalised. In such a rapidly changing political and social environment within Indonesia itself caution should have been the guiding maxim. This was indeed urged by East Timorese leaders such as Bishop Belo and Xanana Gusmao.

In all of this we must also look at the role of the United Nations. There is no doubt that the international community must accept responsibility. It was the United Nations that promised the East Timorese that they would be protected. It was the United Nations, the international community, that let them down in their hour of need. The people of East Timor were betrayed. They were told and convinced into believing that if they voted for independence they would be protected. But when the time came to deliver that promise, we—the international community; those with the authority and the power—were unable to deliver on that promise. Sadly, this saga is one more repetition of what has occurred in other countries in recent times—in Rwanda, in Bosnia, in Kosovo and now in East Timor.

People throughout this country and, indeed, throughout the world are legitimately asking the question: why is it that the international community—the powerful nations of this world; the United Nations itself—is always too late to get involved in these situations? Why is it that people are slaughtered, people are dispossessed, people are displaced before the international community finally takes some form of action? The United Nations General Assembly is meeting in New York at this very moment. It must critically examine its role and it must develop ways to give effect to the noble words and principles that it so often espouses. It must find a way to prevent the slaughter of thousands of people, rather than reacting to such events after they have occurred.

As Edmund Burke, the famous liberal, said: it is necessary only for the good man to do nothing for evil to triumph. Unfortunately, evil has prevailed in East Timor whilst the world has watched and done very little. We who are privileged to live in safe democratic countries all share that responsibility.

Let me conclude by reflecting on what we—particularly those of us here in Australia—can do now. Firstly, we have taken a leading role in the peacekeeping force, as we should. Our armed forces will no doubt be a front-line representation of our support for protecting the people and helping to reconstruct this ravaged country. But we must follow this action with other action. We need to continue—and, indeed, increase—our diplomatic pressure on Indonesia and the United Nations to ensure the safety of those refugees now in camps in West Timor. Our efforts in sending in the peacekeepers is only the beginning. We should take steps—as was stated by Senator Cook earlier—to withdraw our recognition of the Indonesian sovereignty over East Timor.

We should also immediately reopen the Cox Peninsula transmission station and restore Radio Australia's services, as was indeed recommended in the Senate Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee's report in April 1997. Unfortunately, the severe cuts to Radio Australia have reduced our opportunities to promote our national interests in this region at a time when we most need that service. There are now many people in Indonesia who are probably hearing only one message—that Australia is only interested in gun-boat diplomacy. If we are to get our message out to the people of the region, to tell them that we do want a constructive and friendly relationship with the people of Indonesia, then Radio Australia is fundamental to that objective.

We also have to be prepared to provide substantial aid and assistance to the people of East Timor, particularly for the rebuilding of the infrastructure that has been laid waste. We also have to be resolute in supporting the efforts by the United Nations Commissioner for Human Rights and others in pursuing the perpetrators of these crimes against humanity.

Finally, I wish to pay a special tribute to those incredibly brave journalists, religious and humanitarian representatives and UNAMET personnel who risked—and in some cases gave—their lives in trying to protect the lives of the East Timorese. I do not think any Australian will ever forget listening to the news reports and watching the footage on TV of those people in the UN compound in Dili as they were terrorised by the militia and the military. If not for those few brave people who remained to give them succour and protection, then many more civilians would no doubt have been slaughtered. Their bravery is now being followed up by our armed forces. We wish them well. We wish their families well, and we pray for their safe return.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the motion moved by Senator Alston. Today the Senate has heard from many speakers about the serious circumstances that confront both Timor and Australia. The speakers before me have touched on many matters of great concern. They have spoken about the horrors that have occurred in East Timor.

speech.para: East Timor itself is situated just some 500 kilometres north-west of Darwin—about the same distance as from Brisbane to a country town called Roma in Queensland. Prior to the current turmoil, the population was around 800,000. East Timor has a long association with Australia; however, 1975 was a watershed for East Timor. In August 1975 the Portuguese colonial government withdrew, and the Revolutionary Front for the Independence of East Timor took control.

Shortly following this, independence occurred in late November 1975. It should have ended there. This was not to be. The annexation of Indonesia followed. Australia literally turned its back on this action, and the struggle in East Timor began. It did not start recently at the ballot box. It has been a long and difficult road, and the East Timorese have had to travel it mostly alone.

This government failed to act quickly for the East Timorese people. It is too easy to blame only the TNI. The East Timorese voted on 30 August 1999 under the eyes of the United Nations. The outcome of the ballot was announced on 4 September 1999. Dili was razed. Some call it `scorched earth'. Labels such as this disguise the true happenings in Dili. The reports that have reached us show a capital sacked and burned, with death and destruction everywhere. People are now hiding in the hills or have been forced into West Timor, and others have fled to Indonesia. It is too easy to describe this terrible result. The true work, the difficult work, is now to secure Timor; restore peace and order; rebuild East Timor; reconstruct schools, hospitals and homes; and pray that the people will return and that there exist facilitative mechanisms to promote this free flow of Timorese back to East Timor.

Our troops are now on the ground in East Timor. It is a difficult task that they face. They have my unqualified support. They will experience first-hand the matters that have been debated tonight in the Senate. There is, however, a question that we as a nation must face in this matter. We have the onerous task of slowly and methodically going over the chain of events that led to this terrible ordeal that descended upon the East Timorese people. We as a nation need to critically examine our role in this. We need to do this as a nation.

If we do not do this, other parties will. Some will draw adverse conclusions about our actions and our capacity to deal with the crises that confront Australia in its international role in its sphere of influence. By way of example, on 14 March 1999, Mr Brereton was saying that Labor had repeatedly called for the Howard government to give an in principle commitment to participate in a United Nations peacekeeping presence in East Timor. Mr Brereton said:

While the transition of East Timor to its future status is underway, it is vital that early international action be initiated to stabilise the situation on the ground and allow East Timorese people to determine their future, free from violence and intimidation.
Shortly after that, on 28 March, Mr Brereton said:

Plans to hold a ballot to decide East Timor's future may prove to be fraught with difficulty, indeed danger, in the absence of a process of disarmament verified by an effective United Nations peace keeping presence.

Mr Brereton's press statements as shadow minister for foreign affairs continued to point to the right path for Australia to take. However, the spirit of cooperation in politics failed. His messages were misinterpreted or bluntly ignored. We now have a force not of peacekeepers, as we really should have, but of soldiers who will need to restore law and order.

Clearly, our troops are there with our utter support. I pray that they will be kept safe. I do know that they are well-trained and capable soldiers. It is incumbent on government to ensure not only that their needs are now catered for but also that their families are not ignored and that they remain firmly in the loop. Efforts need to be made to ensure that good clear lines of communication are maintained for partners and families. In addition, it is necessary that the Minister for Defence reconsider the effect on the ADF of his policy on the fringe benefits tax. Symbols like this will send unqualified support to the ADF. In addition, it is necessary that, when they return, proper services are put in place to ensure that they are debriefed not only in the military sense but also because they will have experienced a range of circumstances that, gratefully, most Australians will never face.

The minister, Mr Downer, stated in a press statement on 20 September 1999 that Australia's lead role in the multinational peacekeeping force in East Timor `could be wound up before Christmas' and that INTERFET `would probably complete its task in three months'. I seek some comfort from this, but it is not enough to rely on this. The government must plan for contingencies. It is not enough to be hopeful that circumstances will draw to a close in three months.

However, it is critical that this government also look to the future and examine its ability to respond over time to this crisis and others. The government needs to assure the Australian community that it can and will maintain soldiers in the field for as long as it takes. It can be done; it requires planning now—planning that this government needs to take, such as making sure that the part-time army is well resourced and that a new cooperative spirit is put in place to ensure that employers recognise the contribution that they make and can make in times like this. Legislation to encourage job security for part-time soldiers and recognition of part-time service is long overdue.

I have received many faxes and emails from people who are concerned about the situation in East Timor. The faxes and emails call on us as politicians to do whatever is necessary to help restore law and order in East Timor. A concerned person from Toowoomba begged—and I am paraphrasing here—that we bring pressure to alleviate the suffering in East Timor. Another asked senators to use their influence to help East Timor. The email went on to say that they felt deep shame at the lack of effective action taken by our Prime Minister and the desperate state we have left these people in after encouraging them to vote for independence.

On a saddening note, some of the messages I have received do not portray Indonesia in a positive light. Efforts need to be put in to make it plain that our concern is not with the people of Indonesia. Some quarters may wrongly use this opportunity to drive a wedge between us and Indonesia or for other ill-conceived purposes. Australia is part of the Asia-Pacific region. Our place is to be understanding and caring, and to lead by example in the region. This does not mean that those individuals responsible for the horrors which have occurred should not be brought to account. It is clear that we must spend time reiterating this point.

It is also necessary to recognise the contribution of our union movement. It has taken action when the government was silent. Our humanitarian response has been and needs to be swift and generous. The safe haven visa is one response that is applauded. This government must not rest now; it must continue to challenge and explore all possibilities. In addition, community support for the ADF is to be encouraged. I encourage citizens to embrace programs that demonstrate support for our ADF.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —Order! The motion having been approved, I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I rise to declare my formal position on the issue of Australia becoming a republic. I entered the Senate eight years ago as a constitutional monarchist and stand here tonight as a republican. My journey over this time parallels that of many of my colleagues. In the federal parliamentary Liberal Party at present, the balance between the constitutional monarchists and the republicans stands at about fifty-fifty. This is a major shift in Liberal Party sentiment.

speech.para: It was only five years ago that the Young Liberals in Sydney had the temerity to suggest to the state council of the party that they should debate the proposition that Australia become a republic—just debate it. The motion created uproar. A mere five years later, such a suggestion would be considered passe.

Leading the debate in the councils of the Liberal Party at that time was Marise Payne. Three years before entering the Senate, Marise Payne stuck to her principles as a member of the Australian Republican Movement and eloquently backed the then unpopular cause of the republic in the councils of the Liberal Party at that time. Tonight I pay tribute to her personal and political courage. With a Senate preselection imminent, it was—to quote Yes, Minister—a `courageous stand'.

But, tonight, Senator Payne's stand is not radical. Many Liberals have been won over to the republican cause by the sheer weight of the argument—people like Marie Wood, former President of the Women's Council of the Liberal Party, who would have called herself a conservative. At that time, she and I accepted the traditional monarchist argument that `if it ain't broke, don't fix it'.

Of course, our current system of government has served us very well to this point in our political evolution. But as we stand at the beginning of the new century it is time to move on, just as we decided 100 years ago that it was time to move on when we formed the Australian Federation. At that time, Australia was seen as a laboratory for democratic reform. Back then, a growing number of people began to see themselves as liberal democrats, people who rejected tyranny of all kinds—particularly hierarchy and privilege. Indeed, before Federation, in this laboratory we had created for democratic reform, Aus tralia had already achieved secret ballots, universal male voting and the abolition of property qualifications of MPs—all things that we take for granted now but which at the time were considered quite progressive.

When we adopted an Australian federation in 1901 under the aegis of the British Empire, we also adapted the British Westminster system of democratic government. This also brought with it for Australia the considerable economic benefits of our special trading arrangements with the British Empire. But during this century our formal ties with Britain have slowly faded. Special trading arrangements ended in 1962 when Britain entered the European Economic Community. In 1971 Britain shut down its defence presence east of Suez. God Save the Queen was replaced by Advance Australia Fair in 1984. And appeals to the Privy Council formally ended with the passage of the Australia Act in 1986. Now, as we stand on the edge of a new century, the ties to our former colonial master are purely symbolic.

Just as we grasped change at the end of the l9th century, it is now time, at the end of the 20th century, to move on. Now it is time to take the next step in our political evolution. If our symbolic ties to the British monarchy serve no useful economic, political or strategic value, why keep them and create an impression in the rest of the world that Australia is not a truly independent nation?

This point was brought home to me very starkly during a luncheon in honour of the United States President, Bill Clinton, in 1997 in parliament's Great Hall. Like many of my colleagues, I crossed the Rubicon between the constitutional monarchy and the republic at the point of toasts offered by the Prime Minister and the US President. Mr Howard toasted the President of the United States. Mr Clinton toasted Queen Elizabeth II. The protocol was impeccable but the exchange seemed totally bizarre to many observers.
It is time to move on and to become a truly independent nation in reality and perception.

It is time for an Australian republic. We have spent most of the 1990s debating what shape a republic would take. The proposed republic represents a small evolutionary step, much smaller than the step we took in 1901.

It is unfortunate that such a reasonable proposition has been subjected to such a smear campaign by some of the pro status quo mob. Terms like ethnic cleansing and appeasers, invoking the images of the German Weimar Republic before the rise of Hitler and talk of a possible coup have no place in this debate. Such a campaign has been branded as inflammatory, unnecessary and irrational.

As the Attorney-General, Daryl Williams, has pointed out, what is proposed is a small but very important change for Australia. The model is home grown. The proposal does not affect the present powers in the Constitution. It would not give the President more powers than or different powers from the Queen's representative in Australia, the Governor-General. We are assured of this by the Attorney-General, Daryl Williams, former Governor-General Sir Zelman Cowan and two former High Court chief justices, Sir Anthony Mason and Sir Gerard Brennan.

Surely this is an evolutionary improvement—a less capricious selection of a head of state while maintaining the rest of our political system with all its checks and balances. We will keep our two houses of parliament, our Prime Minister, our legal system, our Constitution, our flag and our membership of the British Commonwealth. Let us seize this historic opportunity to have a head of state chosen on merit, not by privilege of birth—an Australian President who represents our unique Australian identity as we face the new millennium, someone who will proudly promote Australia and our interests first, someone who is one of us. I urge all my colleagues to support the yes case for an Australian republic at the November referendum. A republic will deliver a fully independent Australia in perception and reality.

subdebateinfo.title: Bureau of Air Safety Investigation: Confidential Aviation Incident Reports
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 682)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 21 April 1999:

question.para: (1) Is the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) required to fully investigate all confidential aviation incident reports (CAIRs).

(2) Was a CAIR submitted to BASI concerning a breakdown in separation, on 28 January 1999, between a Cessna twin-engine aircraft, which was in cloud on final approach for runway 15 at Cairns and a Navajo aircraft, which was turned in front of the Cessna by Cairns air traffic control (ATC).
(3) Did BASI immediately move to ensure that the Cairns radar tapes relating to the above incident were secure so they would be available for its investigation; if not, why not.
(4) Did BASI immediately advise Airservices Australia (ASA) of the incident; if so, when was ASA contacted; if not, why not.
(5) Did BASI interview any of the ATC staff at Cairns who were on duty at the time of the incident and the pilots of the aircraft involved; if not, why not.
(6) (a) Did the ATC manager at Cairns Airport advise the BASI investigator that the incident did not require further investigation; and (b) what was the investigator's response to that advice.
(7) Did BASI suspend its inquiries into the incident as a result of the advice from the Cairns ATC manager.
(8) Did Cairns ATC management advise controllers at that airport to disregard the CAIR into the breakdown of two aircraft at the airport on 28 January 1999; if so, what was the basis for that advice.
(9) (a) What were the findings of the BASI investigations; and (b) can a copy be provided of both the interim and final BASI reports.
(10) What actions did ASA take following the receipt of the BASI report on the incident at Cairns Airport on 28 January 1999.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

answer.para: (1) No. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) has advised that Section 19CB of the Air Navigation Act 1920 (the Act) determines the Director's powers to investigate accidents etc., in particular, Sub Section 19CB(2), does not impose on the Director [of BASI] any duty to investigate a particular accident, serious incident, incident or safety deficiency. Sub Section 19CB(3) of the Act determines that the Director is not subject to any liability whatever for failing to investigate a particular accident, serious incident, incident or safety deficiency.

(2) Yes. BASI has advised that a CAIR report was received on 3 February 1999. The report mainly concerned local Cairns ATC management issues, but also alleged a breakdown in separation standards on 28 January 1999 near Cairns. The report did not provide sufficient information to identify the aircraft allegedly involved.

(3) No. BASI has advised that other than the CAIR report received on 3 February 1999 alleging a breakdown of separation standards, no incident reports had been received from pilots or air traffic controllers reporting the same occurrence. (Had a breakdown in separation standards occurred, incident reports would have been expected from the pilots and air traffic controllers involved as it is a requirement under the Act that occurrences involving a breakdown in separation standards are immediately notified to BASI.) On 18 February the CAIR reporter was interviewed, and the breakdown in separation standards issue was raised. Based on the information provided in that interview, the radar and audio tapes were requested from Airservices Australia. The recorded radar data was not available as the tapes had since been recycled in accordance with normal operational practice. Information gained from recorded audio transmissions could not corroborate the reported breakdown in separation.

(4) BASI has advised that the existence of a CAIR report was briefly mentioned to the Manager of Air Traffic Services Cairns in early February 1999 during a conversation on another matter. Airservices advises that it was not provided with sufficient detail to take any action until 18 February when a request was received from BASI for audio and radar tapes.

(5) BASI has advised that the Manager of Cairns ATC, the Tower and Terminal Control Unit "Stream Specialists" and the CAIR reporter were interviewed a number of times. The CAIR report did not provide sufficient information to identify the aircraft allegedly involved.
(8) No. ATC management reiterated to controllers the requirement to report any incidents.
(9) (a) and (b) BASI has advised that its initial inquiries determined that there was insufficient evidence to warrant further investigation.
(10) Upon receipt of information pertaining to the CAIR report alleging a breakdown of separation Cairns Airservices management immediately commenced a preliminary investigation.

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Audit by International Civil Aviation Organisation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1168)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 5 July 1999:

question.para: (1) Is the Civil Aviation Safety Authority to be the subject of an audit by the International Civil Aviation Organisation in August 1999; if so, on whose initiative is the audit to take place.
(2) On how many occasions has such an audit taken place.
(3) Who will actually undertake the audit.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes. The International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) conducted a safety audit of Australia from 9—20 August 1999. The 32nd Session of the ICAO Assembly (Montreal, September/October 1998) unanimously adopted Resolution A32-11 regarding the establishment of an ICAO Universal Safety Oversight Audit program providing for regular, mandatory, systematic and harmonised safety audits to be carried out by ICAO. The audit examined Australia's compliance with safety-related standards and recommended practices of ICAO. ICAO intends to conduct audits of all 185 Contracting States over the 1999-2001 triennium.
(2) This was the first audit of Australia under ICAO's Universal Safety Oversight Audit program.
(3) The audit was undertaken by a team selected by ICAO, comprising staff of the ICAO Secretariat and experts seconded to the program by other Contracting States.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 5 July 1999:

(2) See (1) above.
(3) See (1) above.
