question.para: (1) Is Airservices Australia upgrading and extending the National Aeronautical Information Processing System; if so: (a) when was the decision taken to upgrade and extend the system; (b) who made that decision; (c) when will the work be completed; and (d) what will the upgrade and extension cost.
(2) Has Airservices Australia engaged any consultants as part of the process of upgrading and extending the system; if so was the consultancy the subject of a tender process; if not, why not.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Airservices Australia has advised that:
(1) Yes.

(a) and (b) The National Aeronautical Information Processing System (NAIPS) is a software program supporting the delivery of briefing information, the processing of Notices to Airmen (NOTAM) and the processing of flight plans. As such it is subject to continuous improvement, with each improvement being subject to the preparation of a business case and the necessary approvals.

(c) NAIPS upgrades and enhancements are ongoing activities that are programmed to meet customer needs through out the asset life. Each enhancement stage has its own specific implementation schedule. The program is reviewed annually to ensure that appropriate benefits are associated with any expenditure.
(d) A total of $725K was spent on NAIPS upgrades and enhancements during 1998/99 and $656K is budgeted for 1999/00. A further $450K is included in Airservices project expenditure program for 2000/01.

(2) Airservices uses contractors when necessary to supplement its NAIPS development and support team. Airservices was originally tied to a single supplier for all NAIPS software support. However, to reduce costs, a more cost effective method of using a combination of internal and contract staff has been adopted. As such, Airservices has retained two contractors on a fixed daily rate to support NAIPS. A separate contract is being let with a specialist software house to assist in introducing an Internet facility. Given the limited availability of qualified contractors to assist in the NAIPS activities, formal tendering was not used on these occasions.

subdebateinfo.title: Regional Airlines: National Aeronautical Information Processing System
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1215)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 26 July 1999:

question.para: (1) How many regional airlines currently have access to the National Aeronautical Information Processing System.

(2) Does Airservices Australia have a program to extend access to the system to all regional airlines, training schools and other regular flying organisations such as the Royal Flying Doctor Service; if so: (a) what is the current timetable for the roll-out of the system; (b) what is the cost of the roll-out of the system to Airservices Australia; and (c) what is the cost to individual system users.
(3) What savings, in the form of reduced labour needs, will result from the full roll-out of the system.
(4) What is the scheduled reduction in staff involved in the provision of flight information services as the system is extended.

(5) What arrangements does Airservices Australia have in place to ensure adequate staff are available to provide flight information services if there is a delay in the roll-out and upgrade of the system.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Airservices Australia has advised that:

(1) Access to the National Aeronautical Information Processing System (NAIPS) is available to all regional airlines through the pilot access functionality, provided they have suitable computing equipment including a modem. At this stage only a small number of regional airlines are using the system.
(2) Yes.

(a) The roll out of the new pilot access functionality is currently taking place with the timetable to have the majority of regional airlines using the system by 1 December 1999. Other users will be encouraged to use this method of access on an ongoing basis.

(b) Airservices' cost of the roll out of the new interface is part of the cost of a number of interrelated improvements being introduced through the Aeronautical Data Service business strategy and has not been separately costed. Information on the overall cost is provided in response to Senate Question on Notice Number 1214.

(c) The software to use the NAIPS pilot access functionality is being provided by Airservices free of charge and currently access is via a toll free number. The cost of providing the overall briefing service is included in other charges such as enroute charges.
(3) The savings will depend on the number of electronic users, but are expected to be up to $4m per annum.
(4) It is anticipated that up to 40 staff may be affected.
(5) Reductions in staffing levels will occur as workload falls and management will ensure staff are not released prematurely.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Maritime Safety Authority: Emergency Beacons
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1227)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 5 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Has the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) investigated the safety problems associated with a multiplicity of interfering signals from many radiating 121.5 megahertz emergency beacons within a small area as occurred in the 1998 Sydney to Hobart yacht race; if so:
(a) has the investigation been completed;
(b) what other agencies and organisations were involved in the investigation; and
(c) what was the outcome of the investigation.
(2) Can a copy be provided of the report of the investigation.
(3) If there has been no investigation by AMSA of this matter, why not.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Following the 1998 Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) conducted a questionnaire of aircraft pilots involved in the search and rescue effort. The purpose of the questionnaire was to establish whether lessons could be learned from their experiences and observations. Of the 52 questions in the questionnaire, two related to the effects of multiple signals from emergency beacons in the search area.

In addition AMSA has responded to the Cruising Yacht Club of Australia's (CYCA) investigation of the race. AMSA's advice relating to multiple beacon signals is reflected in the CYCA's `Report of the 1998 Sydney Hobart Race Review Committee'.
AMSA is also assisting with the Coronial Inquest into the race and has provided material on emergency beacons, to the Inquest.
(a) AMSA's questionnaire of pilots involved in the search and rescue effort is complete.
(b) Apart from the pilots involved in the search and rescue effort, no other agencies or organisations were involved in AMSA's questionnaire.

(c) Nine of the 13 respondents indicated that search aircraft experienced difficulties because of the multiple beacon signals. Three survey responses also provided some suggestions as to how such difficulties might be alleviated in future incidents. This information has been taken directly from the two relevant questions contained in the survey.
(2) AMSA has not prepared a report of its questionnaire of aircraft pilots involved in the search and rescue effort.
(3) Refer to Question 1.

subdebateinfo.title: Roads of National Importance Program: Funding
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1229)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 5 August 1999:

question.para: (1) (a) What procedures are followed in assessing applications from state governments, local government authorities and community groups for funding through the Roads of National Importance (RONI) program; and (b) who undertakes the assessment.
(2) By type of applicant, how many applications for funding through the RONI program were assessed in the 1997-98, 1998-99 and to date in the 1999-2000 financial years.
(3) How many applications were approved in the above financial years.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) There is no formal application process for Roads of National Importance (RONI) funding. In its RONI program, the Government is responding to a strong view in the community that its road responsibilities extend further than the National Highway network.
Candidate roads are selected against the issued guidelines, the Government's assessment of community needs and available funding.
(b) The Government makes the assessment of which roads will receive funding.

(2) There is no application process for RONI funding. Numerous requests for funding assistance are received from time to time from State and local governments and a wide range of community groups for many roads across Australia. It would be a significant diversion of resources to provide a list of these requests.
(3) The Government agreed to provide funding for 3 RONIs in 1997-98, 1 in 1998-99 and 3 to date in 1999-2000.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 12 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Is the Stevedoring Industry Levy Act still in effect and are the arrangements the Act underpinned still in place; if so, when does the Government intend to wind up the above arrangements.

(2) If the above arrangements are no longer in existence: (a) when were they wound up; (b) how were any moneys remaining in the fund at that time dispersed; (c) how much money was distributed; and (d) who received the funds.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes. The Government is working to wind up the arrangements as soon as possible.
(2) Not applicable.

subdebateinfo.title: Imported Uncooked Chicken Meat: Risk Assessment Panel
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1253)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 18 August 1999:

question.para: (1) When did the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) commence the process of establishing a panel to oversee the risk assessment of imported uncooked chicken meat.
(2) (a) When was the panel established; (b) who is on the panel; (c) what are the qualifications of panel members; and (d) what process was followed to select panel members.
(3) Who has been appointed to chair the panel.

(4) (a) How advanced is the uncooked chicken meat risk assessment process; and (b) what is the estimated completion time for each of the remaining steps in the process as set out in the AQIS Risk Assessment Handbook.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) commenced the import risk analysis (IRA) for uncooked chicken meat in December 1998.
(2) and (3) AQIS will shortly consult stakeholders on the membership of the Risk Analysis Panel (RAP).
(4) (a) After consultation with stakeholders AQIS has decided that the non-routine approach be followed for this risk analysis and is in the process of selecting members for the RAP.

(b) The RAP, when formed, will develop a work program. If the RAP identifies a requirement for external technical inputs, there may be consequences for the timing of the various stages of the IRA. Without prejudging the RAP's consideration of its work program, AQIS anticipates that the issues paper will be released in December 1999, the draft IRA paper in May 2000 and the final recommendations brought forward for consideration by the Executive Director of AQIS in October 2000.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Finance and Administration: United Nations Peacekeeping Operations
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1338)

question.para: Is any money owed to the department by the United Nations or its agencies for peacekeeping operations in which Australia has participated; if so, how much.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Finance and Administration has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: No.
